story:
Showtimes are September 12, 13 and 14, at MoHA, here in Austin, TX. Tickets available HERE!!!

 

Short Summary

Art Sex Magic is a surreal, sincere, and musical exploration of the inspirations and pitfalls of the creative process in the age of social media.

The story unfolds as the archetypal hero's journey, of an artist navigating a reality where art and identity exist on the internet, expectations run sky high and the future remains uncertain. 

Finding her self in a parallel dimension, the artist (and audience) encounter the inner critics and the muses, animated by the artist's Masks and Paintings magically come to life!

Through their wise counsel, musical inspiration and guided meditations, she takes the audience on a journey to re-learn how to feel our bodies and emotions, re-define the meaning of success, integrate pleasure into our process, and embrace our sexual identity and expression!

ART SEX MAGIC: A Jazz Opera, will be showing at the Museum of Human Achievement, in Austin, Texas September 13th-15th. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need development capital, and in addition to offering you an Inspiring, Immersive Theatrical Experience, we have swag to offer as well! Among those offerings are unique merchandise and experiences brought to you by local artists, musicians, and performers dedicating their crafts to the development of our story:

The Erotic Jazz Cabaret with our writer Jade Fusco, of DMZL

A variety of photographic and sensory experiences by our producer: Geof Krum of Cheshire Events.

Limited Edition, A.S.M. themed leather goods by our Art Director: Tressa Gilmer of Kaimera Leather.

Original prints and t-shirt designs by our writer and star, Jade Fusco.

A titillating VIP experience in the theater. 

Custom magical Art. 

Our forever gratitude. 

 

The Impact

Things your contribution will directly allow us to develop :

Original costuming by our fabulous local designer.

Original set and prop designs by our amazing art department.

An original score composed by the best musicians in Austin.

Promo and media development for future runs of the production.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please like, and share our campaign on your social media accounts, share our vision with your word and encourage your friends, family, and colleagues to help us! 

You can contact us directly for opportunities to work with us developing our set, managing our stage, and generally supporting our production needs!

 

We also accept donations through our fiscal sponsor for those of you interested in a tax-deductible receipt. Please contact us directly for more details!

story:
Summary

This musical has gone through several stages of development. There was a staged reading in Las Vegas in 2017. Some of the music was presented at A Little New Music, the ASCAP foundation showcase for new musicals, in LA in 2019. The next step is a reading here in New York. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2500 for this stage of the production. This will pay for performance space, rehearsal space, and stipends for the performers.

Among the perks you can get are VIP seats to the reading (this is a private reading, not open to the public), invitation to the cast party, and exclusive recorded tracks. 

The Impact

Theater is extremely difficult to create, produce, and finance. You need space, actors, musicians, and a host of other things. To get them you need money. Our dream is to see this musical receive a full production on Broadway, but there are many steps to climb before that happens. Your contribution will help us to take the next one!

story:
overview

I'm raising funds to support a production of my play, Term of Art, at JACK in January, 2020 as part of the Exponential Festival.

Term of Art draws on (takes from, writes over) Supreme Court transcripts dealing with detention and immigration in order to make audible the arbitrariness of our laws and limitations, particularly with regard to what is already an arbitrary limit, the border.

Through a series of fragmentary scenes performed by a cast of four speakers moving through many voices, Term of Art examines the relationship between two contemporary instances of U.S. American injustice: the inhumane and ongoing detentions of refugees and immigrants inside our borders, and the torture and indefinite detention without trial of prisoners at Guantánamo Bay.

Meanwhile, a transcriptionist tries (and fails) to keep pace with the accumulating material of injustice.

I'm a playwright and director based in Brooklyn, NY and Wise, VA, where I teach playwriting at the University of Virginia's College at Wise. I received my MFA from Brooklyn College, and am the editor the experimental play publishing organization, 53rd State Press.

collaborators

All funds from this campaign will go directly to supporting the work of my brilliant cast and production team:

  • Kate Kremer - playwright + director
  • Anne Cecelia Demelo - associate director
  • Michael Costagliola - sound designer
  • Lance K. Lewis - lighting designer
  • Jeannipher Pacheco - costume designer
  • Priscilla Villanueva* - stage manager
  • Ash Mayers - transcriptionist
  • Bryce Payne - speaker
  • Rava Raab - transcriptionist
  • Jorge Sánchez-Díaz - speaker
  • Isabella Sazak - speaker
  • Jenna Zafiropoulos - speaker

*Campaign and video cover photo features Bryce Payne in the Aug 2018 production. Photo by Jorge Luna.

project history

Image: Untitled (arches) by Martín Ramírez

In the winter of 2018, I was looking at the work of detained writers and artists: Mansoor Adayfi, Moath al Alwi, Khalid Qasim, and Mohamedou Ould Salahi, who were detained at Guantánamo, and Martín Ramírez, who immigrated to the U.S. in 1925 from Mexico and spent most of the rest of his life detained in U.S. institutions.

I was thinking about materials, the way, when one is detained, one uses whatever's at hand: cardboard painted with stains made from coffee grounds, old shirts stiffened with glue, bottle caps, gravel, sand rock, charcoal from used wooden matches, juice extracted from grapefruits. Ramírez pieced his canvases together from any scrap paper he could find, expanding them in the direction of his interest.

It occurred to me that law is also pieced together out of whatever cases are at hand, and that it too is responsive to our interests and prejudices, though we like to imagine it is smooth, whole, unbiased. I began reading Supreme Court cases dealing with detention and immigration. In Hernández v. Mesa, a case involving Mexican boy standing in Mexico who was shot and killed by an American officer standing in the United States, the question is raised: how is this different from a drone strike in Iraq piloted from Nevada?

The Justices want to draw a firm boundary between these two kinds of killing. They might like to hold the man accountable for the murder of the boy, but they don’t want to hold the United States accountable for the murder of, to date, between 769-1,725 civilians, including 253-397 children. They want these killings to remain extralegal, that is, outside the law.

As it happens, illegal and extralegal are different, and what is outside the law can easily move inward, and can, as we've seen, become the law of the land.

An early iteration of Term of Art was presented at the Public Theater as part of the Weasel Festival in August 2018. It featured Schann Rae Mobley, Bryce Payne, and Jenna Zafiropoulos as speakers, and Sara Brown, Andriana Georgitsis, Ash Mayers, and Rava Raab as transcriptionists.

Since then, I've revised and rewritten the play, in part to account for all that has happened since that time. This summer, we workshopped the new script (and filmed footage for the video above!) with Janice Amaya, Megan Branch, Johnathan Dougan, Bryce Payne, and Jenna Zafiropoulos.

Ash Mayers as the transcriptionist in Aug 2018. Costume by Jeannipher Pacheco; photo by Jorge Luna.

    your support

    The support we have received thus far ($7,000 in grants and stipends) has been crucial to the project’s development. Now, with a total budget of $14,000, we are working to raise the remaining $7,000 needed to present Term of Art in its final iteration.

    91% of the total budget for the production (and all of the funds from this campaign) will go  directly toward paying to the incredible artists involved in the project. I'm deeply grateful and honored to be working with such diverse and brilliant people, among them immigrants and the children of immigrants. We are queer, gender non-conforming, multiracial, and multilingual, and it is immensely important to me to pay these artists equitably. Many have been involved with the project since its earliest iteration, and the play has been written with, for, and alongside them.

    risks + challenges

    We are working within a tight time frame on play that is rigorous and complex, and which requires a great deal of technical skill and emotional courage from performers. I feel immensely lucky to be working with this beautiful, generous company, and I'm confident that we can make something marvelous and strange.

    We would also like to respectfully acknowledge that the land on which the play will be rehearsed and performed is the unceded territory of the Lenape and Canarsie peoples. Many of the legal mechanisms that Term of Art critiques were first deployed against Native American peoples. As Maggie Blackhawk has argued here and here, the legal infrastructure of those injustices has not yet been dismantled, and, in fact, is now being used to justify family separation, migrant detention camps, religious persecution, and U.S. drone policy.

    We wish to recognize the Indigenous peoples who have been dispossessed from their homelands and territories, and to affirm our commitment to the process of working to dismantle the ongoing legacies of settler colonialism.

    other ways you can help

    I would deeply appreciate whatever support you can give to this project, whether by donating, spreading the word about our campaign on social media, or by coming to see the show at JACK in January.

    I have also included below a list of links to organizations whose work combatting these injustices has given me hope and heart over the past few years of working on this play:

    • RAICES
    • Immigrant Families Together
    • American Immigration Lawyers Association: Dilley Pro Bono Project
    • ACLU Immigrants Rights working group
    • Constitutional Law Center for Muslims in America
    • Association on American Indian Affairs
    • Native American Rights Fund

    Thank you so much for your love and support! It means so very much.

RAICES
Immigrant Families Together

Constitutional Law Center for Muslims in America
Association on American Indian Affairs
Native American Rights Fund

Thank you so much for your love and support! It means so very much.

story:
ANOTHER AIRPORT CLOSING! GOES TO DUBLIN!

SAILOR BEWARE is taking ANOTHER AIRPORT CLOSING to the international stage! SAILOR BEWARE has been invited to participate in the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival 2018 (www.gaytheatre.ie). We are honored. This will be SAILOR BEWARE'S first time at this great festival and we need your support to make this happen!

The play will run for eight performances, May 7 - 12, 2018 at the Teacher's Club on Parnell Square. The play is a one-man show and the playwright, Jody O'Neil, who also performs his own show, and the director, Margaret Van Sant, will represent Provincetown, Massachusetts at the 2018 IDGTF.

ANOTHER AIRPORT CLOSING is a brilliant evening of theater.  This one-man comedy tells the story of a groom, who may or may not, have been abandoned at the alter. As he waits to hear from his fiancee, he entertains the audience with the story of his romance with a world-traveling fashion buyer. Will he show up? Or is he stuck in some exotic locale such as Bali, Rome, or Marseille? Should he abandon all hope? Or just dry his eyes and cut the cake? A novel twist answers these questions.

The show has deep roots in Provincetown, the birthplace of modern American theater. Jody is  member of the Provincetown Playwrights Lab, and the play was performed at the Art House in Provincetown to great success.

HELP SAILOR BEWARE GET TO IRELAND

Your contribution (of any amount) will help fund the following:

Roundtrip airfare from Boston to Dublin for the company

The cost of a furnished flat (with kitchen and laundry!) in Dublin for them to stay. And presumably cook and do laundry.

Postcards, posters and playbills.

A per diem so the actors don't have to go out busking in the street! (Though they can if they want to).

Basic groceries to save money on dinner out.

Other Ways:

Many of you are artists trying to get your own work up and running... sometimes you're just not able to contribute in cash. But we still need (and love!) you!

Please share, re-post, tweet, busk and otherwise spread the word about our ANOTHER AIRPORT CLOSING campaign. And:

Send your Irish friends to the International Gay Dublin Theatre Festival and ANOTHER AIRPORT CLOSING.

Come and see us in Dublin…we’ll play great pub games after the show.

https://youtu.be/FJScyC1_Lso

WHO WE ARE:

SAILOR BEWARE

A Cape Cod Coalition of Actors’ Equity Association Members

Long-form Theater in a Low Means Mode

Sailor Beware is a Cape-based collective of theater professionals dedicated to the dramatiz-ation of bold, new full-length American plays and musicals that by their design cast-off creative and financial constraints to the wind and sea in a spirit of unbridled imagination.

JODY O'NEIL

Jody O'Neil is a New York/Cape Cod-based actor, writer, director and founder of Sailor Beware; a Cape Cod coalition of Actors’ Equity Association members, devoted to readings of new American full-length plays and musicals. For five years he was a show writer at Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS where he handed off cue cards to everyone from Jane Fonda and Nathan Lane to Hugh Jackman and Catherine Zeta-Jones. He was a writer and director on the popular WE Network show, “Cinematherapy,” and his short plays have been widely produced in New York and on the Cape. Recent  stage work has swung the gamut from a Cockney junkie Claire in The Maids and a DJ-spinning Mephisto in Doctor Faustus Lights the Lights to a pair of iconic O’Neill roles: Tyrone, Jr. in A Moon for the Misbegotten and Chris Christofferson in Anna Christie. Last summer, he created the duel roles of Sister Etcetera/Older Trevor in Mark Sonnenblick’s Bistro Award-winning musical cabaret, Midnight at the Never Get, in Provincetown and NYC. On screen, he has seduced co-star Margot Kidder in a wicked tango in Never Met Picasso and rallied around Samuel L. Jackson as one of Mango’s Boys on Saturday Night Live. Currently, he can be seen in HUM, his half-hour debut film concerning a cellular apocalypse, and as failed banker Ivan Zamir in the locally-produced 14-part mini-series, OFFSEASON, streaming on Amazon Prime.

MARGARET VAN SANT

MARGARET VAN SANT is a playwright, theater director, festival organizer, educator, and the Artistic Director of Provincetown Dramatic Arts. She has directed classic and contemporary theater, but has a special focus on the development of new scripts. At Long Wharf Theater she managed the Stage II program of new script development, and at the PTC she established the Playwright’s Lab and the Provincetown Playwright’s Festival. She produces the annual Women’s International Theater Festival. She has directed at Virginia Stage Company, Long Wharf Theater, Arena Stage, Yale University (National Conference on Portuguese Theater), Yale Cabaret, Berkshire Theater Festival, University of Massachusetts/ Dartmouth, City Studio Theater, Payomet Center for the Performing Arts, and Provincetown Theater. For the past four years she has taken a play by a Cape playwright to the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival and in turn has brought a play from the IDGTF to Provincetown for performances. Van Sant organized the Centennial Celebration of The Provincetown Players, THEN AND NOW, where she directed THE SNIPER by Eugene O’Neill. She is a past member of the Provincetown Theater Board and directed their Rat Pack Lounge New Year’s Gala in 2015 and 2016. She is a proud member of the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society, the Playwright’s Forum in Washington, DC, the Provincetown Playwrights Lab, and holds an MFA in Interdisciplinary Arts from Goddard College.

story:
Who are we?                                                                          

Edinburgh based SpartaKi are committed to producing professional, affordable and accessible productions, dealing with political, social and cultural issues, current or relevant to Scotland.  As well as established local/national venues, SpartaKi tour productions to communities who have, or feel they have been, previously excluded from access to the arts.  SpartaKi strive to promote equality and diversity and to be a fully inclusive company.

What are we raising money for?

We want to perform a staged reading of Letters from Area C, by Jim Aitken, in an Edinburgh venue on 2 November 2017, to mark the 100 year anniversary of the Balfour Declaration.

 

We are trying to raise £5000 towards the costs of creative development time with a director, professional actors and musician, followed by a work-in-progress performance on 2 November 2017. The money we raise will enable us to pay the artists and creative team at industry rates and cover travel costs; accessible venue and rehearsal space hire; equipment hire and technician fees, and publicity and other production costs.

Once all overheads have been covered, SpartaKi will donate all outstanding ticket revenue to Medical Aid for Palestinians (MAP)
 

About Letters from Area C

 

 

Area C is a land, like many lands today, where people have to find ways to keep going in the face of extreme hardship. The lives of ordinary people become extraordinary ones, and people discover hitherto unknown and profound depths, on which to draw to survive and keep hope alive.

An uplifting and inspiring tale of the triumph of humanity and dignity over adversity and oppression. The story of two women, Laila and her younger sister Hanin and two prisoners Jamal (Hanin’s husband) and Yusuf (a poet and activist).  While Jamal and Yusuf talk politics – and draw maps – in their prison cell, Leila, does whatever she can to help Hanin and her children, after their home is bombed.  To bolster Hanin’s spirits Leila even devises a plan to pass letters between Hanin and Jamal.

Letters from Area C is a real human interest story with a charming twist in its tail!

Creative Team

Directed by SpartaKi Artistic Director Karen Douglas, our highly talented cast includes Nabil Shaban (Theatre Workshop, National Theatre, Royal Court, Dr Who, City of Joy, Children of Men), Manjot Sumal (Scot Squad, How to Make a Killing in Bollywood), Ghizala Avan (Ae Fond Kiss, An Act of Terror, Tezz), Lubna Kerr (The 6th Child, Meet me by the Water, Saturn has a Ball),  Edith Peers (Grouch, Macbeth, King Jamie and the Witches, Leaving George) and Paul Murray (The Royal Lyceum, Traverse, Catch, Fifth Estate, Common Force).

Why we need your support?

One of the challenges of creating and presenting political theatre in this current austere climate is funding it. Although Letters from Area C is currently unfunded, we feel it is important to mark the 100 year anniversary of the Balfour Declaration and its catastrophic consequences for Palestine and Palestinians.

Your support of Letters from Area C will help in three ways: you will be helping to create a new piece of powerful political theatre; and raise awareness of, and discussion around the Balfour Declaration and its ongoing impact on the lives of ordinary Palestinians. And surplus ticket revenue will be donated to MAP.

Tokens of our appreciation

We have various tokens of appreciation for your contributions, including a signed copy of Nabil Shaban's play The First to Go, ticket packages, a personal poetry reading by Jim Aitken, or a full day workshop session with Karen Douglas.

We will be very grateful if you can contribute to our project, and/or share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested.

Anything you can give will help make this production happen, and highlight the plight of Palestinians today.

Many thanks for taking the time to read this.

***************************************************************************

Letters from Area C  written by Jim Aitken

Produced by SpartaKi

Adapted for stage and directed by Karen Douglas, Artistic Director SpartaKi

Edinburgh based SpartaKi are committed to producing professional, affordable and accessible productions, dealing with political, social and cultural issues, current or relevant to Scotland.  As well as established local/national venues, SpartaKi tour productions to communities who have, or feel they have been, previously excluded from access to the arts.  SpartaKi strive to promote equality and diversity and to be a fully inclusive company.What are we raising money for?We want to perform a staged reading of Letters from Area C, by Jim Aitken, in an Edinburgh venue on 2 November 2017, to mark the 100 year anniversary of the Balfour Declaration. We are trying to raise £5000 towards the costs of creative development time with a director, professional actors and musician, followed by a work-in-progress performance on 2 November 2017. story:
Who We Are

My name is Ashley McQueen and I am the Artistic Director of Smashworks Dance Collective. While pursuing my MFA in Dance from Hollins University, I also work as a freelance dancer, choreographer, and teaching artist for Notes In Motion Outreach Dance Theatre and West Side YMCA. Originally from Alabama, I received my BFA in Dance from Webster University and danced professionally in St. Louis for two years before relocating to New York.

Since establishing Smashworks Dance Collective in NYC, I have found my love in every aspect of this company. These dancers and this process have become more than just a creative exploration - Smashworks is my family, my home.

My goal is to continue developing an organization that ignites passion, prompts conversation, and showcases the value of the arts in society.  

The Company

Now in our third New York season, Smashworks Dance has grown immensely, having doubled the number of dancers and repertory pieces in just two years. From windows on Wall Street to the New York City Transit Museum, Smashworks has performed in over ten festivals across the five boroughs - including last year's "City Stories," an evening length performance at the Center for Performance Research in Brooklyn that was named a "Voice Choices" by the Village Voice. Last spring we hosted the Smashworks Film Festival, a dance film screening for emerging and established artists.

 This year, we are getting political.  

Smashworks will premiere FOR WHICH IT STANDS, an evening length work employing 8 performers who brilliantly explore a frightening world of absurd speeches, useless walls, and little plungers for little hands.

Consisting of 9 episodic dances with original sound score and projection installation, this satirical work seamlessly blends humor and reality by exploring themes within the current White House, from twitter-driven alternative facts to the literal and figurative walls built by this presidency. 

Dancers take on modern political figures and showcase the power of "nasty" women in the resistance against this administration's politics. Including  cameos from woods-walking Hillary and puppeteering Putin, FOR WHICH IT STANDS invites the audience to confront the contradictions of modern political discourse. 

This work will also include a work-in-process excerpt from my Master's Thesis - a solo that explores the woman body politic in Trump's America and the use of the American flag in concert dance performance. 

Performers: Sarah Starkweather, Sarah Dodd, Maria Garner, Maria Vittoria Villa, Jesse Obremski, Ellen Sickenberger, Laurie Deziel, Jenna Rae Smith, and Ashley McQueen.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our evening length performance will take place at the Center for Performance Research "CPR" on Friday, February 2 and Saturday, February 3, 2018 at 8:00pm. Theater performances are expensive, and we need your help to bring this experience to life.  Your support will contribute directly to dancer wages, theater rental, costume design, and rehearsal space. The full cost of the performance is detailed below:

Theater rental for two evening performances: $1400

Event insurance: $400

Dancer wages [7 dancers]: $2500

Rehearsal space rental: $400

Costume design/construction: $200

Performance Advertising: $100

Total Cost: $5000

All funds raised [no matter what the campaign outcome] will go towards paying for the expenses outlined above.

In addition to supporting this unique, innovative performance, your contribution will also grant you access to exclusive perks available at a wide range of donation levels from a social media shout out to a personalized dance video.

 

The Impact

Dance is an artistic platform that allows us to express personal creativity and to connect with others. Smashworks seeks to stimulate conversation and to bring together diverse perspectives, while creating a safe space for discussion and creative exploration.

In a time of uncertainty, divisiveness, and fear, the Arts (especially through comedy) can break down barriers, bring laughter to the somber, and serve as a platform to foster better understanding of each other.  It is my hope that Smashworks’ performances give the community an opportunity to come together and potentially catalyze political action.

In the past five years of choreographing professionally, my passion for working with dancers and bringing performances to life has grown. In creating this work, I have built upon a record of successful evening length performances in other cities, and with your support, we can continue that success in New York.

 

Risks & Challenges

As a dancer (and grad student) who works five (5) jobs to cover the costs of running a successful dance company, I understand the challenges of putting on a large production in New York. This performance is important because it provides a paid opportunity for our dancers to perform, network in the New York dance community, and have a positive professional experience that challenges them physically and artistically.

 

It is my goal to present this politically charged work during its relevancy.

It is our job as artists to resist, make waves, and provide an outlet of expression for those in our community.

 

With your help Smashworks can continue to develop and provide even more opportunities for live performance, education outreach, and creative exploration.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign on social media!

Stay in touch - Follow us on Facebook/Instagram or visit our website to join our mailing list!

Spread the word about Smashworks - and our upcoming performances!

story:
American Maniacs unLimited presents: The Spiro Agnew Memorial Variety Hour and Fish Fry Now With Real Fish!

In our nation's capital! During an election year! While there's an impeachment taking place!

Or so we hope to, if we can procure the funds needed to be able to travel to Washington, D.C to perform at the 2020 Capital Fringe Festival!

We are a Chicago-based Sketch Combat ensemble. We're like if Monty Python and Mel Brooks had a baby, and then the Animaniacs taught that baby how to sword fight. We are veterans of Elgin Fringe Festival and are looking to expand our reach!

In this American Maniacs unLimited original production, audiences can expect to see poetry, interpretive dance, cartoon violence, minimal ad breaks, Magic, unwavering eye-contact, Vikings, and perhaps the name sake of the event itself, only at The Spiro Agnew Variety Hour and Fish Fry Now with Real Fish!

So take flight on the wings of an eagle and soar majestically into this bizarre hellscape of artistic expression. Help us rise above the crippling effects of late-stage capitalism by sending us money and/or sharing our campaign. We'll take our special brand of satirical comedy right to the scene of the crime and if we're lucky, a senator or two will get to experience our infamous Mitch McConnell sketch.

What We Need

  • Festival/Insurance Fees, Due in FEBRUARY:
    $865
    Other costs based on previous experiences and market research:
  • Flying our 5 person ensemble out to Washington, D.C for the festival in JULY:
    $1,735 
  • Lodging for 3-4 nights during the festival:
    $500 
  • Car Rental/Fuel to haul props and costumes and us back and forth between our lodging and the performance venue:
    $400
  • Food, because we're human... (5 humans, 4 days):
    $500 

The Impact

Fascism is on the rise again. Comedy has always been an effective weapon against such a rise. American Maniacs unLimited is uniquely positioned to lend our voice in a way most audiences have not yet experienced in a typical sketch comedy show. We have trained extensively in theatre and film acting, stage combat and stunt work, comedy and clowning, studied writing at Second City, and we have a resident history buff/ World War I and II reenactor within our ranks. 

We revel in the absurd and the silly, in sharp wit and biting satire. We fight nihilism with optimism, and we fight optimism with nihilism. We offer cathartic release to the downtrodden. And to those who are abusing their positions of power, we punch up. 

There are plenty of downtrodden Americans in need of some cathartic release at this particular moment in history. And those abusing their positions of power could really use some getting punched...With comedy. 
 

Risks & Challenges

We are DIY.
We don't have a board of directors.
We don't have grants.
We don't have a sugar daddy.
We have a lot of student loans.
We have keen awareness of when a joke is considered protected by free speech, and when it is considered treason, but if we were to need to defend ourselves in a court of law, we wouldn't be able to afford a lawyer.

We take that risk anyway because we believe in what we're creating.

Most of our productions closer to home can be staged with little-to-no budget...(Either due to prop/costume accumulation from our many years in the business, or creative slap-dash construction with duct tape and cardboard.) Unfortunately for us, a cardboard airplane won't get us to any of the places we would like to be...

Our show is ready and raring to go for any audience that will have us, but we need help getting to those audiences. That's where you fine people come in!

Ways You Can Help

  • Donate money! $5.00...$500...$1.00...Any and all amounts will help!
    In order to secure our spot at Capital Fringe, we have to submit the Festival/Insurance fees in February (exact date TBD)...While most of our other costs won't be required for some time, those fees due in February are coming up quick. And rather than launch multiple fundraisers over the next couple months, we figured we'd go all in on this single campaign. ANY amount you can send our way is highly HIGHLY appreciated!
     
  • Share our campaign on social media!
    It costs nothing to do so, and the more buzz we can get surrounding this fundraiser, the better off we will be at the end of it! Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, any bus bench or telephone pole...Tell your friends! Family! Enemies! Teachers! Students! Congresspeople! If 8,000 people see this campaign and only half of them donate a single dollar, we'll have met our goal. 
     
  • Follow us!
    We are on Instagram and Facebook @AmericanManiacsUnlimited and we post behind-the-scenes photos and videos quite frequently! Those pages are also where you will find any upcoming show dates/details. We would be delighted see you in the audience at any of those shows!

story:
The Project

Following the Civil War, The Baltimore Gun Club turns their considerable artillery know how to sending a projectile to the moon. From The Earth To The Moon explores this largely forgotten historic event in a steampunk, revisionist, spectacularly epic fantasy.

I've been interested in adapting this story and it seemed like the 50 year anniversary of the moon landing is as good a time as ever. We'll start with a rough script and flesh out the story in the rehearsal room ... the more we raise the more rehearsals we can afford!! The show will be directed by Ariel Francoeur, Music Directed by Maya Bassuk, Choreographed by Christopher Noffke, with Projection Design by Taylor Edelle Stuart.

The Goal

We are looking for $5000 or more. Ideally, we would like to pay the artists, afford rehearsal space, have some scenic elements, and pick up some costumes ... maybe even have a band!

Donate and Share

Even if you can't give share with those who can! We're hoping this is just the beginning of the life of this project--get in on the ground floor!!

story:
WHO WE ARE:

Third Eye Theatre Ensemble presents quality productions of new or seldom performed operatic works that inspire conversation while advocating for human rights and social justice. We want to get people talking about the issues we face in today's world and hope the power of music and theater can inspire those conversations at a community level. This year we are partnering with the Chicago Women's Health Center. Their mission is to facilitate the empowerment of women and trans people by providing access to health care and health education in a respectful environment where people pay what they can afford. For every ticket purchased, Third Eye will donate $1 to this organization.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:

We work very hard to ensure all our productions are of the highest quality. One of our goals when we started the company was the ability to perform with an orchestra, rather than performing with only a piano. This is the year we are taking that exciting step! We'll be performing with a 7-piece chamber ensemble. This means we've had to move to a larger, more expensive space and hire a conductor, in addition to the orchestra members. This is a significant expense for us, but we believe it is the direction the company needs to move in order to offer our audiences the best possible experience. We hope you will believe in what we want to achieve and will contribute as generously as you can. Every bit helps, so even if you can only give $5, that still helps us get closer to our goal. With $5, we can buy 1/4 hour of rehearsal space!

WHAT YOU WILL GET:

Everyone who donates to our campaign (unless you choose to remain anonymous) will be listed on our website as a supporter of Third Eye Theatre Ensemble. Those who donate prior to 9/17 will be listed in our program. We have some fun perks this year. We are releasing our special Third Eye "Opera is Better with a Goat" line of products. It's a little joke we have at Third Eye as a tribute to our former stage director Rose Freeman. It became her motto because she had a crazy desire to put a goat on stage! You'll also get our undying gratitude, which we hope counts for a lot, and a feeling that you are making a difference. Each and every contribution, no matter the amount, helps us tremendously. Plus you're helping to keep the performing arts alive and bringing new opera to Chicago. Who wouldn't feel good about that?

WHERE THE MONEY GOES:

Artist Salaries (Singers, Directors, Designers, Orchestra, Conductor)

Sets, Lighting, Props, Costumes

Rehearsal Space Rental

Performance Space Rental

Truck Rental (for transporting set pieces and lighting equipment)

The Rights and Rental Fees to Perform Patience & Sarah

Insurance

Marketing

Unforeseen Expenses (we all know these happen!)

HOW DOES MY CONTRIBUTION HELP:

Here are some examples of what your specific contribution can do for us:

$10 buys 1/2 hour of rehearsal space rental

$25 buys 1/4 hour of truck rental

$50 buys 1/4 hour of performance space rental

$100 buys all of the props for our show

$250 buys 1/3 of the costumes for our show

$500 buys 1/2 of our set pieces and lighting equipment

$1000 buys the rights to perform Patience & Sarah

Other Ways You Can Help

Come and see the show, October 5 through October 21 (Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays)

Share this campaign with others who might be willing to contribue

Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/thirdeyete

Follow us on Twitter - https://twitter.com/ThirdEyeTE

Visit our website at www.thirdeyete.com and sign up for our emails

Sign up at iGive.com and shop online at over 1400 retailers who will donate a percentage of your purchase to us - http://www.igive.com/396NT6J

Sign up to support us on Amazon Smile - smile.amazon.com 

Help us spread the word!

Third Eye Theatre Ensemble presents quality productions of new or seldom performed operatic works that inspire conversation while advocating for human rights and social justice. We want to get people talking about the issues we face in today's world and hope the power of music and theater can inspire those conversations at a community level. This year we are partnering with the Chicago Women's Health Center. Their mission is to facilitate the empowerment of women and trans people by providing access to health care and health education in a respectful environment where people pay what they can afford. For every ticket purchased, Third Eye will donate $1 to this organization.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:
We work very hard to ensure all our productions are of the highest quality. One of our goals when we started the company was the ability to perform with an orchestra, rather than performing with only a piano. This is the year we are taking that exciting step! We'll be performing with a 7-piece chamber ensemble. This means we've had to move to a larger, more expensive space and hire a conductor, in addition to the orchestra members. This is a significant expense for us, but we believe it is the direction the company needs to move in order to offer our audiences the best possible experience. We hope you will believe in what we want to achieve and will contribute as generously as you can. Every bit helps, so even if you can only give $5, that still helps us get closer to our goal. With $5, we can buy 1/4 hour of rehearsal space!
WHAT YOU WILL GET:
Everyone who donates to our campaign (unless you choose to remain anonymous) will be listed on our website as a supporter of Third Eye Theatre Ensemble. Those who donate prior to 9/17 will be listed in our program. We have some fun perks this year. We are releasing our special Third Eye "Opera is Better with a Goat" line of products. It's a little joke we have at Third Eye as a tribute to our former stage director Rose Freeman. It became her motto because she had a crazy desire to put a goat on stage! You'll also get our undying gratitude, which we hope counts for a lot, and a feeling that you are making a difference. Each and every contribution, no matter the amount, helps us tremendously. Plus you're helping to keep the performing arts alive and bringing new opera to Chicago. Who wouldn't feel good about that?
WHERE THE MONEY GOES:
Artist Salaries (Singers, Directors, Designers, Orchestra, Conductor)
Sets, Lighting, Props, Costumes
Rehearsal Space Rental
Performance Space Rental
Truck Rental (for transporting set pieces and lighting equipment)
The Rights and Rental Fees to Perform Patience & Sarah
Insurance
Marketing
Unforeseen Expenses (we all know these happen!)

HOW DOES MY CONTRIBUTION HELP:
Here are some examples of what your specific contribution can do for us:
$10 buys 1/2 hour of rehearsal space rental
$25 buys 1/4 hour of truck rental
$50 buys 1/4 hour of performance space rental
$100 buys all of the props for our show
$250 buys 1/3 of the costumes for our show
$500 buys 1/2 of our set pieces and lighting equipment
$1000 buys the rights to perform Patience & Sarah

Other Ways You Can Help
Come and see the show, October 5 through October 21 (Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays)
Share this campaign with others who might be willing to contribue
Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/thirdeyete
Follow us on Twitter - https://twitter.com/ThirdEyeTE
Visit our website at www.thirdeyete.com and sign up for our emails
Sign up at iGive.com and shop online at over 1400 retailers who will donate a percentage of your purchase to us - http://www.igive.com/396NT6J
Sign up to support us on Amazon Smile - smile.amazon.com 
Help us spread the word!

story:
Who We Are

Flash in the Deadpan Productions began as a film company from the minds of Tim Phillips and Sandra Otter. With a natural flair and love for comedy they did what many good artists do and diversified into theatre.

We need your help taking that bold risk of switching from the screen to the stage. We have taken a passion project and want to share it with the world at the Toronto Fringe Festival. We love this play and the comedic joy it brings us and will bring to our audiences. We have gathered a large and talented team of collaborators and artists to bring this project to life and this is where we need you.

Why We Need Your Support

Theatrical shows are very expensive to create and produce. It is a difficult business that is truly fueled by love and ambition but when we go all in, it creates the most rewarding experience for the artists and audiences. We need your donations to help make this production happen! We need to rent rehearsal space, source props and costumes, and most importantly be able to thank the artists who are committing so much time and energy to this fast paced insane show! Let’s make The Joy of Sax at Toronto Fringe 2018 a success!

story:
Short Summary

'On the day of his death, an eminent Cambridge Professor is visited by the angel of his teenage self. He tries to write a great narrative poem as they journey from Cambridge to Heaven'

This fully dramatised performance of Remaking Heaven (Sam's First Day) was recorded in London, Cambridge, Berlin, Karlsruhe, Cirencester (and Heaven!).

It was written and produced by Paul Sutton, author of more than a dozen books, including Talking about Ken Russell, Understanding Gary Numan, and the novel, Charlie Ellis and the Day Trip to Mars. Sutton has written three unproduced screenplays with the great American filmmaker, John McTiernan.

Judith Paris co-stars. With dozens of screen credits to her name, from Dr. Who to The Phantom of the Opera, and with universal acclaim for her own recent theatre productions, on Women in World War One and the life of Madame Tussaud, Judith is one of Britain's top theatrical talents.

The cast also includes Harry Gostelow (known for his work with Alan Ayckbourn), Tom Fiennes, and introduces a new actor, a 14-year-old London schoolboy, Sam Phillips. 

The recording was made by David Martin, the renowned film editor, whose excellent work includes Alex Cox's cult film Sid and Nancy, starring Gary Oldman.

The  music for the play was written and recorded by Craig Walker, formerly of Archive, whose work in the cinema includes the song score for Luc Besson's Le Mans film, Michel Valiant. Craig Walker's song, Fade-out Lines, for The Avener, recently topped the charts all over Europe.

Our aim was to take recorded drama to places where the BBC dares not venture: wholly original literary drama packed with wit and ideas.

Remaking Heaven is bold and challenging and fun. It deals with the eternal theme of ‘life after death’ and offers a thought-provoking and original view of Heaven and the after-life.

A main theme is the sadnesses of youth and the pleasures of old age.

It looks too at the changing nature of higher education in England as it moves from the masculine of the old to the feminine of the new, and from the pastoral to the commercial (“The students have been causing trouble since we trebled their fees, in line with government policy”).

It’s also a play about the death of cinema, as cinema moved away from picture palaces to smartphones. Our heroes take a detour to a 70mm film screening in Germany.

For your support of this entirely new work of literary-audio art, we offer a range of small thank-you gifts, ranging from a download of David Martin's expert recording through to an invitation to join Murray Melvin and Paul Sutton for lunch at the BFI Southbank in London.

 

What We Need

We have borne the costs of the recording ourselves. We are seeking financing for distribution and promotion.

£500 will allow us to release the play on CD.

£500 will contribute to the promotion.

If we don't reach the goal, we will honour all your lovely pledges but we won't be able to have the CD pressed in sufficient quantities to allow us to make a profit; the play won't get promoted; the recording will not bring as much new joy and thought to the world as we hope it will.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to become an Associate Producer, dine with Murray Melvin, receive an exclusive hardback book or a signed photograph, nor add a CD or download to your collection, then you can still help us by being an Arts Angel and clicking the 'Back it' button and making a donation. Every little bit helps and will be gratefully received.

Please help us too to get the word out. Use all possible methods of communication to tell everyone you know that one of Stanley Kubrick's and Ken Russell's favourite actors has the lead role in a fascinating new play that moves from the Colleges of Cambridge to Heaven itself.

story:
How much does it cost to put up a show at the Hollywood Fringe Festival?:
Venue: $750- COST COVERED!!
Stage Manager: $375
Registration Fee: $170
Insurance: $125
Misc (Marketing/Props/Costumes/etc): $100

Total Cost: $1,520

Hi, I'm Brittany Kay Taylor. 
I'm here with my good friend Alyssa Yyonne Saenz. 

We’re producing a One-Woman-Musical-Comedy entitled 'Molly Goes To Middle School' for the 2018 Hollywood Fringe Festival. We'll be performing at the Hobgoblin Playhouse in Hollywood through out the month of June. It's written by and starring me, Brittany Taylor, in  the title role of Molly… and all the other supporting characters. Alyssa Yvonne Saenz will be doing all the “work” like “directing” and other less visible, less glamorous things that require “skill” and “organization."

Molly Goes To Middle School is the story of a mid-pubescent tween (played by a 28 year old woman) who is nervous about her first day at a brand new school. In need of courage, Molly prays that God would send an angel to guide her. To her surprise, God sends her Beyoncé. In this -One-Woman-Musical-Comedy-, empowered by the musical styling and feminine prowess of the Queen B, Molly bravely sets out navigate her new jungle gym world.

It’s full of fun, adventure, dancing, singing, drama, bullies, hormones, hygiene, good grades, and artistic interpretations on the nature of God. 

You can reserve your tickets NOW! HERE!: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/5434

One of the great things about producing a -One-Woman-Musical-Comedy-, is that they are cost efficient! We already have costumes, props, the script, the music, my human body and comedic talents, as well as Alyssa’s ‘whatever-she-does!’

But we still need to pay for a venue, marketing stuff, …we want to pay this cool chorographer guy, other unexpected expenses that pop up… Alyssa knows, she did the budgeting. 
 

We’re hoping to raise just $1,500. We have some RAD incentives!

$25 gift…. A personalized video from Molly! Perfect for you, or someone you love. 

$100 gift… A handmade friendship bracelet from Molly! Perfect for you, or someone you love.

$200 gift… A Middle School Survival Kit! Includes travel size deodorant, panty liners, and a mix tape of Beyoncé’s greatest hits. Perfect for you, or someone you love.

$300 gift… One of the shows will be dedicated to YOU! (That’s because if you do basic math and division, $300 covers the cost of one whole evening.) Perfect for YOU!

$1,500 gift… Molly will babysit for you! (flight not included.)
 

Thanks so much for your continued support. 

Best,
Brittany Kay Taylor and Alyssa Yvonne Saenz

PS: Reserve your tickets HERE! http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/5434

story:
Cheryl Him Wan Kee

 

  • Hi, my name is Cheryl, 21 years old this year and had just graduated with a Diploma in Dance from Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts in 2017. I have been dancing since Primary School in Co-Curricular Activities and always have the passion which became something I wanted to do as a long span of time as my career.
  • I am very fortunate to be offered a place on the BA (Hons) Dance (Contemporary) at Northern School of Contemporary Dance, However, the school fees, accommodation and other expenses are very costly and I could not afford to provide the amount of money required in the short period of time given. I would not want to miss this chance in pursuing my studies as this would be a great stepping stone that aid me in my career. This allows me to further upgrade myself, gaining all the necessary knowledge to be able to educate the younger generation in the future. 
  • I always wanted to be a dance educator, educating the younger generation in the future, your kind contribution would greatly help me in advancing my path, allowing me to be a better educated educator in educating the younger ones in the future. 

 

What help i needed

  •  I hope to be able to raised an amount of $25000 USD. This amount of funds consist only one year of my school fees. The duration of my studies would be three years. The fund raised will be used for the first year of my school fee. 
  • Even if I couldn't reach the entire goal, whatever amount raised are still a greatly help to me in paying for my school fees. I am working hard and finding ways to earn as much as I could but it is the short given time which is stressful for me.
  • I hope you could help me share this campaign too! Any help provided is greatly appreciated. Thank you very much for your kind support!

Hi, my name is Cheryl, 21 years old this year and had just graduated with a Diploma in Dance from Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts in 2017. I have been dancing since Primary School in Co-Curricular Activities and always have the passion which became something I wanted to do as a long span of time as my career.
I am very fortunate to be offered a place on the BA (Hons) Dance (Contemporary) at Northern School of Contemporary Dance, However, the school fees, accommodation and other expenses are very costly and I could not afford to provide the amount of money required in the short period of time given. I would not want to miss this chance in pursuing my studies as this would be a great stepping stone that aid me in my career. This allows me to further upgrade myself, gaining all the necessary knowledge to be able to educate the younger generation in the future. 
I always wanted to be a dance educator, educating the younger generation in the future, your kind contribution would greatly help me in advancing my path, allowing me to be a better educated educator in educating the younger ones in the future. 

 

What help i needed

 I hope to be able to raised an amount of $25000 USD. This amount of funds consist only one year of my school fees. The duration of my studies would be three years. The fund raised will be used for the first year of my school fee. 
Even if I couldn't reach the entire goal, whatever amount raised are still a greatly help to me in paying for my school fees. I am working hard and finding ways to earn as much as I could but it is the short given time which is stressful for me.

I hope you could help me share this campaign too! Any help provided is greatly appreciated. Thank you very much for your kind support!

story:
Hi there! I'm Eliyahu Kheel, producer of Island Song and creator of All Things Broadway! 

In 2014, I created All Things Broadway as a place where Broadway stars and fans alike can share their love for theatre in a safe and loving place! In the last three and a half years, this FB group has grown more than I could've ever imagined. With nearly 60,000 members worldwide including eight Tony Award winners! 

In January, we hit the 54 Below stage with several Broadway stars from the group as well as our amateur performers who will soon be Broadway stars for a huge hit show! (Which can be seen on our YouTube channel). On April 3rd, we continued with another cabaret at the Laurie Beechman Theatre! (Videos coming soon).

Now, we have rights to perform Carner and Gregor's musical Island Song at the Davenport Theatre Loft on West 45th St.! We want to make this production the best that it can be. And that's expensive. To hire the best musicians, the best props, the best lighting, to pay for the theater space, the rights, the rehearsal spaces, publicity, programs, all this really adds up. And we can't do this without your help to bring this dream to life!

story:
About Black Garden

Inspired by real historical events in Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan, where over 30,000 soldiers were killed between 1988-1994, Black Garden is a theatrical collage that portrays the harrowing landscape of an Armenian woman’s trauma. She is haunted by the memories of a lost lover, while two glutinous buffoons and self-serving leaders contrive to abuse their countries for their own personal power, a man is imprisoned and interrogated for unknown crimes, and a handful of diaspora Armenians are looking for love and their identities.

A piece in development

Set against an ongoing geopolitical conflict, Black Garden is always evolving to embrace the current political narrative. Since 2017, the piece has seen several iterations, and has currently landed into the form of a two-hander (needing only two actors), geared for touring. One of the most exciting aspects of this process is the active collaboration between the playwright, director, actors and design team to create, discover and flesh out the truest form of this play. And you get to join us on this adventure.

About the artistic team

Arthur Makaryan is an emerging NYC-based Armenian theatre and opera director, and recent graduate of the Columbia Graduate School of the Arts and Juilliard Opera Directing Fellowship. He has worked all over the world, under the tutelage of Ann Bogart, Stephen Wadsworth and Tadashi Suzuki, among others.

Gordon Penn is an American playwright who met Arthur Makaryan at Columbia. Also a recent graduate of the CU School of the Arts, Gordon’s experience within the American military and his newfound closeness with the Armenian artistic community have given him an extraordinary and original in to the topic.

Featuring: Tamara Sevunts, Robert Najarian, dramaturged by Elizagrace Madrone, set and lighting design by Kelvin Pater, costume design by Nina Vartanian, sound design/music by Jacob Sachs-Mishalanie 

The impact

Theatre has the ability to ask questions and expand on issues in ways often unexplored in the media. Black Garden hopes to start a conversation on an ongoing socio-political conflict that has consumed its warring parties, but gone almost completely undiscussed in the international arena.

The Théâtre de l’Opprimé is the perfect venue for Black Garden as both the theatre and the project deal with current issues. We are delighted to be part of a program that includes emerging companies from the Strasbourg National Theatre, the National Conservatory of Paris, l’ENSATT de Lyon, etc.

About your contribution

Black Garden has been officially selected for the Pleins Feux sur la jeune création festival in Paris at the Théâtre de l’Opprimé (Theatre of the Oppressed), for 7 performances, September 5 - 9, 2018.

Our budget is $10,000 ($9,200 + 5% fee of Indiegogo +3% transaction fee). Your contribution will help with:

  • Building the elements of performance such as costume, set and sound, etc. 
  • Travel expenses for our team: flights to/from Paris, accommodation.
  •  Modest compensation for our team of emerging and established artistic professionals.

THANK YOU!

story:
The Dance Legacy Project

Doris Humphrey at Michigan - Support Women & The Arts

In Collaboration with the University of Michigan Organ Conference and The Baroque Chamber Orchestra

 

The Dance Legacy Project’s inaugural season marks the first time that Doris Humphrey's Air (1928), Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor (1938), and Brandenburg Concerto No. 4 (1958/59) will be presented in a single concert with live music, reflecting the theme of the Conference: Trailblazers: Women's Impact on Organ, Carillon, Harpsichord, and Sacred Music.

 

The Challenge

The University of Michigan has generously supported this performance with almost $20,000 of the $32,000 needed. 

Only an additional $12,000 is needed.

Funds are needed for guest artists to stage the works, to costume thirty-two dancers, to hire a stage manager and crew, to build and transport staging materials, to livestream the concert, and to provide modest promotional and administrative support.

$500 pays for half of the event’s stage manager 

$1000 will cover half of the staging of the works by Trustees of the Doris Humphrey Foundation

$2000 will pay for half of the unique and integral Humphrey costumes

$2500 will pay for the archival recording and broadcasting of the concert

Click on the BACK IT button at the top of the page, next to the video to DONATE any amount of your choosing. 

 

The Project

Humphrey is one of North America’s preeminent pioneers in twentieth-century modern dance and one of the first women to lead her own company of professional dancers. Her love for the music of J.S. Bach is woven through her work. Talented dance students and faculty from the University of Michigan and Eastern Michigan University will perform three seminal dances spanning four decades of Humphrey’s influential career. 

These works are filled with hope, joy, and the harmony of dancing together. Presenting the legacy of Humphrey’s work will provide an historical connection to many of today's master works. In addition, the creative process of staging these works together will provide an impactful and unique creative experience for students, faculty, performers, and audience. The beauty and power of Humphrey’s work will transport, connect, and inspire this community, while sustaining an important dimension of our shared dance heritage.

The dancers have trained in the Humphrey Technique through an experiential learning process. This intensive process will deepen the performers’ understanding and execution of Humphrey’s choreography, bringing her work into direct relation to present-day lives. Setting these works to live music performed on the organ by James Kibbe, Professor of Music and by the University of Michigan’s Baroque Chamber Orchestra will honor the full creative force of Humphrey’s vision.

University of Michigan Dance faculty Jillian Hopper and Christian Matijas-Mecca are producing the works. Staging will be by Gail Corbin, Dr. Lesley Main, and Jillian Hopper.  Rehearsals are underway and preview performances have galvanized audiences.
story_txt: The Dance Legacy ProjectDoris Humphrey at Michigan - Support Women & The ArtsIn Collaboration with the University of Michigan Organ Conference and The Baroque Chamber Orchestra The Dance Legacy Project’s inaugural season marks the first time that Doris Humphrey's Air (1928), Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor (1938), and Brandenburg Concerto No. 4 (1958/59) will be presented in a single concert with live music, reflecting the theme of the Conference: Trailblazers: Women's Impact on Organ, Carillon, Harpsichord, and Sacred Music. The ChallengeThe University of Michigan has generously supported this performance with almost $20,000 of the $32,000 needed. Only an additional $12,000 is needed.Funds are needed for guest artists to stage the works, to costume thirty-two dancers, to hire a stage manager and crew, to build and transport staging materials, to livestream the concert, and to provide modest promotional and administrative support.$500 pays for half of the event’s stage manager $1000 will cover half of the staging of the works by Trustees of the Doris Humphrey Foundation$2000 will pay for half of the unique and integral Humphrey costumes$2500 will pay for the archival recording and broadcasting of the concertClick on the BACK IT button at the top of the page, next to the video to DONATE any amount of your choosing.  The ProjectHumphrey is one of North America’s preeminent pioneers in twentieth-century modern dance and one of the first women to lead her own company of professional dancers. Her love for the music of J.S. Bach is woven through her work. Talented dance students and faculty from the University of Michigan and Eastern Michigan University will perform three seminal dances spanning four decades of Humphrey’s influential career. These works are filled with hope, joy, and the harmony of dancing together. Presenting the legacy of Humphrey’s work will provide an historical connection to many of today's master works. In addition, the creative process of staging these works together will provide an impactful and unique creative experience for students, faculty, performers, and audience. The beauty and power of Humphrey’s work will transport, connect, and inspire this community, while sustaining an important dimension of our shared dance heritage.The dancers have trained in the Humphrey Technique through an experiential learning process. This intensive process will deepen the performers’ understanding and execution of Humphrey’s choreography, bringing her work into direct relation to present-day lives. story:
(Poster design by Gráinne Barry Wallace)

This is Real, This is Me

Slingshot Theater Co. was co-founded in 2017 by Steven Russo, Kari Buckley, Andrea Louise Soule, and Tyler Christie.  Aimed at cultivating a laboratory where brazen, unexpected, and fearless theater can take place, Slingshot is dedicated to engaging our audiences with fresh and simply entertaining contemporary stories!

An Evocative New Autobiographical Play

Tamra has been workshopped over the past several months with playwright Doug Kmiotek and Slingshot.  After finding our eventual venue at The PIT, we eagerly began putting together our production timeline.  This Indiegogo campaign is part-and-parcel with Slingshot's desire to strengthen our theater community, and naturally, fund our inaugural full-length production!

Where's ya money going?

  • Rehearsal studios!
  • The Set!
  • Costumes!
  • Props!
  • Videography!
  • Photography!
  • Printing & Marketing Materials!
  • Designers!
  • Cast!
  • Crew!

A little bit more...

The Playwright’s Loft, Slingshot’s signature 10-minute play festival has been such a success over the past year.  We would not be here without all of your support, and we owe it to our audience to keep moving you, making you laugh, and hopefully, making you think.  Thrilled doesn't even begin to describe how excited we are to finally be bringing you our first full-length play.

Where can I buy tickets?

Head to www.thepit-nyc.com/events/tamra to snag a ticket!

*Slingshot Theater Company is fiscally sponsored by Unique, which means your donations are tax deductible!

story:
Homegrown Art...5 Years Later

What began as a simple "What if" has united artists across the US, México, and Middle East.

Here's what The Theorists have done so far:

  • Produced 55+ residencies for world-class artists
  • Given $21K+ in scholarships
  • Commissioned 13 original works
  • Toured 18 cities

We've done a lot with a little and can make $5.5k go a long way!

The Theorists spark numerous multi-cultural and multi-disciplinary conversations locally, nationally, and internationally about our role as artist citizens. 

Ultimately, this campaign takes the basic act of buying a ticket and ask "how is this important, accessible AND how can we cover costs together? Let's stimulate conversations that connect us deeper to ourselves, each other, and our environment. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The festival will run for four days, October 18-21, 2018
  • 50 artists from five countries in one Festival-- All 100% free to attend!
  • Live Music, Dance, Installations, Film Screenings & Professional Workshops
  • Theorist Hub for chai & chit chats with artists

What does my donation actually do?

Your donation is the backbone of Theorist Fest. Matched dollar for dollar, you bring it to life! Your help matters. Consider this:

We have five weeks to raise at least $5,555.

100% of the funds from this campaign support artists.

Your donation gets you phenomenal perks: custom designed & locally printed SWAG, backstage, VIP pass & The Experimentalists Membership!

Risks & Challenges

Here's the breakdown:

  • $3k artist fees
  • $1.2k theater rental
  • $1.3k lighting/sound/production fees

All this is matched dollar for dollar with the rest of our budget for accommodation, staff, and marketing to make this really happen! Thanks for meeting us at $5,555 in the middle! 

Beyond the Campaign

There are lots of ways you can help beyond the Benjamins. Here are a few simple and impactful ways:

Volunteer (email theorists@amarts.org).

Spread the word to friends and family with a personal invite.

Attend - we do need money, but your presence is the greatest gift!

story:
Summary

Water House Collective is mounting an evening of queer fantasy shorts performed in varied and experimental styles. The production is titled, "A Minute Flowering" and is set to premiere in June 2019.

As an emerging theater company, we are building our pool of resources from the ground up. In spite of this, we believe that paying artists for their work is imperative, and therefore have the intention of paying our each of our performers and collaborators a small stipend for their work. To cover that cost as well as the cost of rehearsal space and design elements for the production, we are humbly asking for your support.

The funds raised will all go directly towards materializing this queer, mythological evening of theater. 

WE CAN'T DO IT WITHOUT YOUR SUPPORT!

From paying for rehearsal space to paying our performers, here's how it breaks down:

$1000 ($100 per person)
8 actors
1 stage manager
1 hair, makeup, and costume designer

$300 - rehearsal space

$100 - costume materials

$100 - set
________________

Fundraising Goal: $1500


_____________________________________________________________

Rewards:

$5 - 1 digital art piece, emailed to you

$10 - 1 piece of hand-made flora jewelry

$20 - Personal thank you post 

$50 - Super secret workshop footage & outtakes emailed to you

$100 - A short song written just for you!

$200 - Be a named investor in our program & on our website, and get a song written just for you!

_____________________________________________________________


Water House Collective is committed to building mythologies for the Queer community through daring methodologies in storytelling, performance, and design. 

We make theater that is lyrical, magical, physical, and immediate. 

We aim to share our own radical Queer stories and amplify those of our collaborators; we believe that the best personal and performance practices are those which reflect, and on reflecting, change.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute, doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Share our campaign on social media, you never know who will want to get involved
  • Follow our instagram, @waterhousecollective for raffles, updates, opportunities to get involved, and even rewards for just sharing!

story:
Why Head Trick?

Head Trick Theatre is a performing group based in Providence, RI that puts on innovative productions of classic plays with a focus on the importance of liveness. But doing older work doesn't mean shying away from contemporary issues. Last season, we brought our audiences plays by female and minority playwrights that, centuries later, still speak to contemporary feminist, LGBT, and minority issues, because "we've always been here"; the female authors of 2018-19's "Making a World" offer perspectives on complacency and resistance in the face of rising fascism, and on women's memories, bravery, and imaginations, that ring as true today as ever.

Where Your Contribution Will Go

  • Performance rights. Unlike most of our previous plays, Watch on the Rhine and the musical of Goblin Market are still in copyright and are not free to perform.
  • Set, costumes, and props. We're all about transforming a black box theatre into a haunted glen or a comfortable Washington living room with the power of imagination, but money helps too!
  • Paying performers and staff. Everyone on the Head Trick team is doing this for love, not a paycheck, but it's important to us that artists receive some consideration for the enormous amount of time they put into bringing you these plays.
  • Publicity. Web and print advertising to make sure that audiences who want to see the shows know they're happening.
  • Your donations keep us going!

The Plays

¤ Watch on the Rhine

by Lillian Hellman

“It’s an indulgence to sit in a room and discuss your beliefs as if they were a juicy piece of gossip.”

¤ From the Farrellys’ living room in Washington, the Nazis and the war in Europe seem very far away – until the war comes to them, when Sara Farrelly brings her anti-fascist husband home after twenty years abroad. Watch on the Rhine confronts an American family with the struggle between fascists and freedom fighters in their own home: Lillian Hellman strips away the civility and intrigue of a comedy to reveal the violence and immediacy of a political thriller, showing us the impossibility of shutting our eyes to the crisis around us.

OCTOBER 12–21, 2018

¤ Goblin Market

by Polly Pen and Peggy Harmon
music by Polly Pen
adapted from the poem by Christina Rossetti

“At twilight, halted by the brook,
For the first time in my life I began to listen and look…”

¤ Two adult sisters return to their childhood home, where they once again come face to face with the perils and fantasies of their youth. In Polly Pen and Peggy Harmon’s haunting chamber musical, adapted from Christina Rossetti’s poem, Laura and Lizzie are tempted to risk their lives, their bond, and the Victorian world they know for the mysterious offerings of the goblin market. Rich in symbolism and sensuality, Goblin Market explores the power of love and the purpose of imagination.

MARCH 29–APRIL 7, 2019

What People Are Saying About Head Trick Theatre

  • “The greatest art has the ability to hold up a mirror to show us our flawed humanity. This was never more apparent than in Head Trick Theatre’s outstanding production of Shalom Asch’s God of Vengeance. A powerhouse cast…With this fascinating group of actors, the show left you wanting to see what they will do next.” — Edge Media Network
  • “Invested by an innovative director and uniformly excellent cast with surprisingly modern relevance…Head Trick breathes genuine life into Gabriel, a work that was way ahead of its time in understanding the subtleties of what makes men men and makes women women – if anything at all does.” — Motif Magazine
  • “Cleverly blocked and choreographed...sings out its truths without a hint of being dated…crisp attention to roles, and sharp delivery of lines from this versatile cast, made it fun to be around.” — Providence Journal [on The Cradle Will Rock]
  • "This by far was the best play I saw this year and why theater companies like yours need to exist...I wish you continued and growing success." — e-mail from an audience member
  • Find more reviews on our website!

Learn More

  • Follow us on Facebook for show and audition announcements, peeks at rehearsal, interesting links, and more!
  • Visit our website for information and photos of our past productions, and details about upcoming ones!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Alexander Diaz, choreographer and dancer from the Bronx. Charlotte Keefe, dancer and artistic collaborator from the Bay Area. This campaign is not about us. This campaign is about a group of humans who are homeless or formerly homeless; humans we will have the privilege to work with.

Our journey began in 2015 with our first piece, Humanity - a research piece based on conversations between ourselves and a few homeless people in Civic Center, SF. Based on those conversations, we understood a striking need among the homeless community to simply be acknowledged, to be talked to, to be respected. Being walked by and ignored for the majority of the day destroys a person’s self-worth and self-respect, as Alex and I were repeatedly told by those who experienced this. Often we spoke to people who just wanted to have a conversation with someone willing to listen. Alex and I transitioned from a piece based on these conversations to a piece exploring what we must change in ourselves in order to shift our view and interactions with the homeless community. This piece, Human, we performed at the Black Choreographers Festival last February and March in San Francisco and Oakland.

Our next project, HUMAN, involves creating an environment through workshops and performances where homeless and low-income residents of San Francisco feel heard, seen, and understood. We are volunteering in partnership with Grace Cathedral and Episcopal Community Services of San Francisco to ensure the support and personnel we need to succeed in this project. The funds we raise will cover the following costs. in order of priority:

  • Rehearsal and performance stipends for participating performers and artists
  • Aid in transportation to rehearsal locations
  • Water, food, and necessary supplies for rehearsals
  • Publicity

Four years ago the need to for us to engage the homeless community was huge, now it is even larger. We believe our project is a part of our civic duty to support the under-served and ostracized in our community. Our artistic goal is to share our expertise in communication, listening, and understanding beyond what is seen or has become the norm. It is an illusion that we take care of ourselves, and we humans may be more willing to help people we know. Please come be willing with us.

Performance Dates and Location:

June 7, 8, 21, and 22nd at 7:30pm; Grace Cathedral, 1100 California St, San Francisco, CA 94108

Tickets: $10- $25, sliding scale.

Grace Cathedral: https://gracecathedral.org/

Episcopal Community Services of San Francisco: https://ecs-sf.org/
