story:
One Two One Two

One Two One Two is the live performance company led by Zoe Ní Riordáin and Maud Lee. Together, have been making bold, heartfelt and ambitious work for theatre and music audiences in Ireland and beyond since 2014.  

Everything I Do

EVERYTHING I DO is the latest show by ONE TWO ONE TWO- Zoe Ní Riordáin & Maud Lee. It premiered at Dublin Fringe Festival 2018 in a sold out run at Project Arts Centre. It won the 'Best Performer' award (Zoe Ní Riordáin) at Dublin Fringe Awards. 

EVERYTHING I DO is an hour long music theatre show about love, loss and connection.

“I want to help, I want to help you, everything I do is for you, everything I do is for you.”

Accompanied by her guitar, a hysterical pop singer riffs on love in a lonely universe. She’s attempting heartfelt communication with a room full of strangers. It’s a live action album of original pop songs from Zoe Ní Riordáin, powered by a need to express the inexpressible.

Anyone fresh from a bad breakup will recognise the sensations, oscillating between anguish and repudiation.

- ****  Peter Crawley, Irish Times 

Mesmerising gig theatre

-Chris McCormack, Musings in Intermissions

The show is very personal and it has been an amazing experience sharing it with audiences so far. We have been given the opportunity to tour the show to Summerhall, one of the city's best venues, for the month of August. The Edinburgh Fringe is one of the best platforms in Europe to showcase work. 

We have support from Culture Ireland and we are crowdfunding to make up the deficit in our budget to help pay the team and cover some technical costs for the month. 

We are supported by Project Arts Centre, as one of their Resident Artists. 

This is what your funding will contribute towards: 

Technical/Sound/Lighting equipment costs/fees

Materials for the set build.

Costume costs

Fringe Registration costs

Graphic design/print/promotional costs

Crew costs in the venue

We are very proud of this award winning show and we look forward to introducing it to new audiences in August. 

Thank you, we are very grateful that you took the time to read this!

One Two One Two xxx
story_txt:
One Two One Two
One Two One Two is the live performance company led by Zoe Ní Riordáin and Maud Lee. Together, have been making bold, heartfelt and ambitious work for theatre and music audiences in Ireland and beyond since 2014.  
Everything I Do
EVERYTHING I DO is the latest show by ONE TWO ONE TWO- Zoe Ní Riordáin & Maud Lee. It premiered at Dublin Fringe Festival 2018 in a sold out run at Project Arts Centre. It won the 'Best Performer' award (Zoe Ní Riordáin) at Dublin Fringe Awards. 
EVERYTHING I DO is an hour long music theatre show about love, loss and connection.
“I want to help, I want to help you, everything I do is for you, everything I do is for you.”
Accompanied by her guitar, a hysterical pop singer riffs on love in a lonely universe. She’s attempting heartfelt communication with a room full of strangers. It’s a live action album of original pop songs from Zoe Ní Riordáin, powered by a need to express the inexpressible.
Anyone fresh from a bad breakup will recognise the sensations, oscillating between anguish and repudiation.
- ****  Peter Crawley, Irish Times 
Mesmerising gig theatre
-Chris McCormack, Musings in Intermissions

The show is very personal and it has been an amazing experience sharing it with audiences so far. We have been given the opportunity to tour the show to Summerhall, one of the city's best venues, for the month of August. The Edinburgh Fringe is one of the best platforms in Europe to showcase work. 
We have support from Culture Ireland and we are crowdfunding to make up the deficit in our budget to help pay the team and cover some technical costs for the month. 
We are supported by Project Arts Centre, as one of their Resident Artists. 

This is what your funding will contribute towards: 
Technical/Sound/Lighting equipment costs/fees
Materials for the set build.
Costume costs
Fringe Registration costs
Graphic design/print/promotional costs
Crew costs in the venue
We are very proud of this award winning show and we look forward to introducing it to new audiences in August.

story:
Short Summary


"What's In Front of You," seven short plays written and directed by Joseph Walsh, is a cast of characters and situations that range from the comic and absurd to the tender and human.  Written and Directed by Joseph Walsh.  What's In Front of You debuted in December at the Broadwater Theater, and was enthusiastically received with two sold out shows.  With this campaign we are working to fund a longer run of 6 nights at the end of September for those who weren't able to catch it the first time and those hungry to see it again!

What's In Front of You is Joseph's first work for theater.  His other credits include writing and directing the feature film, "Girl Missing," with Patrick McCartney, Adam McKay, Kate Walsh and Amy Poehler and co-Writing and co-directing the award-winning short film, "Model Trapper."  He is currently developing a new feature film set in Ireland in conjunction with the Irish Film Board; as well as working on a new full-length play.  Mr. Walsh is also and actor and artist. 

What We Need & What You Get
Impact

Like most independent productions, What's in Front of You is self-financed and produced.  To fund all planned performances, our goal is to raise $10,000.00 by July 1st.

The funds raised will go toward theater rental costs, rehearsal space, fees for technical support and Stage Manager(s), expenses incurred by our Production Team and the care and feeding of our performers throughout the run.

For this we need YOU!  People who care about theater, new theater, funny theater, weird theater, experimental theater, independent theater; who care about laughter, tears, awe, language, character, surprise, refinement, offense!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help monetarily, no problem; we only ask that you share this on your social media: share, tweet, like, forward, instagram, hashtag--whatever!  All those things help too!  Lots!

story:
Our Story

Our names are Richie, Brittany, Claire, Gab, Fate, Ben, and Rachel, and we are The Whisper Theatre Collective, an ensemble-devised theatre company. That means we rely on creative collaboration to produce original and exciting work, and we empower each ensemble member to have an artistic voice in all areas of the production. Our strength lies within each other. We share and utilize our combined skills of physical theatre, dance, circus, improvisation, performance art, music, design, and technical theater. Our audience is also a crucial part of our process, as their feedback helps us develop our work in directions we can’t do in a room by ourselves.

Although this is the launch of our company, our collaboration is already two years strong. We began our journey together when we started an MFA in European Devised Performance Practice at Columbia College Chicago, the first year taking place at Arthaus Berlin (formerly LISPA) and the second year being in Chicago. We studied in Berlin with 33 students from 15 different countries, and through them we learned to make theatre that is more embodied, dynamic, and accessible to the world. We have worked with Familie Flöez, Artists of the MCA, and with Thom Pasculli of Walkabout Theatre. The Whisper Theatre Collective strives to continue making this work. We want to invite our audiences to peer into the dark underbelly of the human experience and engage with the unknown.

Some of the members of the ensemble are also a part of other amazing companies and events!
We have amongst us founding members of The West, a multi-media storytelling collective based in Chicago and Berlin, and Heels Over Head, a physical performance variety show based in Chicago. We also have members who have toured with Aura Curiatlas, Theater Unspeakable; and members who have performed with About Face Theatre, Canterbury Summer Theatre, The Fly Honey Show, Desert Rose Playhouse, and more!

Performing internationally is essential to us because we value connecting with other cultures and artistic disciplines, and we have experienced firsthand the effects of that artistically and personally. Your contributions to our cause will help us share our work with a huge international audience at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. That will give us invaluable connections, feedback on our work, and possibly provide international touring opportunities.

Our end goal for this opportunity is to legitimize our company, so in the future we can apply for grants (and we won't have to keep crowdfunding). We are currently taking steps to securing a space in Chicago when we return, as well as building a season with our existing and new works!

Here’s a rundown of the shows we plan to take:

Wild Women
Written and Directed by: Brittany Price Anderson
Co-created and Performed by: Claire Kaplan, Gabrielle Wilson, and Fate Richey
Runtime: 45 minutes
Synopsis: Three goddesses are summoned to Earth through an ancient ritual; instead, the heavens send the women your mother hoped you would never become. These grotesque creatures go on a hilarious, offensive journey of feminine storytelling (from Eve to Cinderella) to discover what has happened to the Wild Woman.

Oneironauts
Directed by: Richie Schiraldi
Co-created and Performed by: Ben Heustess, Gabrielle Wilson, Fate Richey, Brittany Price Anderson, and Richie Schiraldi
Runtime: 45 minutes
Synopsis: We drift off to sleep. We slip away from reality into the illogical dream-state, where time begins to melt around us. Only here can we encounter the moments, memories, and shadows our subconscious has tucked away. We submerge the audience into our world of visual poetry and post-modern dance and dare them to engage the unknown.
 

The Budget

Here’s a budget break down, because deep down everyone loves to know where there money is going.

****But first, some GREAT NEWS: We have secured a venue, and we have a place to stay (and they provide breakfast)! Now, we just need to get there.

  • Travel: $3600
    • $550 Roundtrip to London x 5 = $2750
    • $100 Flight from Berlin to Edinburgh x 2 = $200
    • $130 Train to Edinburgh x 5 = $650

**How did we get these numbers?: We have 7 people in our ensemble, but two of us will already be in an artist residency in Berlin. That means we only need to fund 5 flights from the USA.
It’s also appears to be cheaper to fly from Chicago to London and take a train to Edinburgh than it is to fly from the USA to Edinburgh.

  • Marketing: $115 for a Festival marketing package of posters and flyers
     
  • Venue Rental: $1200 for 3 days at the awesome SUMMERHALL venue. This is where we were invited, and it’s where all the cool physical and experimental theater is done. Check it out! https://www.summerhall.co.uk/
     
  • Registration fee: $325 This makes us legit, and we can’t perform there without this.
     
  • Public Transit: $350
    • $25 weekly pass, 2 weeks ($50) x 7 people = $350
      This is the cheapest and most efficient way for us to get around.
  • Food: $410
    Breakfast is provided at the place where we are staying, and you bet we will be stuffing our pockets with bananas and muffins. The rest of this money will help us cover some groceries to cook some family meals throughout our two week stay.

What happens if we don’t reach our budget?

Every little bit helps! If we aren’t able to raise the full amount, the first thing that needs to be paid is the venue. Then, we will allocate some money to each performer to help pay for travel and transit. What suffers first is our food budget. Muffins and biscuits will only last so long…


The Significance

Edinburgh is just the beginning. Our work has already gone through one Works-In-Progress showing back in March, and we will have a preview performance at Columbia College Chicago’s The Third Mask, a festival for new devised performance. Then in mid-June we will have a soft-opening in Chicago to gear up for Edinburgh. In the beginning of August, we make our international premier at the Fringe, and then we plan to bring the shows to Chicago for local touring. This process serves as a professional launch for our company The Whisper Theater Collective, but our ensemble and work is already two years strong. With your help, we will hit the ground running.
 

The Risk

There’s always a lot at stake when pursuing international goals. It’s inevitable that we will run into some bumps, some bruises, and some failures. That’s how we learn, and this is the ultimate learning experience. We have each other and our community to help us get back up and charge forward.
There’s also a risk in introducing ourselves as a new company in Chicago - that we will be written off as just another startup, one of the many that begin and end within the year. However, we have already taken steps as individuals and as a group to open doors and make deeply rooted connections in the Chicago physical theater scene. We have been part of round-table discussions on national and international touring for local companies in Chicago at Chicago Shakespeare Theater, and have a vast network of combined resources across the nation, as our members come from all over the USA. We are here to support each other, but we have no intention of being insular. We are pumped to dive into the Chicago arts community to share with and learn from the incredible artists in our city. Collaboration is what we thrive on.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every contribution takes us closer to our dreams. We understand if you really wish you could help, but just can’t afford it right now. You can still help! Share our story and help us make some noise. You have our full gratitude. We hope to see you at one of our shows!

story:
About Us.

Arion Productions and Rigmarole Productions are passionate about new writing, with a proven track record of bringing high-quality productions with exceptional casts and production teams. We believe Dark Sublime is a truly beautiful play and our leading lady, Marina Sirtis is so impressed by it, that she will be travelling from her home in LA to perform the leading role in London's West End. 

Why we need your help.

Finding funding for brand new pieces of theatre is hard. We decided to create this campaign as a way to give some incredible perks to those who want to see this out-of-this-world production and by doing so, you will be helping support the show and in return, we want to give you some once in a life-time experiences and exclusive rewards as a supporter of Dark Sublime.

What happens if we don't reach our funding goal?

We are raising investment and the production will go ahead regardless of our fundraising goal. However, this is a way for us to produce a piece that is only limited by our imagination rather than our financial constraints. In short, the more we raise, the more we can do.

Spread the word.

Please do spread the word. We have a Twitter and Instagram account @DarkSublimePlay and we can't wait to welcome you to Dark Sublime at Trafalgar Studios and we hope you take advantage of these extra special support initiatives. 

Please note this is the second campaign we've run for Dark Sublime on IndieGoGo and we are trying to reach our overall goal of £10K to make the production as truly out of this world as can be. Thank you to everyone who gave to our first campaign and we hope you enjoy your perks :)

story:
Hello!! Welcome to The Creative Artist Workshop page. Our workshop is made up of amazing artists who are actors, singers, writers and dancers. They go by the names  Lauren Coccaro, Dylan Bivings, Mariah Elle Kane, Mila, and Javan Zapata. We have merged our original group and added two new members as the second official group of  The Creative Artist Workshop. A series of workshops created by MTEAF’s and Triple Threat Theatre's very own industry professionals, Maria Torres and Dee Kanevsky are unifying artists to nurture their artistic talent. A world-renowned director-choreographer, who worked with award-winning playwrights, actors, singers, Film, TV, Theatre, Music, you name it. Maria Torres has helped them bring their projects into the professional purview when they started at the ground floor. Some of which started in her own personal MTEAF workshop series. Together with Triple Threat Theatre and Maria Torres's MTEAF, they are collaborating to bring a hands-on, educational experience to the artist of today.

Our mission is to take any artist and teach them how to turn an idea into a reality. Part of our learning in this workshop is learning how to produce. This is a skill that many young artists are lacking today, when it comes to creating their original work.  Dee and Maria’s vision for The Creative Artist Workshop is to provide equal prospects to artists who don’t have the advantage or opportunity to produce their own work.

Creative work has been shoved to the back burner, and has been labeled “non-essential.” Which makes it almost impossible for new artists to showcase their work. But that’s why the Creative Artist Workshop is so important now more than ever! Given time, unique social distancing based staging, choreography,  filming, and the proper resources, we can reach our goal. Which is to show the world how essential art is though the art we create in this moment.  Let us make a difference together. Donate and spread the word to everyone you know. Share it across all social media platforms, join our movement! Your contributions will help us, and the many artists who come after, to have an amazing opportunity that artists can’t get anywhere else.

Art Unity Throwdown Sign up below >>>>> Slots are going fast!

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdsqiC...    

To learn more about our program, emerging artists, and the work we are doing, click the link >>>>>>  https://msha.ke/thecaw

story:
Black Sheep Theatre Company: Theatre Done Differently

Hello, I am Caylin Bach, a 20-something theatre nerd. For many years I have dreamed of being in a musical. But the fact is... I'm not your typical-looking performer. I'm a plus-sized person of color with chronic pain. Not many casting directors see me as 'Elle Woods'. The more I thought about my situation, the more I began to think there must be people like me--people who want to be in a production but feel discouraged by who they are. In my mind the wheels began to turn. If I want to see a change, I have to create it myself.

My idea in creating The Black Sheep Theatre Company was to do several things. 

-Create opportunities for actors who are:

  • People of color (POC)
  • Different body shapes
  • LGBTQIA
  • Living with a disability
  • Underrepresented in theatre
  • New to theatre

-Encourage acceptance and raise awareness for minority actors.

-Involve and develop local talent.

-Entertain and tell a meaningful story.

Even though I initially wanted to wait until COVID was gone before producing shows, I decided that, now more than ever, people need something positive to be a part of. I think that now is the time to pursue this dream. Involving members of my community in a positive project that benefits both the actors and the audience can only be good for us all.

What We Need

Money needed for:

  • Production rights- about $1,000
  • Filming/editing/streaming- about $2,500
  • Costumes/make-up- about $2,000
  • Promotion and marketing- about $500

What You Get

Some of our perks include:

  • Black Sheep T-Shirt
  • Signed cast poster
  • A cameo in the show
  • And much more!

Even if the Black Sheep Theatre Company doesn't reach its goal, your money will still help in funding our first production.

The Impact

By continuing to diversity theatre in our community, we:

  • create an ongoing dialogue in our community.
  • allow more people to feel included.
  • inspire more creators to hire different types of actors.
  • see talented people succeed.

If a 5-year-old POC girl sees a person who looks like her on stage, she too can envision herself as an actress. When we give young people the chance to see themselves in others, we give them a window into their possible future.

Risks & Challenges

I know you value transparency. By being open and honest with you about our challenges, I hope to show you how I can handle them. Here's what we are up against.

  • COVID-19

The novel coronavirus has made live theatre difficult, but by no means impossible. My plan to handle this is simple and very effective. We will audition, rehearse, and run through the production on Zoom. We will record the performance with social distancing and with the actors individually. We will use the power of editing to create a fantastic show. At performance time, we will stream the recorded version online. 

  • First Show

At some point, all theatre companies have a first show. Some go better than others, but the advantage of a virtual production is the amount of control the production team has. We can work together to make the debut production go as smoothly as possible; and we can try new things, because virtual productions are new to most companies.

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be able to contribute now, but that doesn't mean you can't help. You can:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Contact me about other resources you may have.
  • Consider telling a friend about our shirts, the profits still go to our production! Buy them at: https://www.bonfire.com/support-black-sheeps-debut-production/

Thank you for your time!

-Caylin Bach
story_txt:
Black Sheep Theatre Company: Theatre Done Differently
Hello, I am Caylin Bach, a 20-something theatre nerd. For many years I have dreamed of being in a musical. But the fact is... I'm not your typical-looking performer. I'm a plus-sized person of color with chronic pain. Not many casting directors see me as 'Elle Woods'. The more I thought about my situation, the more I began to think there must be people like me--people who want to be in a production but feel discouraged by who they are. In my mind the wheels began to turn. If I want to see a change, I have to create it myself.
My idea in creating The Black Sheep Theatre Company was to do several things. 
-Create opportunities for actors who are:

People of color (POC)
Different body shapes
LGBTQIA
Living with a disability
Underrepresented in theatre
New to theatre

-Encourage acceptance and raise awareness for minority actors.
-Involve and develop local talent.
-Entertain and tell a meaningful story.
Even though I initially wanted to wait until COVID was gone before producing shows, I decided that, now more than ever, people need something positive to be a part of. I think that now is the time to pursue this dream. Involving members of my community in a positive project that benefits both the actors and the audience can only be good for us all.
What We Need

Money needed for:

Production rights- about $1,000
Filming/editing/streaming- about $2,500
Costumes/make-up- about $2,000
Promotion and marketing- about $500

What You Get
Some of our perks include:

Black Sheep T-Shirt
Signed cast poster
A cameo in the show
And much more!

Even if the Black Sheep Theatre Company doesn't reach its goal, your money will still help in funding our first production.

The Impact
By continuing to diversity theatre in our community, we:

create an ongoing dialogue in our community.
allow more people to feel included.
inspire more creators to hire different types of actors.
see talented people succeed.

If a 5-year-old POC girl sees a person who looks like her on stage, she too can envision herself as an actress. When we give young people the chance to see themselves in others, we give them a window into their possible future.

Risks & Challenges
I know you value transparency. By being open and honest with you about our challenges, I hope to show you how I can handle them. Here's what we are up against.
COVID-19
The novel coronavirus has made live theatre difficult, but by no means impossible. My plan to handle this is simple and very effective. We will audition, rehearse, and run through the production on Zoom. We will record the performance with social distancing and with the actors individually. We will use the power of editing to create a fantastic show. At performance time, we will stream the recorded version online. 
First Show
At some point, all theatre companies have a first show. Some go better than others, but the advantage of a virtual production is the amount of control the production team has. We can work together to make the debut production go as smoothly as possible; and we can try new things, because virtual productions are new to most companies.

Other Ways You Can Help
You may not be able to contribute now, but that doesn't mean you can't help. You can:

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Contact me about other resources you may have.
Consider telling a friend about our shirts, the profits still go to our production! Buy them at: https://www.bonfire.com/support-black-sheeps-debut-production/


Thank you for your time!
-Caylin Bach

story:
Overview

 They Say a Lady Was the Cause of It  is an evening-length dance production, that embodies the contemporary exploration of agency and identity. The eleven dancers performing in this work will be accompanied by live, original music, composed and performed by Matt LaRocca, along with five additional musicians. Vocals will be performed by Roxanne Vought, and Allison and Cameron Steinmetz. 
Mark your calendars! The performances will take place February 21-22, 2020 at The Main Street Landing Performing Arts Center in Burlington VT, and February 28-29, 2020 at
Town Hall Theater in Middlebury, VT. 
 

The Work

Inspired, in part, by the explorations of gender and gender identity in Orlando, by Virginia Woolf, and Undine Geht (Undine Goes) by Ingeborg Bachmann, They Say A Lady Was the Cause of It  examines the complexities of gender roles imposed by society, as well as the fight to reclaim individual narratives and rewrite what society has prescribed. The eleven dancers performing in this work contribute their own narratives and voices to this important conversation. 

A reflection on gender identity and discrimination, Virginia Woolf's Orlando tells the story of a person who's life spans more than 300 years. Orlando is born male, with the privilege of being a nobleman. After falling into a deep sleep for a number of days, Orlando wakes up female. Lady Orlando must then navigate her role in life as a woman. 

An Undine is a water sprite, like a siren or a mermaid, almost exclusively depicted as female; their stories almost exclusively written by men. Bachmann's Undine Geht is written from the perspective of Undine, herself, and within this context, she examines the difficulties and obstacles of finding her own voice in world made by men for men.

These pieces of literature are part of the extensive research that has gone into this project. We will not tell these stories in work we are creating, but they have informed us and helped us to frame our own narratives within this context. 

They Say A Lady Was The Cause of It explores the themes of identity and agency in two parts. Part 1, The Dinner Party, was originally created as Jessie's thesis work at Smith College in 2015. This piece exists as a framework or a setting, in which much of the content is created by the performers themselves, based on their own real life experiences, and so it changes with each new creation. In keeping with the tradition of Tanztheater, a dance form born out of German Expressionism, this work is an exploration of individual experience and emotion, in which the performers will make use of theatrical methods (set, props, costume), and will intentionally reference reality in the creation process. 

Part 2, The Wet Frontier Between Me and Me, is a raw and physical work, in which the performers contend with themselves as they negotiate their relationships with each other and with the audience. 


What We Believe...Why This Work is Important

As performers, we seek to connect to the essence of our humanity and to find it within each other. With this work, we seek to create ways of knowing, beyond words and information, factual histories and timelines. We seek to conceive of ways of telling our stories within landscapes both visual and aural, to move ourselves and our audiences closer to our individual truths and our shared memories. We seek to convey, in our own felt senses, who we are in our bodies and how we move our bodies through this world.

Driven by authentic exploration and expression, the artists in this work create inherent moments and experiences of connection and meaning among the performers and with the audience. We tell stories, both true and imagined, through the mediums of movement and music. Through imaginative and approachable landscapes, we develop our individual and shared relationships with performance, continuously looking for ways to conceive, create, connect, and convey. Art provides us all, creators, performers, and viewers, with an intimate lens through which we can explore how we locate ourselves in the world. And locate ourselves, we must, because there is so much work to be done.

 

The Collaborators

As a dancer who came to the form later in life than many, creator and choreographer,
Jessie Owens is interested in pushing the parameters and boundaries of dance. She graduated Summa Cum Laude from Smith College in 2015, with a major in Dance and a minor in German when she was 36 years old. The experience of formal training at this stage of her life, combined with her practical knowledge, contextualized her previous dance experience, and helped her to hone a new approach to her work. In 2015, she founded ERGO/movement, a performance project based in Burlington, VT, where she seeks to create works that are accessible to both dancers and audience. 

With ERGO/movement, Jessie has created, produced, and performed site-specific works, an evening-length concert, and multiple improvisational performances and informal showings. She presented work at DanceFest Vermont at Castleton University in 2016, and at the Vermont Dance Alliance Winter Gala in 2018 and 2019. She collaborated with singer/songwriters, Shannon Hawley in 2015, and Emma Back in 2018. In 2015, she presented work at Qrosswalk, a queer and women-centered art and music event, and at Pushing a Brain Uphill -a multimedia showcase in 2016. In 2018, Jessie was hired to choreograph Vermont Stage’s production of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Nighttime. 

From 2002 to 2012, Jessie performed with Burlington’s Spielpalast Cabaret, a non-profit dance and theater company, modeled after German Weimar Era cabarets, and was the group’s art director and co-producer from 2005 until 2013. She co-produced performances annually in Burlington and throughout Vermont, as well as the group’s venture to the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland in 2011.

Jessie is the current Vice President of the Vermont Dance Alliance, a non-profit organization serving as a foundation for dancers and a public platform for dance in Vermont. Find out more about Jessie's work and ERGO/movement at jessieowens.com.

Photo by Michael Heeney 
 

Vocalist, Roxanne Vought has been performing professionally at age eleven and spent her formative years touring with the Vermont-based vocal ensembles, Village Harmony and Northern Harmony. She earned a Bachelor's degree in Vocal Performance from the University of Vermont under David Neiweem, and continued her studies with Beth Thompson and Bill Reed. An experienced soloist, ensemble member, and teacher, she has performed a diverse body of repertoire, including Early American, Eastern European and West African folk music, a wide array of sacred music and choral works from baroque to contemporary, art song, oratorio, opera, musical theater, and jazz. She has been a soloist with Burlington Choral Society, Onion River Chorus, and Vermont Opera Theater, performed art song programs in collaboration with pianists Annemieke Spoelstra and Randal Pierce, served as a soloist and section leader for the First Unitarian Universalist Society of Burlington, and been a member of Counterpoint, Vermont's only professional vocal ensemble. Having a particular passion for opera and theatrical productions, she has been a company member of Spielpalast Cabaret and Green Mountain Opera Festival, and founded Viva La Voce Puppet Opera, for which she directed productions of Carmen, Faust, and Die Fledermaus. In addition to performance, for over 15 years she has taught students of all ages and backgrounds vocal and performance techniques. Currently she is developing a one-woman show exploring popular mid-century wartime songs, her paternal family's involvement in World War II and U.S. intelligence work, and mental health. 

Photo courtesy of Roxanne Vought
 

Matt LaRocca is a composer, conductor and educator based in Burlington, VT. He is on the composition and theory faculty at the University of Vermont, and is the Artistic Director of the Champlain Philharmonic Orchestra. Matt is also the Executive Director of Music-COMP, an organization that teaches composition to students throughout the country and facilitates live performances of their music by professional musicians. Committed to new music and innovation, Matt is the Chair of Creative Projects and Artistic Curator for the Vermont Symphony.

As a composer, Matt’s work has been commissioned by groups such as the Vermont Symphony Orchestra, the Metropolitan Wind Symphony, the New Jersey Youth Symphony and the Great Falls Symphony Orchestra. From 2007-2008 he was the Faculty Composer in Residence for the Montana State University Symphony. Artistic residencies include an expedition to the high arctic through The Arctic Circle organization and composition/improvisation residencies at schools throughout New England and California. He frequently performs as both a violist and a guitarist in classical, rock and improvisation ensembles. Matt holds degrees in chemistry and music from Middlebury College, and a doctorate in music composition from Boston University. Find out about Matt's work at mattlarocca.com.

Photo courtesy of Matt LaRocca


The Challenge

This is a large-scale production, featuring an array of talented artists, performers, and designers. We are committed to paying these artists a fair wage for the work they are doing. Here are many expenses to consider in the creation of a performance, and the stark reality is that there is limited grant funding for independent dance artists in New England to create works on this scale. We are relying on your support to bring this work to life!
Where is the money going?

Your contributions will go directly toward paying the salaries for:
1 Director/Choreographer
1 Assistant Choreographer
11 Dancers
1 Composer
5 Musicians
3 Vocalists
1 Dramaturge
1 Lyric Wordsmith
1 Costume Designer
1 Stylist/Makeup Artist
1 Lighting Technician
1 A/V Technician
1 Stage Manager
1 Videographer

It will also help us pay for:
Rehearsal space
Performance Venue Rental
Props and Set
Costumes
Marketing and Publicity 
 

How You Can Help

We know that this is a huge undertaking. We believe that this work is worth the effort. There are so many ways that you can support us. 

  • Contribute to our campaign in any amount
  • Share this campaign with the people you know via email, text, or social media
  • Follow our progress at jessieowens.com/they-say-a-lady
  • Follow our progress on Facebook and on Instagram at @jojotanzt
  • Share posts on social media
  • Save the dates and attend the performance


If you would like to make a tax-deductible contribution to this project, you can do this by contacting us directly at info@jessieowens.com, and we will guide you through this process. Contributions in the amount of $250 or more are eligible. 

We are grateful to the Vermont Dance Alliance for providing fiscal sponsorship for this project. 

Your support in any form will help to make this production a success. We thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

story:
Who are we? 

Caston & Company, originally founded in New York City, is now laying down roots in Detroit. We are a professional dance company under the Caston-Clark Tap Dance Foundation, a 501(c)3 organization dedicated to the advancement of tap dance through performance, preservation and education. We strive to reach underserved communities that are hungry for more exposure to the performing arts.

Short Summary

Former Radio City Rockette Denise Caston-Clark is ecstatic to be back in her home state of Michigan, launching Tap Dance Detroit for the community and creating work for the talented artists that call Michigan home.

We are infusing tap dance into the vibrant concert dance scene through creating productions that utilize the world-class talent of Detroit's musicians, and presenting shows at well-known venues in Metro Detroit that will bring wider awareness and appreciation to this uniquely American art form.

What We Need & What You Get

We seek $10,000 for our debut season. Here is where those donations will go:

  • Salaries for dancers, musicians and stage technicians. 
  • Budget for costumes, transportation of our floors to performance venues, marketing, PR and the other details that will make our endeavors successful.
  • Your donations will also help us to hire more dancers and travel to other communities to create more access to dance performances and education. 

While the concert dance scene in Michigan is vibrant with a plenitude of dance companies from major troupes to those just getting started, there is an absence of tap dance. We want tap dance to be an integral part of the dance scene here. The mass appeal of tap dance is undeniable. Everyone from connoisseurs to people that have never danced love to watch tap dance.

The Impact

With your help, Michigan too can be a destination to see and experience tap dance in concert. Many productions will travel through, but we are creating a home base right in the heart of Metro Detroit. There will be work for professional tap dancers right here in the mitten, and people will see how tap dance is still thriving and as strong as ever globally! 

Risks & Challenges

I moved back to Michigan after being in New York City for years. We moved back to launch Tap Dance Detroit. Anyone who has started a business knows that it is an enormous undertaking. I didn't really have the money to do it, but I did anyway! I jumped into the very deep end because I simply believe that's the only way to do it. Go in! It's been overwhelming, hugely rewarding, and all the emotions in between.

Many major dance companies have corporate sponsors, and with their years-long track record are able to obtain grants from large funding organizations. We will get there but we aren't there yet! Without donors, we simply can't do it. With my history of building Motor City Tap Fest into one of the largest tap festivals in the country, I know what it takes, the time, the patience and the persistence. I know we can become a world-class tap company that will in turn give back to the community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not in the position to donate dollars? Keep reading! 

You can also donate in the form of costuming, fundraising, grant writing, photography, videography or volunteering in another way.

Contact me and get involved!

story:
Welcome!!

  • Hello everyone! My name is Jacob Taylor and I am a Choreographer based in NYC. I am a graduate of Indiana University’s Ballet Performance program and have been working as a choreographer, teacher, and dancer in NYC for 6 years. 
    This Project is in collaboration with Emily Speed who is a professional freelance dancer in NYC. She has worked with Colorado Ballet, Boulder Ballet, Alabama Ballet, and Tucson Ballet before moving to New York. 
  • This campaign is designed to help fund a dance film that will be exploring the new and exciting ways the body can move in the genre of neoclassical and contemporary ballet.
  • Contributors will help us to produce this product in an exciting, high quality way
  •  
  • What We Need & What You Get

We will be needing 3000  dollars to help fund this project. The funding will go towards paying for studio rehearsal space, compensating  the artists for their time and other costume/production costs 

The perks we offer are a chance to have your name in the credits of the final project, a glimpse into our rehearsals and signed pointe shoes form one of our dancers!

 

The Impact

  • This project is meant to continue the development of neoclassical and contemporary ballet in the New York City  dance community. This project will help to push the art of contemporary ballet forward into the future!
  • I have done other fundraisers before which have been great successs like the project to present my choreography at Morgan Stanley Childrens Hospital. Please help us create another great project!! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that these are difficult times with Covid-19 and the subsequent financial downtown so if you are unable to contribute financially we would greatly appreciate if you could share this campaign with your friends.

My name is Jacob Taylor and I am a Choreographer based in NYC. I am a graduate of Indiana University’s Ballet Performance program and have been working as a choreographer, teacher, and dancer in NYC for 6 years. This Project is in collaboration with Emily Speed who is a professional freelance dancer in NYC. She has worked with Colorado Ballet, Boulder Ballet, Alabama Ballet, and Tucson Ballet before moving to New York. 
This campaign is designed to help fund a dance film that will be exploring the new and exciting ways the body can move in the genre of neoclassical and contemporary ballet.
Contributors will help us to produce this product in an exciting, high quality way
 
What We Need & What You Get


We will be needing 3000  dollars to help fund this project. The funding will go towards paying for studio rehearsal space, compensating  the artists for their time and other costume/production costs 
The perks we offer are a chance to have your name in the credits of the final project, a glimpse into our rehearsals and signed pointe shoes form one of our dancers!
 

The Impact

This project is meant to continue the development of neoclassical and contemporary ballet in the New York City  dance community. This project will help to push the art of contemporary ballet forward into the future!
I have done other fundraisers before which have been great successs like the project to present my choreography at Morgan Stanley Childrens Hospital. Please help us create another great project!! 

 
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that these are difficult times with Covid-19 and the subsequent financial downtown so if you are unable to contribute financially we would greatly appreciate if you could share this campaign with your friends.

story:
Chi siamo?

Siamo Semi Permanenti,  un collettivo internazionale che unisce i diversi codici dello spettacolo dal vivo ricercando un linguaggio originale e trans-disciplinare. Ci siamo incontrati lo scorso anno e dopo aver condiviso una formazione intensiva abbiamo deciso di continuare a lavorare insieme.

Per maggiori informazioni visita la nostra pagina Fb: https://www.facebook.com/Semi-Permanenti-114105... 

Cosa abbiamo fatto e cosa vorremmo realizzare

Abbiamo già svolto una residenza artistica grazie al sostegno di Rete Habitat e Sementerie Artistiche, una bellissima realtà che si trova a Crevalcore (BO).

L'energia scaturita da questa esperienza è ancora attiva e impaziente di continuare a manifestarsi in un periodo in cui tutto il sistema teatro è in pausa.

Questa residenza è per noi una forma di resistenza, una possibilità per continuare a creare con l'obiettivo di presentare il nostro lavoro nel prossimo futuro.

COME PUOI AIUTARCI

Il vostro contributo ci aiuterebbe a sostenere i costi dello spazio in cui lavoreremo e di conseguenza renderebbe possibile questo periodo di lavoro destinato alla creazione del progetto in cui siamo impegnati.

Il nostro obiettivo è di riuscire a raccogliere 1575 euro  con i quali sostenere le spese di alloggio e utilizzo del teatro per 9 persone per una durata di 10 giorni e una parte delle spese di viaggio. 

Se non riuscissimo nell'obiettivo dovremo rimandare il nostro lavoro e ricercare altri partner che sostengano il progetto; in tal caso il budget raccolto costituirebbe una parte della cifra necessaria alla sua realizzazione.

DIFFONDI IL VERBO

Se non puoi partecipare direttamente, potresti aiutarci a diffondere la campagna: condividi questo progetto con i tuoi amici, te ne saremo grati!

Grazie per la tua attenzione, 

Sara C, Sara B, Maria, Jakob, Tamar, Eka, Francesca, Yaara, Davide.

story:
Let’s find wonder in the face of grief!

I am Mieke D, an interdisciplinary dance, theater, and performance-maker based in Philadelphia, PA bringing together an ensemble of artists to produce a new work of site specific theater for our pandemic times. It’s my birthday week, and I want nothing more than to raise $2000 in order to workshop my project, Mortal Meal Services, in November 2021!

 

What is Mortal Meal Services?

Mortal Meal Services is a site specific, promenade-style, scavenger-hunt inspired play that takes audiences of one throughout a local cemetery to find wonder in the face of grief. This whimsical, interactive journey unfolds through rituals, stories, games, puzzles, riddles, songs, and many quiet moments to help audiences contemplate: How can we find joy within landscapes of loss? Connection within chaos? Beginnings within endings?

 

Why now?

This is a time of re-emergence for so many of us, with more opportunities to contemplate what we are returning to, what has changed, and what is possible. In this moment of a little more breath, there is a lot to integrate, to grieve, and to retrieve. This project hopes to offer creators and audiences a playful, supported way of doing some of that reflecting through play and fun, while making room for reimagining what comes next.

 

Who is involved?

Our current ensemble includes a Director, Stage Manager, 3 Creator-Performers and Puppeteer. I am looking to add a props and objects designer and a Disability Justice Consultant as well! 

 

What are we fundraising for?

This funding will allow me to produce some much-needed workshop showings of this interactive outdoor project, before the winter descends again and we have to go back inside! It will allow me to pay my collaborators for their invaluable time devising and performing; hire a production stage manager and prop designer; and increase the accessibility of this piece in as many ways as possible before attempting a full run of this ambitious project in 2022!

We have already received support from the Leeway Foundation (Art & Change Grant), the Network of Ensemble Theaters (NET/TEN), and Illuminate the Arts—the first grants I have ever received for an original project in my life. This generous support will allow us to workshop and develop the project through September, and work towards a full run in 2022, but between that... we’re broke! The dream is real, and the momentum is building, but we need your help to workshop this project with audiences in November!

 

If you are excited about socially distant performance, queer and disabled leadership within a majority-BIPOC team, and values-driven art with a flare for the ridiculous - DONATE NOW!

story:
The ZEN Room, created by ZEN Productions, has been shadowcasting The Rocky Horror Picture Show since October 2011.

For those unfamiliar with the term, a shadowcast is a group of performers who re-enact a film while it plays on a screen behind them. The performers and audience add their own unique twists to what is seen on screen, whether that is achieved by shouting at the screen (callbacks), dancing, throwing items like confetti, or using visual/physical humor. Shadowcasting is a popular tradition with several cult films, the most notable film being the Rocky Horror Picture Show.   

In addition to our regular schedule of shows performed in Nassau and Suffolk counties on Long Island, ZEN has performed at a number of regional conventions such as I-CON, Wicked Faire, Lunacon, the Macabre Faire and the Alternative Living Expo in Philadelphia.   

We ZENnies (as we call ourselves) have willingly donated our time, energy, and our own limited personal funds to keep these movies and the fan experiences go with them alive in our region (and all on a volunteer basis)! At least once a week (but often more frequently), we get together and spend a minimum of 5 hours working on choreography, blocking, scene work, and character development.

Because shadowcasting can become incredibly expensive (both for individual performers and for communal cast items), we would like to humbly ask for your support.

The following is a basic list of what we intend to use these funds for:
- Props (ray gun, Criminologist Book, weight set, etc.)
- Set Pieces (Rocky's tank, functional wall with levers and switches, pommel horse, Frank's throne, etc.)
- Storage/Misc. (shelving for prop trailer, plywood to extend trailer, batteries, etc.)
- Communal Costume Pieces (Riff's and Magenta's space suits, screen accurate boas, wigs, etc.)
- Creation of apparel/merch (tee shirts, stickers, buttons, etc.) 

Lastly, we would like to thank everyone who has helped us along the way with loans (Space Suits on loan from Seduction Production from Toledo, OH), advice, donations, rehearsal space, and performance opportunities. Last but certainly not least, we thank all our fans who have faithfully attended and promoted our shows over the years. We would not be who we are today without your gracious support and love. Thank you so much, and thank you to those who are offering their support by sharing this fundraiser and helping us raise money.

story:
The Story of In/Visible City

The story of In/Visible City begins in 2005, when DAH Theatre, the single professional alternative theatre in Serbia which has been actively creating since 1991, embarks on a journey with a wish to destigmatize the question of differences, national minorities and xenophobia. The journey is not just a metaphorical one, but a literal one - through the capital of Serbia, Belgrade. In search of ways to connect its citizens and educate them about all of the things that bring us together despite our differences, we decided to make an interactive performance, on a city bus line that connects two culturally exceedingly contrasted ends of the city. Various dramatic, dance and musical scenes, emerging from an original script that was created from the stories, dances and music which relate to the particular part of the city which the bus is going through, change and draw the passengers into those magical and inspirational stories filled with love, understanding, perseverance and compassion.

By putting theatrical action into a city bus, the prosaic situation of city transportation is made uncommon, and the richness of diversities that we carry daily within ourselves suddenly rises into focus. The bus is a condensed space in which our coexistence and our tolerance for the Other is being put to the test on a daily basis.

In 2005, all of the passengers who embarked on a journey with us experienced a great deal of surprise, and all of the stories were met with approval and support. Many passengers decided not to get out on their stop, but to stay until the end of the performance. The busses were crowded, and other people had to wait for another bus because they couldn’t get in. Some even hailed a cab hoping to get into the bus at some of the following stops. Some went out of the bus visibly shaken up saying ’’What have they done to us?’’. Our usually somber co-citizens would often climb off the bus with wide smiles on their faces. During this magical journey, passengers were able to obtain additional information about the project from flyers handed out at bus entrances.

Seeing the huge success this project had in 2005, DAH Theatre decided to extend it to the entire country in 2007/08.

In 2008 we successfully implemented the European pilot project  In/Visible City in Norway, and with a wish make a contribution to normalization of relations between various ethnic communities throughout Europe and development of a civic society based on tolerance, we implemented this project across Europe.

In 2010 we became the first Serbian organization to have become a holder of a project within an EU program entitled Culture 2007-13. Our bus went on a visit to four countries with four partners from Denmark, FYR Macedonia, Great Britain and France.

This project received an award from ERSTE Foundation for the best project in the field of social integration.

In 2014 In/Visible City was implemented in Sardinia.

Making In/Visible City Visible in 2015

This year we are celebrating a jubilee that we wish to mark by once again starting our busses’ engines and heading on a tour through our country, reminding it about all of those values that seem to have fallen into oblivion during the last several years. We begin celebrating the 10thanniversary of In/Visible City in Novi Sad, the city known for its richness of cultures and influences from diverse ethnic minorities. In light of recent incidents of attacks on members of national minorities, we believe this project to hold special importance. Attackers were prevalently young people, so this years-long project is focused on the youth, aiming to offer a different kind of picture to our society and a possibility to inhabit a different, constructive place in it. We are continuing our little journey we continue towards Inđija, a city filled with contrasts, diversities, history and conflicts. Our final destination is also our starting point – Belgrade – along the bus line that connects diverse cultures, various histories and stories.

To achieve this we need your support.

To be more specific: DAH Theatre has succeeded in gathering funds for implementation of this project in Novi Sad and Inđija, but we are in need of funds to travel a full circle with our project and dance one more dance at its birthplace. To reach this goal, we need exactly 12,000 euro, and so we reach out to all of you who are willing to help spread peacebuilding and tolerance, multiculturalism and to support putting an end to violence directed at all of those who are different in one way or another.

By donating you are helping us cover:

·  Fees for all the participants;

·  A conference dedicated to the significance of this project for Europe and Serbia;

·  Handouts and flyers with additional explanation and idea behind the project;

·  Promotion of the project and extension of its activities.

All donations, no matter how small, help spreading the idea of peacebuilding and tolerance. If you are in no position to donate, we would also appreciate if you would kindly spread the word of the idea and making it visible to other donators and backers.

And we have some interesting prizes for all our backers, so please join our little peace making community now.

story:
About THE MARK dance company:

THE MARK dance company was founded in 2012 by Artistic Director, Arlynn Zachary. Since the inception of the company, we have performed our repertoire at various professional concerts and dance festivals in North and South Carolina. Due to funding purposes THE MARK has always worked jointly with other artists to produce multi-company shows (showcasing only 1 - 2 of our own works in each concert). Thanks to the Charlotte Dance Festival, THE MARK will be able to produce our first full-length concert The Next Step on March 19th, 12pm, at the Duke Energy Theater in Charlotte, NC.


About "The Next Step" concert:

The Next Step is a 90 minute concert showcasing the culmination of several dance repertoire pieces we have set on the company since 2012. The concert features 9 dancers and will present 9 works, showcasing one world-premiere, two Charlotte-premieres, a film for dance piece, and the very first piece created for the company’s repertory, all nestled between a collection of audience favorites. The title for this concert depicts THE MARK’s advancement into ‘the next step’ within our company's career.

Through this fundraising campaign, contributors will help THE MARK to off-set production costs that incoming ticket sales will not cover. As a company, we want to not only cover the facility and technical costs, but also provide our dancers with some form of compensation for the hard work and long hours they have put into creating and presenting this concert.


Breakdown of Concert Expenses:

  • $300: CDF Administration Fee
  • $250: Campaign Administration Fee (if full funding is obtained)
  • $800: Theater
  • $540: Lighting Designer
  • $150: Stage Manager
  • $150: Videographer
  • $200: Costumes (we are excited to be designing and creating a new set of costumes for the world-premiere of our newest piece, Paloria!)
  • $2,500: 1 Choreographer & 9 dancers (rehearsals/performance stipend)


    • Total Expenses: $4890

    Estimate Income from tickets: $2,500

    Campaign Goal: $2,400 (Exciting fact: If THE MARK raises at least $1k in this campaign, our fiscal agent Fractured Atlas will sponsor us in the pursuit of applying for future grants to help found the company!!!)


    If we do not reach a minimum of $2,400 in our advertising campaign, THE MARK will need to cut-down on the small stipend each of the 9 dancers and the choreographer will receive. All other costs are fixed prices and must be paid for the show to be produced. If ticket sales do not cover the facility/technical costs of the concert itself, the Artistic Director will need to cover any additional expenses out-of-pocket.


    ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX-DEDUCTABLE!!!!!


    The Impact:

    THE MARK has been working extensively in the Charlotte dance community to bridge the gaps between dancers and audience members, providing opportunities for performances to take place. By producing their own show, THE MARK will be able to provide a more personal approach to their audience. This chance to perform for patrons and new audience members alike, will provide an even stronger footing for promoting the company towards future full-length concerts. 

    THE MARK has successfully turned out audience-choice favorites in each of their concerts for the last several years. By putting this show together, we want to thank all of our patrons for supporting us, and encouraging us throughout the last few years. Without the faithful interest and support of our audiences, we wouldn't be able to do what we are capable of in this community. This concert is a testament to that support!

    The funding for this concert will also provide much-needed assistance in paying dancers. Each company member donates a significant amount of time towards the creation of each work. We would like to be able to recognize them, and show our appreciation through providing a small stipend for the work they have done. 


    Risks & Challenges:

    The show must go on! Even if we do not receive full funding from this campaign, we will still produce the show. Most of the budget is a fixed price and does not give us much wiggle-room for trimming back costs. This leaves us in a place where dancers stipends will be the first and only thing that we can cut back on in costs. 

    Choosing to produce this show, does have a risk-factor, in that if we do not reach our ticket sale goals and/or raise enough via our online fundraiser, all expenses will need to be paid out-of-pocket by the Artistic Director, Arlynn Zachary. Finding personal funding to sponsor a full-length concert (and not being able to provide for that in the past) is why the company has not produced their own show before. With the prospect of potential grad-school on the horizon for Arlynn, out-of-pocket funding will be difficult to put into this show....but....the show must go on!


    Other Ways You Can Help:

    • Spread the word about our campaign!!! If you know of anyone who would be interested in donating to help fund our concert (tax-deductable), send out our campaign info and get us connected!
    • "Like" us on Facebook! www.facebook.com/themarkdancecompany
    • Buy tickets to our show! (Make sure to put THE MARK on your calendar for March 19th at 12pm!) 
    THE MARK dance company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of THE MARK dance company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

$540: Lighting Designer
$150: Stage Manager
$150: Videographer
$200: Costumes (we are excited to be designing and creating a new set of costumes for the world-premiere of our newest piece, Paloria!)
$2,500: 1 Choreographer & 9 dancers (rehearsals/performance stipend)

Total Expenses: $4890
Estimate Income from tickets: $2,500
Campaign Goal: $2,400 (Exciting fact: If THE MARK raises at least $1k in this campaign, our fiscal agent Fractured Atlas will sponsor us in the pursuit of applying for future grants to help found the company!!!)

If we do not reach a minimum of $2,400 in our advertising campaign, THE MARK will need to cut-down on the small stipend each of the 9 dancers and the choreographer will receive. All other costs are fixed prices and must be paid for the show to be produced. If ticket sales do not cover the facility/technical costs of the concert itself, the Artistic Director will need to cover any additional expenses out-of-pocket.

ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX-DEDUCTABLE!!!!!

   The Impact: THE MARK has been working extensively in the Charlotte dance community to bridge the gaps between dancers and audience members, providing opportunities for performances to take place. By producing their own show, THE MARK will be able to provide a more personal approach to their audience. This chance to perform for patrons and new audience members alike, will provide an even stronger footing for promoting the company towards future full-length concerts. 
THE MARK has successfully turned out audience-choice favorites in each of their concerts for the last several years. By putting this show together, we want to thank all of our patrons for supporting us, and encouraging us throughout the last few years. Without the faithful interest and support of our audiences, we wouldn't be able to do what we are capable of in this community. This concert is a testament to that support!
The funding for this concert will also provide much-needed assistance in paying dancers. Each company member donates a significant amount of time towards the creation of each work. We would like to be able to recognize them, and show our appreciation through providing a small stipend for the work they have done. 
 
   Risks & Challenges: The show must go on! Even if we do not receive full funding from this campaign, we will still produce the show. Most of the budget is a fixed price and does not give us much wiggle-room for trimming back costs. This leaves us in a place where dancers stipends will be the first and only thing that we can cut back on in costs. 
Choosing to produce this show, does have a risk-factor, in that if we do not reach our ticket sale goals and/or raise enough via our online fundraiser, all expenses will need to be paid out-of-pocket by the Artistic Director, Arlynn Zachary. Finding personal funding to sponsor a full-length concert (and not being able to provide for that in the past) is why the company has not produced their own show before. With the prospect of potential grad-school on the horizon for Arlynn, out-of-pocket funding will be difficult to put into this show....but....the show must go on!
 
   Other Ways You Can Help:  Spread the word about our campaign!!! If you know of anyone who would be interested in donating to help fund our concert (tax-deductable), send out our campaign info and get us connected!
"Like" us on Facebook! www.facebook.com/themarkdancecompany

Buy tickets to our show! (Make sure to put THE MARK on your calendar for March 19th at 12pm!) 


THE MARK dance company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of THE MARK dance company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
P L A I N  &  S I M P L E

We ask for your support to fund the creation of innovative, original contemporary dance works and bring them to stages near & far in 2017.  

Become a part of our #MembersONLY club & assist us with the presentation of:

• |the sum of 4 / + one| JAN 20 & 21 - Mandelstam Theater, South Miami, FL   

• |apportioners & capers of destiny| APR 8 - Duncan Theater, Lake Worth, FL 

• |360º| MAY 31-JUN 6 - Plovdiv Drama Theater, Plovdiv, Bulgaria 

 

W H A T   F U N D I N G   C O V E R S

| the sum of 4 /+ one | Dancer salaries, lighting designer, technical staff/crew, lodging, per diem, 3 round trip flights from NYC to MIA, HOU to MIA, RI to MIA, luggage fees, theatre/production costs, insurance, costuming, sets

| apportioners & capers of destiny | Dancer salaries, gas allowance

| 360º | Dancer salaries (for 3 working months,) lighting designer, lodging, per diem for dancers and staff, 3 round trip flights from NYC to MIA, RI to MIA (for rehearsal processes,) 6 international round trip flights from MIA to BULGARIA (4 dancers & 2 co-directors), luggage fees, transfers, costuming, props, shipping, insurance, music copyrights

*There are also campaigning fees to consider, as well as, potential for additional Summer & Fall  touring to Mexico City and Panama to participate in Festivals 

 

I M P A C T   Y O U R   G I F T   W I L L   M A K E

iMEE guarantees to put your contribution to powerful use by continuing to share our vision with audiences in the United States and abroad. There is NO amount too small (or too large) and any contribution will make an impact on the creation and presentation of:  1) iMEE full programming in South Florida for the first time, 2) incorporating the talents of a young artist for the first time for our performances in Bulgaria and 3) crossing the pond for our second tour to Eastern Europe. Even if we do not complete our goal, ALL monies raised will go directly towards artist compensation, travel and production costs. The more we raise, the more work we can produce and get #iMEEonthemove in 2017! Support our momentum and help iMEE build larger audiences.  We thank you in advance for your new and continued support!

 

recap on the "W H O"

Over the past seven years, iMEE has provided quality art education through multi-disciplinary collaborations and dance programming for audiences in Southern California, South East Texas, Florida, Rhode Island, Italy & Bulgaria. The company has participated in several Festivals, including: Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance 2009, 2010, 2011; FestOval of Dance (FL) 2012; Houston Dance Festival 2011; McCallum Theatre’s 15th & 17th Annual Choreography Festival (CA) 2012, 2014; Palcoscenico de Danza (Italy) 2013; The Dance Gallery Festival (TX & NY) 2011, 2012; Boston Contemporary Dance Festival 2014; Mass Dance Festival (MASS) 2014; the black box INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL THEATRE & DANCE (Bulgaria) 2015, 2017; Barnstorm Dance Fest (TX) 2016 and Festival Internacional de Danza Contemporanea de la Ciudad de Mexico (Mexico City) 2016. CLICK HERE to learn more about our 2016/17 Season.

 

the S K I N N Y....  i M E E  2017  P R O J E C T S

| the sum of 4 /+ one | iMEE presents the sum of four / + one Friday, January 20 & Saturday, January 21, 2017 at the Mandelstam Theater in South Miami, FL. the sum of four / + one showcases video landscape & film shorts by Oliver Halkowich (an iMEE project artist and soloist with the Houston Ballet,) as well as, concept & choreography by iMEE Co-Directors, Spencer G. Hering & Andrea D.  Shelley. Light design by Amanda Motta. This body of work demonstrates the company’s flair for dramatic story telling while examining acceptance and surrender experienced during life encounters. “When you repeat a mistake, it is not a mistake anymore; it’s a decision.”  the sum of 4 / + one premiered October 2015, Megley Black Box Theater, Newport, RI and premieres Winter 2017 in South Florida.

| apportioners & capers of destiny | iMEE presents Spencer Gavin Hering's visually pleasing apportioners & capers of destiny Saturday, April 8, 2017 at the Duncan Theater in Lake Worth, Florida as part of create.DANCE.florida presented by The Dancers' Space. apportioners & capers of destiny, which recently premiered on November 17-20, 2016 at Moorpark Performing Arts Center in Moorpark, CA, is inspired by the three spinners of destiny and the Greek Mythological tale of the Moirai. Hering will extend the work for it's South Florida premiere in the Spring. 

| 360º | iMEE presents and premieres 360º  May 31- June 6, 2017 at the Plovdiv Drama Theater in Plovdiv, Bulgaria at the black box INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL THEATER & DANCE 2017.  iMEE’s first performances at the black box IFTD2015 were such a success that the company was invited to return to the Festival for a second time!  These performances will include, in our line-up of world class artists for the first time, a young artist. Young artist and ABT  full time student, Jack Wolff will join us for our World Premiere of 360º. Inspired by the Fibonacci sequence in nature, 360º revolves around the journey through life from adolescences to adulthood… 360º, full circle. CLICK HERE to unlock a secret perk!  

 

WHAT'S IN IT FOR ME, YOU MIGHT FIND YOURSELF ASKING? Well... You might just find yourself feeling a great deal of satisfaction in knowing that your contribution helped iMEE present our very first young artist, as well as, our newest work to audiences in South Florida, Eastern Europe and potentially in Mexico City and Panama. You can share in our excitement and take ownership in knowing that your generosity & belief in what we do will have played a major role in our success. You will have our INFINITE GRATITUDE, some "epic" karma coming your way and… some dope perks!  

UNABLE TO MAKE A CONTRIBUTION AT THIS TIME?  Well... Share our campaign with your friends via Email, Facebook or any social media outlet possible and spread the word about iMEE. Consider donating your sky miles and help us "fly the friendly skies". This really great option has helped us tremendously with touring in the past. Sky mile donations are an invaluable, in-kind contribution.  

 

T H E  L A S T   P L E A

Please help us continue to produce and present high-quality, ever-evolving contemporary dance to cities across the US, South Florida, and abroad into 2017 and beyond.  Your support will help us continue to realize our goal of becoming a touring company of national & international prominence. We hope that you will be inspired to include iMEE in your year-end giving. Become a part of our #MembersONLY club by making a contribution that will allow us to continue to realize our mission! Thank you.  

INFINITE GRATITUDE…

iMEE

story:
Shortly before his death, Bishop Joseph Sullivan of Brooklyn, NY commissioned us to write a play based on the real life stories of LGBT Catholics and their families.  The result is Full of Grace, a unique theatrical piece based on stories of both clergy and laity of all ages and from all over the country.  Through these stories, audiences enter into the struggles and triumphs of real people seeking to  reconcile their Catholic faith with their own dreams and desires.  

This campaign is to bring this play to its final stage of development from reading to production.  Full of Grace will be fully staged as part of The Rough Draft Festival at Laguardia Performing Arts Center.  We will hold 3 performances of the play on

Friday March 24 at 7pm

Saturday, March 25 at 7pm

 Sunday, March 27 at 7pm.  

Your contributions will be used to mount this full production which will include costumes, set and lighting not to mention world-class actors and a dedicated and creative production staff. 

Following the Rough Draft Festival, Full of Grace will be ready for touring.  It is our plan to tour Full of Grace to Catholic college campuses across the United States and abroad to foster a conversation on sexual identity and faith among students and faculty.  In addition, we hope to bring the play to Catholic parishes, regional theaters and other theatre festivals to share these important and prophetic stories of faith and grace.  

Your contribution now will go a long way to helping us achieve our goal of bringing these stories to a broader audience and shedding light on these untold stories.

Also, we invite you to come to the show!.  More information on the performances can be found here:  http://www.lpac.nyc/rough-draft-2017.

More info about the play itself and its development can be found at our website:  www.fullofgraceplay.com

story:
Dear Voyeur,

Willkommen, Bienvenue, Welcome... to Berlin's most provocative Weimar Cabaret experience: Kabarett der Namenlosen. Originally created by Jewish Conférencier, Eric 'Elow' Lowinsky' in 1926, Kabarett der Namenlosen was infamous for presenting only the worst possible talent, in order to satisfy the perverted pleasures of a cruel audience.

Visiting Berlin in 2012, I was instantly intrigued by the title alone, but wanted to reinvent Elow's original concept and offer something dreamier, darker and more poetic. Kabarett der Namenlosen 2016 is presented in English and German and comprises, part Theatre, part Cabaret, part Salon and sometimes Pantomime. The show incorporates original music, including period composers: Mischa Spoliansky, Bertolt Brecht and Friedrich Hollaender, interwoven with bizarre Performance Art, Tableaux Vivants and short 'Vignettes'.

WHY we need YOUR Contributions:

Kabarett has been lovingly nurtured with passion, energy and enthusiasm.  Audiences at the show are thrilled, inspired and even slightly unnerved;  theatre is supposed to do that. The show has been produced twice in recent months, to prove it's potential and the response has been overwhelming. To move forward we now need YOUR support to expand the production in 2017, initially in Berlin and then further afield.

What are we using the funds for?

We have tried and tested the show on a self funded basis. Now we need more people to discover and believe in the potential of this beautiful creation.. Therefore we need to raise additional funds to cover the Marketing and Production Costs that would help the show to develop and evolve. We aim to raise £15,000 in total:

Marketing: £8.000

This is essential for any emerging show. We need to fund a strong and visible campaign to reach a wider audience and spread the word. The show IS a success but we need the WORLD to know.

In the wise words of P.T. Barnum : "Without promotion, something terrible happens... nothing!"

Production Costs: £7.000

Kabarett is an expensive and extravagant show to stage. The show is presented in an authentic pre-war venue (with original features) thus providing the perfect "mise-en-scène" for this spectacle. In addition we need: new costumes, set and a variety of curated props are required to recreate the Zeitgeist of the Golden Twenties. We also need to secure new equipment, hire additional staff and pay for extra rehearsals.

Photo by © Ben Asif

Have you seen our exciting Perks?

We are offering exclusive artwork and merchandise, VIP show tickets, personal meet and greets, a photoshoot, a private 'Vintage' tour of Berlin and even an intimate dinner with the star of Kabarett, Le Pustra. Go and look for yourself.

Illustration created by Massimiliano Mocchia di Coggiola

Final thoughts..

Innovative theatre needs to be encouraged as it requires endless motivation, self belief and determination. This show is not only historically important in keeping the spirit of Weimar Berlin alive but it offers all of us the chance to dream... AND WE ALL NEED TO DREAM ONCE IN A WHILE.

Photo by © Ben Asif
 

How else can YOU be involved?

If you are unable to contribute you can still help Kabarett. Have you seen the show yet? Or do you like the 1920's? Are you a fan of femme fatale, Lada Redstar? Then you can still help! Share our campaign on Social Media and make Le Pustra' s Kabarett der Namenlosen more visible. Here is our Facebook Event:

https://www.facebook.com/events/1770320919885836/

Thank you for reading and see you at the Kabarett. And.. NEVER stop dreaming!

Le Pustra, Artistic Director.

Photo by © Daggi Binder

WHAT THEY SAY:

http://www.independent.co.uk/travel/europe/berlin-alternative-clubs-nightlife-berghain-lgbt-kabarett-der-namenlosen-ballhaus-porn-karaoke-a7371336.html
