story:
THE SHOW

When you hear the words "Baroque-Metal Wrestling Opera", you might be thinking.... 

What?

Let us introduce you to "The Final Battle for Love," the first of its kind. An all-star cast takes the audience on an emotional, musical, and dramatic tour de force in under an hour. As the Narrator feels his relationship with his girlfriend Starla slipping away, he watches the city where he lives lose its one crowning glory-- its professional wrestling league. The final event the wrestling league will present before its dissolution is "The Final Battle for Love," in which the misogynistic (but extremely muscular) Bob Noxious will fight the paisley-clad Lord Poetry for the affections of the beloved Darling Donnis. Who will win? Will the Narrator and Starla turn over a new leaf? And what becomes of "love," that ephemeral beast?

THE PERFORMANCE

Thompson Street Opera Company produced the premiere of this amazing show in Louisville, KY in June of 2016, and since the company moved to Chicago IL this summer, we have been dying to introduce it to new audiences. We have commissioned a new arrangement from the composer for string quartet, keyboards, and drumset, which is easily manageable in the smaller space we'll be performing in. The cast of 14 singers will bring their fantastic voices, epic wrestling moves, and poignant story-telling abilities to the West Stage of Chicago's Raven Theatre Complex. Performances will be January 19-21 at 8:00PM, and January 22 at 2:00pm. 

WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION SUPPORTS

As a small company, we work on a very small budget. What that means for you, is that every dollar goes a LONG way. Here are some examples:

$1000 will pay for our venue rental
$750 will pay for our pit orchestra
$500 will pay our pianist and Music Director
$250 will sponsor a principal singer
$100 will pay for the costumes OR the set
$50 will print our programs
$25 will print posters for promotion
$10 will pay for snacks so the cast won't pass out from low blood sugar while wrestling

*SPECIAL PERK FOR DONATIONS ABOVE $500*

LIMITED EDITION Bob Noxious T-shirt. YOU KNOW YOU WANT IT!

ABOUT THE COMPANY

After four successful seasons in Louisville, KY, Thompson Street Opera Company has decided to call Chicago its new home! Our mission is:  

  • To produce high-quality performances of new operatic works, particularly those that bring non-traditional audiences to opera 
  • To provide professional-level opportunities to current students and recent graduates of music degree programs 
  • To inspire performers to be advocates for contemporary opera 

The company has produced the World Premiere of eight operas, US Premieres of two, and Regional Premieres of five more. We are quickly becoming a sought-after organization by composers who want their work to receive a professional production with exceptional singing actors. 

Louisville Public Media called our work "...opera stripped down to its bare essentials-- powerful voices and beautiful music." Our US Premiere of Robin Haigh's The Man Who Woke Up was called "very funny and provocative" by BroadwayWorld, and Arts-Louisville praised the cast of Chappell Kingsland's Intoxication: America's Love Affair with Oil as "an impressive assemblage of talent." 

Central to our methods is our belief that the best art is created by a group of people who are personally, as well as professionally, committed to one another. We aim not only to create great performances of important new operas, but also to form a community of like-minded artists that support and enrich each other's lives. We pride ourselves on being an encouraging and loving company to work for, and we provide a nurturing place for emerging and established talent alike.
story_txt:
THE SHOWWhen you hear the words "Baroque-Metal Wrestling Opera", you might be thinking.... What?Let us introduce you to "The Final Battle for Love," the first of its kind. An all-star cast takes the audience on an emotional, musical, and dramatic tour de force in under an hour. As the Narrator feels his relationship with his girlfriend Starla slipping away, he watches the city where he lives lose its one crowning glory-- its professional wrestling league. The final event the wrestling league will present before its dissolution is "The Final Battle for Love," in which the misogynistic (but extremely muscular) Bob Noxious will fight the paisley-clad Lord Poetry for the affections of the beloved Darling Donnis. Who will win? Will the Narrator and Starla turn over a new leaf? And what becomes of "love," that ephemeral beast?THE PERFORMANCEThompson Street Opera Company produced the premiere of this amazing show in Louisville, KY in June of 2016, and since the company moved to Chicago IL this summer, we have been dying to introduce it to new audiences. We have commissioned a new arrangement from the composer for string quartet, keyboards, and drumset, which is easily manageable in the smaller space we'll be performing in. The cast of 14 singers will bring their fantastic voices, epic wrestling moves, and poignant story-telling abilities to the West Stage of Chicago's Raven Theatre Complex. Performances will be January 19-21 at 8:00PM, and January 22 at 2:00pm. WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION SUPPORTSAs a small company, we work on a very small budget. What that means for you, is that every dollar goes a LONG way. Here are some examples:$1000 will pay for our venue rental$750 will pay for our pit orchestra$500 will pay our pianist and Music Director$250 will sponsor a principal singer$100 will pay for the costumes OR the set$50 will print our programs$25 will print posters for promotion$10 will pay for snacks so the cast won't pass out from low blood sugar while wrestling*SPECIAL PERK FOR DONATIONS ABOVE $500*LIMITED EDITION Bob Noxious T-shirt. YOU KNOW YOU WANT IT!ABOUT THE COMPANYAfter four successful seasons in Louisville, KY, Thompson Street Opera Company has decided to call Chicago its new home! Our mission is:

To provide professional-level opportunities to current students and recent graduates of music degree programs

story:
**All donations are tax-deductible**

What is MOTION PICTURE SHOW?

Founded by Director/Choreographer, Nick Kepley, MOTION PICTURE SHOW is a physical theatre company which challenges its audiences to engage beyond the fourth wall through immersive, site-specfic works. Using a blend of familiar narrative, dynamic physical movement, and beautiful design instillation, the company places audience members at the center of their own story, allowing them to make split second decisions using intuition as their only guide. 

Where does my money go?

Donations made to this campaign will go directly toward the financing of a developmental lab for REAL LIFE TEST. The lab will be held in a former hosiery mill in Spruce Pine, NC. From there, the show will travel east to be reinstalled in an abandoned Coca Cola Factory in Spruce Pine, NC. There, RLT will open its doors to our first paying audiences. ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX-DEDUCTIBLE through the fiscal sponsorship of MOTION Dance Theatre.

How we say thank you!

Thanks to several private investors and producers, MPS is only looking to raise $3,500 through this IndieGoGo campaign! This amount will allow us to integrate more sophisticated lighting and sound into the show, and will also help finance performer salaries. We plan to post regular updates on the project, along with behind-the-scenes videos of the creation process as the show progresses. By investing in this show, you will become part of the MOTION PICTURE SHOW family. We're a company that likes to work hard and play harder, and so we've come up with some fun ways to say thank you to our financial supporters!

Why should I support this project?

MOTION PICTURE SHOW strives to build experiences that provoke, surprise, entice, and touch audiences in a visceral way not possible through more traditional forms of proscenium theatre. Building a large, multi-story show requires not only years of effort, but large amount of financial support. However, MPS is 100% committed to building worlds which feel completely real and which allow audiences to fall into the spell of whatever story we are telling. 

We believe that REAL LIFE TEST is a show that is incredibly timely. The warnings of George Orwell's 1984 resonant more strongly today than ever. But the message of our show is equally about the power, freedom and exhilaration which can be discovered when you allow yourself to truly release and be no more, or less, than who you truly are.

I donated! What else can I do?

First of all, THANK YOU! Your support means the world to us. Please help us spread the word to more people by using the IndieGoGo share tools.

story:
CIANE nace en el año 2002 cargado de ideas, valores, entendimientos, contrastes, sentimientos y una profunda pasión por el  arte y su poder transformador. Con un trabajo inspirado en el poder transformador de las artes, con fines de crecimiento humano y desarrollo social, aunado a la investigación del cuerpo como herramienta del intérprete escénico, las  investigaciones basadas en el estudio de la biomecánica, desarrollando nuestro trabajo en una fusión del teatro físico, la danza, la acrobacia y los zancos, sumando a estas disciplinas, bases del trabajo del CIANE, la iluminación escénica e iluminación corporal diseñada como un intérprete más, como parte fundamental del espectáculo cuando la ocasión lo permite, igualmente la conjunción de elementos que permiten la integración de los espacios tomados como escenario.

CIANE ha representado en muchas ocasiones a Venezuela en importantes eventos internacionales. Es considerado una importante agrupación experimental, como creadores de la Danza de Altura, es una agrupación que se mantiene en una investigación permanente en cuanto al trabajo físico del intérprete y el fortalecimiento de la masificación de las artes escénicas fomentando la intervención en  calles, parques, plazas, estacionamientos, sótanos, montañas y espacios no convencionales en general que logran cobrar vida en un encuentro entre el teatro de Calle, la Danza acrobática, las múltiples disciplinas escénicas posibles fusionadas en espectáculo, comunidad y el espacio público.

 

El Elenco de CIANE se prepara de un modo intensivo y disciplinado constantemente, ello implica la preparación psico física y estimulación de la creatividad sumado a la vinculación permanente con el entorno, la colectividad, la calle, el medio ambiente, el trabajo eco creativo, y la interacción con nuestros escenarios, entiéndase la Urbe, las calles, la ciudad entera, así como también los ambientes naturales en una constante búsqueda, estableciendo puentes entre la sensibilidad del artista y la importancia de una relación sostenible con la naturaleza.

 

Cómo será destinado el dinero recaudado

Para el mes de Octubre 2016 CIANE ha sido invitado en representación de Venezuela a una gira internacional en Colombia, que incluye Córdoba, Huila y Cundinamarca. En vista de no contar con apoyo institucional siempre CIANE se ha dedicado a proyectar el trabajo a través de la autogestión y en esta oportunidad tendremos la dicha de contar con tu apoyo, lo cual de antemano agradecemos con el corazón. 

Tu ayuda nunca será pequeña, sea cual sea tu aporte es vital para alcanzar la meta. Tu eres parte de nosotros, de la fuerza que nos inspira, contamos contigo y una vez que salgamos de nuestras fronteras tu energía nos acompañara a cada paso. 

El dinero recaudado en esta campaña será destinado al traslado hasta Bogotá del elenco de CIANE que forma parte del espectáculo VUELVO AL SUR, creado y dirigido por Soraya Orta en homenaje a la memoria de Esquía Ramírez. Una vez en la capital colombiana el traslado interno lo asumirá la organización del país anfitrión. 

Importancia de tu aporte para CIANE y para el mundo

CIANE, como agrupación de teatro experimental y laboratorio creativo ha generado un gran movimiento de crecimiento humano y profesional para generaciones jóvenes y también para no tan jóvenes que comprenden la importancia del no sedentarismo. 

En una época en que la tecnología, la globalización y nuevos paradigmas en la comunicación envuelven a la sociedad, ¿cómo puede el teatro ser ajeno a estas posibilidades de transformación?. Siendo un arte antiguo, que se mantiene vivo y presente en nuestra época, ha de permanecer con la potencia necesaria que permitirá hacer indispensable mantener ese punto de encuentro, esa relación con el espectador, insustituible, donde se genera un intercambio de energías vivas y retroalimentación diferente en cada representación, siendo cada una de ellas, una nueva experiencia.

La necesidad de un escenario vivo, de un torbellino de energía y flujo de percepciones nos lleva a determinar la importancia de la inclusión de nuevas técnicas actorales transdisciplinarias y multidisciplinarias en los montajes de CIANE, producto de una estrategia de creación generado a partir de la fisicalidad.

Esta visión ha generado un gran interés internacional sobre el trabajo de CIANE y la necesidad de proyección del mismo, así como de actividades formativas, multiplicadoras de estos valores. 

Tu apoyo es tan valioso que no solo va a repercutir en CIANE, ni se detendrá en el tiempo un vez culminada la gira, tu apoyo permanecerá en una realidad de transformación en cada espectador, en todo el público asistente, en nosotros, en cada actor - intérprete apoyado por ti, en sus familiares y amigos, en su entorno, en un país que te lo agradece por la oportunidad que le das de ser representado fuera de las fronteras. 

CIANE ha tenido la dicha de girar  nacional e internacionalmente desde sus inicios representado a Venezuela en diferentes eventos internacionales en Bogotá, San Juan de Pasto, Barranquilla, Mesitas, Pradilla, Cartagena, San Andrés Islas, Providencia, Santa Marta, La Guajira, Riohacha, Tunja, Medellín, Manizales, Cali, Buenaventura, Sahagún, Neiva, Tópaga, Iza, Pesca, Monguí,  Cúcuta, Facatativá, Viotá (Colombia) Bérgamo, Milán, Roma, Florencia (Italia), Morelia, Pátzcuaro (México), Panamá (Panamá) entre otros, generando la masificación de la cultura y el intercambio así como la difusión de la técnica a través del trabajo pedagógico desarrollado  en diferentes ciudades del mundo

story:
Who am I?

My name is Megan Gogerty. I'm a playwright and comedian. I'm also a professor at the University of Iowa Playwrights Workshop. 

I've written my fourth full-length solo show, which premieres at Riverside Theatre in Iowa City in February 2017. It's directed by Saffron Henke and it stars lil' ole me.

The show is called Lady Macbeth and Her Pal, Megan, and it's about the following things: a) What's it like being a woman in comedy? b.) Sexism! So hilarious! c.) Not Hillary Clinton. d.) Witchcraft - a promising lifestyle choice? e.) We are all Lady Macbeth, yearning and striving and trapped by our own ambition. f.) Delightful, enjoyable rage. 

 

What do I want?

I want to take my show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland in August 2017. This is a big deal. EdFringe is the largest arts festival in the world. For three weeks, the whole town hosts thousands of shows, comedians, dancers, street performers, students, and performance artists. It's a "go big or go home" situation. I've been home. I think it's time I go big.

Plus, if I'm going to write a play about Lady Macbeth, I might as well do it in Scotland.

 

What We Need 

Three weeks in Scotland - even with a show as sleek and travel-ready as mine - is expensive. I need to raise $20,000 to make it happen. Here's roughly where the money goes:

  • $6,000: Venue. This includes theatre rental, liability insurance, box office commission fees, and  program fees to the Edinburgh Festival Society.
  • $3,000: Marketing. In addition to working with the EdFringe people, I'm also hiring a professional public relations expert to help my show stand out from the throng. 
  • $3,000: Travel. This primarily means airfare for me and my team.
  • $6,000: Lodging. It turns out, living in Scotland for almost a month is expensive! And space during the Festival is at a premium. 
  • $2,000: Miscellaneous. This covers food, sim cards so our cell phones work overseas, and other contingency costs. 

 

What You Get

My undying gratitude! But also, when you donate at the following amounts, you get fun perks:

  • Any amount: A public, personalized thank-you splattered all over my social media.
  • $20 Text Vacations! Give me your cell phone number or email address, and I'll text you three imaginary mini-vacation stories ("You're standing on a beach...") designed to transport you out of your hectic life for a moment or two. 
  • $50 A Mediocre Poem! A personalized poem of middling quality - but with your name in it! - flung all over my social media.
  • $100 Exclusive Video Diary Updates! I'll send you video updates regaling you with my adventures in Scotland. It'll be like you're there, only without the jet lag. 
  • $500 PDF of an Annotated Script! I'll send you the script of the show with special notes in the margins - what parts I cut out, which parts were hard to write, etc. A personal tour.
  • $1000 Living Room Show! If you live within two hours of Iowa City, I'll come to your house and do the show for you and your friends right in your living room.  That's a hell of a theme party.

 

The Impact

This show is really important to me. I'm digging deep, telling some hard truths, and trying - please, God - to make it funny along the way. 

Some of you have been following my career for some time. Maybe you remember my last solo show, Housebroken (you can watch the whole show right here). I've taken my shows all around the United States. They've made yearly Best Of lists, they've been published and performed by others, and I've met a lot of great people along the way. 

But this show feels different. It feels risky. It feels urgent. After wading through 2016's cesspool of misogyny (You didn't notice? Just me, then? That's fine), I want to speak to these issues in a way that is warm and empathetic. I want to share my story with the world. 

 

Risks & Challenges

How am I going to get over there? What if I don't like Scottish food? What if they don't understand my thick American brogue? 

Deep breath, Megan. One thing at a time.

Live theatre is always a risk, and it's hardly ever a money-maker. That's not why we do it. We do it because the act of making a community out of strangers is transformative. We do it because empathy, the engine of all theatre, is a radical act. We do it because experiences are more profound and lasting than any products we might purchase. We do it because the world needs more art, and more love, and more connection.  

I don't know if it's going to work. I never know. I'm going to try it anyway.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you don't have any money, but you have deep love in your heart for me and my work. Here's how you can help me, even without cash:

  • Help me get the word out! Share, share, share. Indigogo has all these helpful Share tools to make it easy. The more people know about my campaign, the greater the chance I won't have to max out my credit cards.
  • Do you know anybody in Edinburgh? Do you think they'd mind if a group of polite Midwesterners stayed at their house for a few weeks?
  • Do you have any frequent flyer miles? Maybe they're just sitting there in your account, gathering dust. 
  • Tell people about the show in general! Send them to my show's website LadyMacbethShow.com for more details.

Thanks for being wonderful. I love you.

Some of you have been following my career for some time. Maybe you remember my last solo show, Housebroken (you can watch the whole show right here). I've taken my shows all around the United States. They've made yearly Best Of lists, they've been published and performed by others, and I've met a lot of great people along the way. 
But this show feels different. It feels risky. It feels urgent. After wading through 2016's cesspool of misogyny (You didn't notice? Just me, then? That's fine), I want to speak to these issues in a way that is warm and empathetic. I want to share my story with the world. 
 

Risks & Challenges
How am I going to get over there? What if I don't like Scottish food? What if they don't understand my thick American brogue? 
Deep breath, Megan. One thing at a time.
Live theatre is always a risk, and it's hardly ever a money-maker. That's not why we do it. We do it because the act of making a community out of strangers is transformative. We do it because empathy, the engine of all theatre, is a radical act. We do it because experiences are more profound and lasting than any products we might purchase. We do it because the world needs more art, and more love, and more connection.  
I don't know if it's going to work. I never know. I'm going to try it anyway.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Maybe you don't have any money, but you have deep love in your heart for me and my work. Here's how you can help me, even without cash:


Help me get the word out! Share, share, share. Indigogo has all these helpful Share tools to make it easy. The more people know about my campaign, the greater the chance I won't have to max out my credit cards.

Do you know anybody in Edinburgh? Do you think they'd mind if a group of polite Midwesterners stayed at their house for a few weeks?

Do you have any frequent flyer miles? Maybe they're just sitting there in your account, gathering dust. 

Tell people about the show in general! Send them to my show's website LadyMacbethShow.com for more details.

Thanks for being wonderful. I love you.

story:
Performed first in 1942 with children of the Jewish orphanage in Prague, Hans Kraśa  reconstructed his opera, Brundibár, from memory after he was sent to Theresienstadt  concentration camp in 1943.

Tailored to the children and thirteen adult instrumentalists in the camp, the opera was performed fifty-five times within the walls of the Theresienstadt.

While the children were onstage playing their roles in 1943 and 1944, they lived some of the last happy hours of their short existence creating this masterful work of art. Fewer than twenty of the many children who had participated in Brundibár survived the war.

After the death of Krása and the liberation of the camp, the opera fell out of sight until 1986, when it was performed for Radio Prague. World interest was sparked, and Brundibár has had a slow but steady recognition by opera enthusiasts. The voices of Ojai Youth Opera now echo the message of Brundibár, one of hope, that has touched countless audiences all over the world for the past seventy years. 

Since its inception in 2012, Ojai Youth Opera, OYO as we affectionately call it, has been providing opera education outreach programs to the youth of Ventura and Santa Barbara counties while enriching the cultural landscape of these communities and beyond.

We are committed to creating opportunities for children to discover opera, fostering transformative outreach and education about the operatic arts and encouraging its growth through our distinct Ojai educational programs, workshops, and camps.

As the first stand-alone children’s opera company in the United States, OYO is also developing a replicable model for budding youth opera programs in other parts of the country to follow. 

Andrew Petracca, age 24, is a vocalist and multi-instrumentalist. He has been singing professionally since he was 8 years old, touring America and the world as a soloist and section leader in the All-American Boys Chorus for 6 years. In high school he pursued extensive piano and vocal studies, singing in Opera Pacific's opera camp for 2 years and participating as a pianist at the International Institute for Young Musicians. He was given the privilege in 2007 to play the villain in the American debut of the opera "The Star Child" by German composer Hans-Andre Stamm. He studied piano performance at the University of Kansas, and also at Fullerton college where he began to acquaint himself more deeply with jazz music. He is a guest artist/faculty member of the Ojai Youth Opera company, and will play  Vodnik in Rusalka at the Vivace opera workshop in Vancouver this August. He currently lives in Camarillo, where he makes music full time. 

 
Kaylie Turner was born in Ojai, California. She is a student at Villanova Preparatory School, but will be attending Nordhoff High School as a junior next year. Kaylie began playing the violin at age six and started voice lessons at the age of 12. She has been focusing on voice ever since. She attended Interlochen Center of the Arts Summer Camp for violin in 2013 and 2015. Kaylie will be returning to Interlochen again this summer for their high school vocal artist program. This past summer she was a part of Idyllwild Arts Academy’s Festival Choir. Recent performances include the role of a child in Opera Santa Barbara’s production of Carmen, the role of the cricket and a fox cub in Opera Santa Barbara’s production of The Cunning Little Vixen, and at Carnegie Hall with the Honors Performance Series Concert Choir. She will be playing the role of Annika in Ojai Youth Opera’s production of Brundibar in May 2017. She is a singer with both Santa Barbara Youth Opera and Ojai Youth Opera. Besides her love of singing, Kaylie enjoys spending time with her family and friends. She hopes to grow her love of classical singing into a career.

Rebecca Comerford (mezzo soprano) is the founder of Ojai Youth  Opera Company. She has sung both nationally and internationally as an opera soloist with some of the world's finest houses, under the baton of Metropolitan Opera conductor Steven Crawford in Rigoletto at Carneigie Hall, the New York City Opera VOX series, the National Chorale at Lincoln Center, Spleto Opera Italy, Neue Oper Wien, Opera Memphis, Utah Festival Opera, Tanglewood Music Center, The Granada Festival for Spanish Song Spain, Brevard Music Center and Aspen Opera Theater. Notable roles include Carmen (Carmen), Siebel (Faust), Tisbe (La Cenerentola), Meg(Little Women), Lucretia (The Rape of Lucretia) and Lucy Brown in the Off Broadway Revival of The Threepenny Opera. She holds a Masters Degree of Music from Manhattan School of Music in New York and a Bachelors Degree in Voice from Eastman School of Music in Rochester, NY. While in New York she co-founded City Youth Opera Company, a nonprofit Children’s Opera Theater at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. As a young artist with the Metropolitan Opera Guild, Rebecca performed Opera Outreach for over 15,000 kindergarten through high school students, sharing her love of opera and has brought this unique model of Opera education to the Ojai Vallley.

Kostis Protopapas was named Artistic Director of Opera Santa Barbara in August 2015.  He made his conducting debut with the company in November 2016, conducting the season’s opening production of Carmen.  The company’s 2016-17 season, the first to be planned entirely by Kostis, also includes two company premieres:  Janacek’s The Cunning Little Vixen, in a new production by Crystal Manich starring Isabel Bayrakdarian, and Puccini’s La Rondine.  

2016 saw the end of Kostis’ long association with Tulsa Opera, where he served as Artistic Director from November 2007 until May 2016, as Interim Executive Director from November 2011 until February 2013 and as Associate Conductor and Chorus Master from 2001 until 2007. During his 15-year tenure with the company, Kostis conducted 30 productions of a diverse repertoire extending from popular classics like La Boheme, Carmen and Cavalleria Rusticana/I Pagliacci to contemporary American works like Elmer Gantry, Of Mice and Men, A Streetcar Named Desire and Barber of Seville.

Born in Athens, Greece, Kostis Protopapas studied Archaeology and History of Art at the University of Athens before coming to the United States in 1993, on an Onassis Foundation scholarship, to study piano at The Boston Conservatory and conducting at Boston University. He became an American citizen in 2011 and splits his time between Chicago and Santa Barbara, with his wife, soprano and stage director Cathleen Dunn-Protopapas, and their four cats, Gus, Miles, Zsa-Zsa and Gigi.

story:
It’s never easy, but it’s always worth it.

Theater is the ultimate collaborative art. A talented cast is already in rehearsals, major dances have been choreographed. Amazing, original music is being composed. Actors are learning to interact with dynamic, sculptural set elements. The amount of creative talent joining forces on this show is astounding and ensures a groundbreaking and inspiring show will result.

Artists deserve to be paid!

3 designers
2 composers
5 actors
1 lighting designer
1 stage manager
1 choreographer
1 producer
1 writer/director
1 dramaturg

=A Whole Lot of Valuable Talent

Each of the artists working on the show will be paid $750. That’s $12,000! Grants from Theatre Bay Area, Puffin Foundation West and The Venturous Fund have raised about $5000 of this fee. We’re asking you to help us make up the rest: $7,000

Perks galore! Check ‘em out!

  • Can’t come to the show, but want an awesome memento? Buy one of the spectacular posters designed by, Kim Anderson. (You can see the full version of the poster at 6NewPlays.com.) You'll receive the poster in the mail so you can be with us in spirit.
  • The best thing about donating at a $35 price or above: you’re also buying your tickets to the show! No double-dipping here! This show will sell out, so by securing your ticket now you make sure you’ll see the hottest show in San Francisco during the election season!
  • Give a little more and we’ll treat you to premium seating. A little more and you get front row parking!
  • Hey, if you really want to help us out, and get some hand-made art, give at the $250 level and Andrea will silk-screen a T-shirt (herself!) with the poster image made by Kim. 
  • Any amount you give will help us reach our goal. Even $5 let’s us know you’re thinking about us and gets us that much closer to making the show happen.

Best of all, your donations are tax deductible! 6NewPlays is fiscally sponsored by Intersection for the Arts, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, which allows us to offer you tax deductions for your contributions. When you donate to our campaign, you’ll receive an acknowledgement letter for tax purposes.

  • Intersection provides resources, community and cultural space in order to contribute to the sustainable practices of artists and arts organizations the San Francisco Bay Area. Intersection is San Francisco's oldest alternative arts space, providing fiscal sponsorship, networking, consulting and presenting opportunities to artists. Visit www.theintersection.org.”

We Open One Week before the Election

It’s incredibly important to us that we bring this show to audiences while the election is happening.  How many of us have felt like we’re in an alternate reality watching the election coverage this year? “dark is a different beast” speaks to so much of what living in times like these is like. Help make timely, relevant theater happen.

  • In 2008, Andrea’s play “best.worst.best” was chosen as one of the top 10 moments in Arts and Entertainment by the “Marin Independent Journal” alongside a Robin Williams’ stand-up routine and a Grateful Dead reunion show. They said about the show, “it promised to take us into the real world of Marin teenagers…and it did.” This show promises to be just as timely and noteworthy.
  • We care about our world. We care about art. We care about creating a future that is based on love and hope. We know you care about those things too. With your help, we’ll be able to bring a whole community of people together around the idea that there is a better way. And we can find it. We can create it.

If You Can’t Donate, We Still Need You!

Thank you for taking the time to learn about our show even though money may be tight or perhaps you are even trying to get your own project off the ground.

If so, we are asking you to help us spread the word about our campaign.

  • We believe others will find our project inspiring. Share our campaign on all your social media pages! You’d be helping us get the word out and reach our goal!
  • Tell all your Bay Area friends to come check us out, and introduce themselves to us! We are happy to continue to grow our community of passionate souls.

We believe others will find our project inspiring. Share our campaign on all your social media pages! You’d be helping us get the word out and reach our goal!
Tell all your Bay Area friends to come check us out, and introduce themselves to us! We are happy to continue to grow our community of passionate souls.

story:
Hola! 

My name is Susana Arenas Pedroso. I am from Havana, Cuba and have lived in the Bay Area since 1998. I am the Director, Choreographer, and Principal Dancer of Arenas Dance Company.  

When I lived in Cuba, I studied with teacher, choreographer, and Cuban cultural treasure, Juan de Dios Ramos, director of  the highly-celebrated dance company, Raices Profundas.  I had the great honor of performing in many of Ramos' choreographies over the years and was a principal dancer with his famed Raices Profundas. 

This year Raices Profundas celebrates its 40th Anniversary. It is very important that I,  a student of Juan de Dios Ramos,  continue his  artistic, cultural, and spiritual legacy. For this reason I am raising money so that my dance company and I can travel to Cuba this Summer  to participate in a historic cultural exchange and artistic collaboration between Raices Profundas and Arenas Dance Company.

We must make this trip this Summer to celebrate the anniversary of one of the most important dance companies in Havana as Juan de Dios Ramos is getting older and his health needs attention.  With renewed relations between Cuba and the Unites States, now is the time to  document the words, the works, and the methods of Ramos in order to preserve his legacy before it is too late. 

For this reason I ask for you support.  We are trying to raise $25,000 to cover the cost of the visas, plane tickets, accommodations, educational workshops, and other expenses so that my company and I can embark on this amazing exchange and document Ramos' work. We are also raising funds  so that we can purchase and bring Ramos some much needed medical supplies.

Thanks you in advance for your support.

Mil gracias,

Susana


(Video by Antonio Ortiz)

story:
River Valley Dance Project (RVDP)
is collaborating with the film team
at Regional Productions to create Evolutions Purpose:
Music & Dance Film Performance.


Linalynn Schmelzer is the Artistic Director of the River Valley Dance Project(RVDP), a modern dance company with a mission to create original dance works that collaborate with other artists.  RVDP's next project is a collaboration of dance, music and film. 

This project is the integration of original choreography by Linalynn Schmelzer and the videography of Regional Productions set to a unique musical interpretation of Ástor Piazzolla's History of the Tango.


In November of 2014, the River Valley Dance Project raised $1,600 to stage Evolutions Purpose at the Deep River Town Hall Historic Theater.  These funds supported the rental of rehearsal space, rental of the theater, lighting design, and wardrobe.  The premiere was a success and RVDP is ready to take it to the next stage.


Our collaboration with Regional Productions is going to be amazing.   We are making a 30-minute film that combines modern music and modern dance.  We are working with film to give viewers an interesting and engaging performance through multiple perspectives that would otherwise be lost. 
                        - Linalynn Schmelzer

Why We Need $5,000

  • High quality film equipment
  • Film production crew
  • Rehearsal and performance space
  • Dancers
  • Lighting design
  • Costumes
  • Musical copyrights
  • Musicians

The Impact

Evolutions Purpose: Music & Dance Film Performance will capture a unique collaboration that contributes engaging and intelligent art to the community.  
This project unites three art forms and a group of artists that are dedicated
to the creative process, creating  an original performance that can be shared
for generations.

  • We have talented artists willing to devote time and energy to this work
  • All of the artists bring years of experience
  • We are driven to create this film because we believe in it's value

Risks & Challenges

Time and money are our two big hurdles:

  • We are determined to make this film.
  • We are organized and prepared to work diligently in the preliminary stages to limit wasting time.
  • We are prepared to work within our budget so that in the end we have the hightiest quality art we can afford to produce.

Other Ways You Can Help

You do not need money to help us achieve our goal.

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools
  • Share this with friends
Thank you in advance for your time and consideration!

story:
My name is Maya Horowitz. I am a senior dance major at Cornish College of the Arts, in Seattle, Washington. I am originally from Chicago, Illinois, but I have been blessed with the opportunity to dance in Seattle, New York, and Israel. I will graduating with a BFA in dance, this May. This summer marks the launching point into the next chapter in my life!

This campaign will go towards the chance to participate in The Movement Invention Project in New York and The Gaga Summer Intensive in Tel Aviv. The Movement Invention Project is a three week intensive. The Gaga Summer Intensive is two weeks long. These two intensives offer amazing teachers, choreographers, and classes that will help me develop artistically, mentally, and physically. It is one of my dreams to settle down in Israel one day and dance there. After spending last summer in Israel, I really fell in love with the culture and dance scene. Over the past two years I have really began to explore improvisation, and I feel that this is something I want to continue to deepen my knowledge about.  I want to absorb as much as I can from these two programs! It would mean the world to me if friends, family, and anyone who is willing to give to this amazing opportunity could pitch in. I would not be able to express my gratitude.
I need about $1,100 for a plane ticket to Israel. The rest of the money will go towards food and transportation in New York and Israel. Even if my entire goal is not reached, every penny helps!

 One of my biggest fears is not knowing what I will do with my life after graduation. By being able to attend both The Movement Invention Project and The Gaga Summer Intensive, I will be able to make lifelong connections with teachers, choreographers, and other dancers attending the programs. Hopefully making these connections will help get me started in the real world. Dance is a beautiful expression, but unfortunately it is expensive.

My savings are slowly growing (I babysit part time for six families while I am in school), but I cannot do this myself!  Every donation is helpful, even if it is small! I will be so delighted with any kind of donation and your support.

Please share this page with anyone who might be interested in it!
story_txt:
My name is Maya Horowitz. I am a senior dance major at Cornish College of the Arts, in Seattle, Washington. I am originally from Chicago, Illinois, but I have been blessed with the opportunity to dance in Seattle, New York, and Israel. I will graduating with a BFA in dance, this May. This summer marks the launching point into the next chapter in my life!
This campaign will go towards the chance to participate in The Movement Invention Project in New York and The Gaga Summer Intensive in Tel Aviv. The Movement Invention Project is a three week intensive. The Gaga Summer Intensive is two weeks long. These two intensives offer amazing teachers, choreographers, and classes that will help me develop artistically, mentally, and physically. It is one of my dreams to settle down in Israel one day and dance there. After spending last summer in Israel, I really fell in love with the culture and dance scene. Over the past two years I have really began to explore improvisation, and I feel that this is something I want to continue to deepen my knowledge about.  I want to absorb as much as I can from these two programs! It would mean the world to me if friends, family, and anyone who is willing to give to this amazing opportunity could pitch in. I would not be able to express my gratitude.I need about $1,100 for a plane ticket to Israel. The rest of the money will go towards food and transportation in New York and Israel. Even if my entire goal is not reached, every penny helps!  One of my biggest fears is not knowing what I will do with my life after graduation. By being able to attend both The Movement Invention Project and The Gaga Summer Intensive, I will be able to make lifelong connections with teachers, choreographers, and other dancers attending the programs. Hopefully making these connections will help get me started in the real world. Dance is a beautiful expression, but unfortunately it is expensive.
My savings are slowly growing (I babysit part time for six families while I am in school), but I cannot do this myself!  Every donation is helpful, even if it is small! I will be so delighted with any kind of donation and your support. 
Please share this page with anyone who might be interested in it!

story:
Looking at A Abroad is a journey to find and make home within myself, to come to terms with my limits, my love and my body as home space. It is part travelogue, part choreo-poem exploring the ways in which borders of country, identity, and race, gender and sexuality divide us from ourselves.

We are at a state in our country and in our world where the rallying cry of #blacklivesmatter #blackwomenslivesmatter #blacktranslivesmatter is being increasingly pushed back against. Extreme amounts of violence, aggression and disenfranchisement face black people everywhere. The conversation about black women's value, our suffering and our uplift is being raised by activists, writers (Claudia Rankine's Citizen) and artists. This piece comes out of this moment. It is a questioning, a reckoning and an engagement with our state, our identities and our bodies.

I can't wait to share this superbly ripe piece but I'll only be able to do so with your support. I'm trying to raise 3,000 to support the costs of space, lighting equipment, sound and media production and design elements to make Looking at A Broad take flight.

So please take some time to donate, share and repost! I can't wait to share this piece with you in November. See you there!

story:
Welcome to North Atlantic Dance Theatre's Scheherazade!!

I am the director of NADT , Lucy. We are asking for your help to get our original production of Scheherazade up and running. Now your probably asking yourself who, what and why, right?

The who:

North Atlantic Dance Theatre (formerly associated with North Atlantic Ballet) is a vibrant Boston based dance company creating  and recreating new and original works. Our collaborations with Dancers, Choreographers, Musicians, Visual Artists and Community keeps our art form fresh; invigorating our audiences with a new experience in the ballet world. We create and recreate innovative performances which inspire audiences to give themselves over to our world for a short time.

check out our WEBSITE

I am the director of the company forming it in 2014 at the demand for more quality ballet in Boston. Formerly a freelance performance artist in and around the Boston area I am excited and eager to show this company's chops off. NADT separates itself from the rest in its originality and integrity within its creations. This company brings a fresh approach to an age old art form. We are intense in our passion for what we love but work in a relaxed environment, usually filled with raucous laughter, with dedicated professionals.

The what:

Our newest  production of Scheherazade is an original work. Unlike the typical staged productions set by companies the world over, we have chosen to focus on the actual arrival of Scheherazade and her journey as a woman overcoming her obstacles.  Based on the stories from 1001 Arabian nights, this production includes an anime prologue by Giorgi Shanidze, live instrumentation, Choreography by me and elaborate costuming by Li-Ann Lim.

                             

This is what we are saying about it:

A mystical tale of passion, betrayal and love’s conquests. Scheherazade’s struggle for her survival depends on her skill in storytelling and keeping the sultan enthralled night after night for A 1001 Arabian Nights. Unlike most staged productions this story begins where most end.  Scheherazade, our heroine, vows to save the lives of all the women in her city from the the vengeful hands of the Sultan, Shahryar. Sheherazade offers up her life in marriage to the sultan in hopes that her story telling will keep her alive long enough to break through the Sultans calloused heart and renew his ability to love once more. Filled with stories of genies, princesses, and the seductive ladies of baghdad. This is an empowering tale of women; their mysteries and willingness to sacrifice for what they believe in.

The why:

This is a story that lasts throughout the ages. A woman's journey is never over and this ballet empowers women in their strength in love, ability for compassion, and forgiveness. Help us tell or rather dance this story!

Your donation can help us put this great ballet together and empower women through the gift of dance. One more small step for women.

This is what we need:

All donations will go towards making this ballet happen and spreading the word.

We need:

$1800 for the Plaza Theatre (fee of $650 + 10%  has already been paid)

$600 for our lighting designer

$1200 for dancers

$500 for the anime artist

Of course there are other costs but these are the ones we need help with the most. We have  a hold on the theater already but as a new company we still need some help.

Stuff you can get for helping out:

  • A personal stage thank you.
  • Receive a signed photo by the company (below) Photo by Zev Hoover

  • Thank you videos with dancers from NADT.
  • A T-shirt with a photo from the company and 2015 season line-up.
  • Attend a rehearsal and give us some input on the creation of the ballet.
  • Join the company for a private dress rehearsal showing with a tour backstage and chat with the dancers and choreographer.

In the case we don't make our goal the funds will be used for later purposes. We will try again but we will most likely have to down-size our production and possibly delay it. Which will stink but we will perform this ballet it is worth the wait if we have too.

Your Impact

Most dance companies rely on supporters such as family, friends and fans. About 70%-80% of a company's budget comes from these supporters. So your donation matters to us. We value and appreciate every penny that comes our way and understand that the quality of what we produce needs to match your dollar.

Without your donation this powerful story stays silent. The story of Scheherazade is about one of the strongest literary female leads in the world.  Her story can be passed down just as other women's stories have been, fictional or not. Scheherazade can be listed among powerful women such as Joan d'Arc, Jane Eyre, Hester Prynne, even Hermione Granger! Help her voice be heard through dance.

Our last performance was raised through Indiegogo also. Thanks to supporters like you we managed to collaborate with a production crew to integrate live video into a production of Vivaldi's Four Seasons. It was a thrilling show and experience for the dancers. It was our premiere performance and a successful one at that.


Our Risks & Challenges

Well mainly if we don't make it now we'll make it later. I'm in this for the long haul and believe that Boston does need this small passionate company. It will take time and patience to build a company from nothing so we expect people to not believe in us until we gain their trust and prove to them that we are truly a great company and are an important part of the Boston dance scene.

Those of our fans whose hearts we have won over, Thank you for taking a chance on us.

    Other Ways You Can Help

     Can't donate but still want to help?

    Spread the word twitter, instagram, facebook, pinterest. Get busy and make some noise!

    Check out the Indiegogo share tools for ease.

    Thanks for taking a chance on us!

story:
Anonymous article in The Blind Man # 2, May 1917. 

Written by Beatrice Wood, H.P. Roché and/or Marcel Duchamp.

The Richard Mutt Case

They say any artist paying six dollars may exhibit.
Mr. Richard Mutt sent in a fountain. Without discussion this article disappeared and was never exhibited.
What were the grounds for refusing Mr. Mutt's fountain:
        1. Some contend it was immoral, vulgar. 
        2. Others, it was plagiarism, a plain piece of plumbing.
Now Mr. Mutt's fountain is not immoral, that is absurd, no more than a bath tub is immoral. It is a fixture that you see every day in plumbers' show windows.
Whether Mr. Mutt with his own hands made the fountain or not has no importance. He CHOSE it. He took an ordinary article of life, placed it so that its useful significance disappeared under a new title and point of view – created a new thought for that object.
As for plumbing, that is absurd. The only works of art America has given are her plumbing and her bridges. 

Founded in 2013 for the production of the film Seep, The R.Mutt Society is a multidisciplinary company based in New York City. Our name and logo comes from Duchamp’s ‘Fountain.’ As the renowned scholar Martin Esslin says in his landmark work The Theatre of the Absurd: “We believe that every work of art must be a statement. It must be a statement addressed in the first person singular to the first person plural, and the latter must retain the right to dissent.” 

You can read or mission here

The Play

The first scenes were drafted by Ionesco after trying to learn English from the Assimil method called English Without Toil. In the ready- made phrases aligned one after the other he saw an inconsistency in language which became the inspiration for his play. From the beginning, this admirer of Lewis Carroll and other surrealists, knew he wanted to make his play a parody of theatre. 


The Impact

What Ionesco called ‘The Tragedy of Language’ more than half a century ago is still relevant today. The abuse of language through vast quantities of information, the impossibility to process the infinite number of messages thrown to us by the ‘society of information’. Social Media, express journalism (The Huffington Post model of cheap and quick news) makes it even more difficult to separate what piece of information is important and what’s not. At the same time, today’s instant messaging and other ‘communication’ tools connect us with practically everyone around the globe instantly and all this 'progress' has not yet solved the most basic human problem: We still can't understand each other.

This is why we think this play must be presented again, with energy and passion, to as much people as possible.

“The play is an attack against what Ionesco has called the universal petty- bourgeoisie ...the personification of accepted ideas and slogans, the ubiquitous conformist.The acceptance of ready-made ideas by the masses turn our societies into collections of centrally directed automata”

―Martin Esslin.The Theatre of the Absurd. 

By supporting our project you are making a strong statement. A different Theater is possible.


What We Need & What You Get

Here is what your money will be going towards:

  • Performance Space
  • Rehearsal Space 
  • Costumes (designed by Miwa Ishii)
  • Advertising and promotional materials
  • Buy the rights 
The R.Mutt Society divides it's benefits from the Box-Office equally after every performance. The team (cast and crew) get 70% of the total and the company keeps the rest for future projects. 
We will publish a relation of every dollar spent on this production at the end of the run on our website (www.rmuttsociety.com). To show our appreciation of your generosity, we will be offering some great perks, including: show tickets, an original poster signed by the cast, digital copy of Seep (R.Mutt Society’s latest short-film), a video of a bedtime story of your choosing read by a member of the cast, a golf lesson with PGA Professional Golfer and actor John Anhony Gorman and many more.

The Team

  • Directed by Guillermo Logar
  • Production Manager: Charles Furst
  • Costume Designer: Miwa Ishii
  • Poster by Paul Zdon

The Cast

  • Mr. Smith: Peter Wallace
  • Mrs. Smith: Nanda Valencia
  • Mary: Charlie Gillette
  • Mr.Martin: Jacob Rico
  • Mrs.Smith: Kat Erasmus
  • Fire Chief: Xavier Galva

The Visuals

Take a look at Miwa Ishii's costume designs here

The Tour

Be te first to know the venues and dates for the play by signing up here

Other Ways You Can Help

No amount is too small, but we know that making a donation is not possible for everyone. You can still be a huge help to us by simply spreading the word about our campaign and sharing our project with your friends, family and contacts. You can use the IndieGoGo share tools to make this easier. And check out our website to learn more about us

www.rmuttsociety.com

You can also follow us on Facebook and Twitter. Thank you very much.

If you want to partner up with us please get in touch here info@rmuttsociety.com and join our Support Community.

You can use the IndieGoGo share tools to make this easier. And check out our website to learn more about us

story:
Eight.

 

This is Indy Convergence's eighth year in Indianapolis. We can't believe how time has flown by. In 2008, we were just excited that people showed up to our first Open Lab, now we're working with a community center in Haiti, collaborating with York University in Toronto and proud to be a part of a thriving and growing arts scene in Indianapolis, Indiana (we'd like to think that we've helped it along!). 

None of this is possible without the continued support of generous individuals (like you) who believe that sharing art is better than keeping it inside our brains, houses, rehearsal rooms or desk drawers. Sarah Moon, a 2012 participant said it best, "Indy Convergence is a great big exercise in Dream it. Make it".  Your support keeps us dreaming. Thank you.

But what do we actually do?

Indy Convergence is a non-profit arts organization that hosts pop-up artist residencies in Indianapolis, at York University and at the Sa-K-La-K-Wel Community center in Oban, Haiti. 

Indy Convergence provides opportunity to artists getting their ideas off the ground. We provide space, material and human resources for artists to work on projects they've been imagining, but haven't had the time or space to explore.  In past years we've had scripts read aloud for the first time, choreographers finally put a missing section into a larger piece of work, puppeteers create that huge puppet they've always wanted to try making. 

Indy Convergence provides opportunities for artists to share and learn. Each participating artist teaches a class that is open to the community for free or trade. Being an artist isn't just about creating, but also the ability to talk about your art work and share it with your community.

Indy Convergence provides opportunities for collaboration. We bring together artists from all over (primarily North America), in all disciplines, of all types. We provide new eyes and ways of understanding for the artists who've come to work... but having other artists work with them. 

Indy Convergence provides a challenging work environment. We push the artists that join us, and they push each other, to do more and go farther with their ideas than they ever though possible. 

Thank you for providing these opportunities for artists at Indy Convergence. 

Where does your donation go?

SPACE

We require a large space to host movement workshops, build sets and props, write, and hold daily meetings. For the first time, we're renting TWO spaces in Fountain Square (a vibrant, up and coming arts neighborhood in Indy) to provide adequate space for our participating artists. But, this also means that rental costs are rising significantly from $1,500 to $2,500 .  The good news is that our rental fees are going to other great people and organizations: The University of Indianapolis and Grove Haus.

MATERIALS

We provide all of our participating artists with the supplies they need to take their work to the next level. That can be printed scripts, puppet building materials, a special lighting instrument or lumber for a large prop. We also require materials to support our community workshops. On average we host 9 workshops that cost us $100 each. Artists are creative, resourceful and inventive. However, sometimes you just need that "thing" to make the magic happen. This year, we'll also need specialty lighting instruments for this year's Umbrella Project (led by our incredible designer and do-it-all man Ian Garrett).

PEOPLE

Indy Convergence is a small organization that relies on volunteer hours from the staff and everyone involved to support our website management, marketing, design, housing and transportation. This year we are committed to providing our staff and interns from York University with a small stipend,  and covering fuel costs for all the volunteers who drive participants from their housing to our rehearsal spaces. 

STORAGE AND TRANSPORTATION

We have a medium sized storage unit that holds all of our supplies including dissembled sets, yoga mats, dance shoes, lighting instruments the all important coffee maker and much more. Every year we rent a truck to bring all of this to the theater so our participants can use whatever they need to create.  This year we will have rent one twice because we are moving spaces midway through our Indianapolis residency. 

Can't donate? Still want to help?

We understand if making a monetary contribution isn't possible for everyone. But you'd still like to help? Never fear! there are many ways you can support Indy Convergence without making a donation. The easiest way is to share this campaign with your friends and colleagues. We also need volunteers to help with loading into our rehearsal spaces (Monday May 18 and Wednesday May 27), house artists in Indianapolis and Toronto, help  with carpooling, and assist with getting the word out about workshops and open labs.

If you would like to volunteer with Indy Convergence email caitlin@indyconvergence.org today!

Indy Convergence is a non-profit arts organization that hosts pop-up artist residencies in Indianapolis, at York University and at the Sa-K-La-K-Wel Community center in Oban, Haiti. 
Indy Convergence provides opportunity to artists getting their ideas off the ground. We provide space, material and human resources for artists to work on projects they've been imagining, but haven't had the time or space to explore.  In past years we've had scripts read aloud for the first time, choreographers finally put a missing section into a larger piece of work, puppeteers create that huge puppet they've always wanted to try making. 
Indy Convergence provides opportunities for artists to share and learn. Each participating artist teaches a class that is open to the community for free or trade. Being an artist isn't just about creating, but also the ability to talk about your art work and share it with your community.
Indy Convergence provides opportunities for collaboration. We bring together artists from all over (primarily North America), in all disciplines, of all types. We provide new eyes and ways of understanding for the artists who've come to work... but having other artists work with them. 
Indy Convergence provides a challenging work environment. We push the artists that join us, and they push each other, to do more and go farther with their ideas than they ever though possible. 
Thank you for providing these opportunities for artists at Indy Convergence.    Where does your donation go?
SPACE
We require a large space to host movement workshops, build sets and props, write, and hold daily meetings. For the first time, we're renting TWO spaces in Fountain Square (a vibrant, up and coming arts neighborhood in Indy) to provide adequate space for our participating artists. But, this also means that rental costs are rising significantly from $1,500 to $2,500 .  The good news is that our rental fees are going to other great people and organizations: The University of Indianapolis and Grove Haus. 
MATERIALS
We provide all of our participating artists with the supplies they need to take their work to the next level. That can be printed scripts, puppet building materials, a special lighting instrument or lumber for a large prop. We also require materials to support our community workshops. On average we host 9 workshops that cost us $100 each. Artists are creative, resourceful and inventive. However, sometimes you just need that "thing" to make the magic happen. This year, we'll also need specialty lighting instruments for this year's Umbrella Project (led by our incredible designer and do-it-all man Ian Garrett).
PEOPLE
Indy Convergence is a small organization that relies on volunteer hours from the staff and everyone involved to support our website management, marketing, design, housing and transportation. This year we are committed to providing our staff and interns from York University with a small stipend,  and covering fuel costs for all the volunteers who drive participants from their housing to our rehearsal spaces. 
STORAGE AND TRANSPORTATION
We have a medium sized storage unit that holds all of our supplies including dissembled sets, yoga mats, dance shoes, lighting instruments the all important coffee maker and much more. Every year we rent a truck to bring all of this to the theater so our participants can use whatever they need to create.  This year we will have rent one twice because we are moving spaces midway through our Indianapolis residency. 
  Can't donate? Still want to help? We understand if making a monetary contribution isn't possible for everyone. But you'd still like to help? Never fear! there are many ways you can support Indy Convergence without making a donation. The easiest way is to share this campaign with your friends and colleagues. We also need volunteers to help with loading into our rehearsal spaces (Monday May 18 and Wednesday May 27), house artists in Indianapolis and Toronto, help  with carpooling, and assist with getting the word out about workshops and open labs.
If you would like to volunteer with Indy Convergence email caitlin@indyconvergence.org today!

story:
GLOW Lyric Theatre Summer Festival Season

"A Season of New Perspectives" - that is the subtitle for GLOW Lyric Theatre's fantastic Summer Festival Season of THE WIZ and THE HOT MIKADO, July 9-19 at Greenville's Peace Center for the Performing Arts.  

  • GLOW Lyric Theatre is South Carolina's ONLY professional lyric theater that produces musical theatre, operetta and opera. 
  • We present art with a heart.  GLOW does more than produce entertainment - our shows excite and enlighten.  Our productions ask the hard questions about the current social issues of our state, and your support helps strengthen the voices in our community.  GLOW gives back! 
  • We want to play our part in making Greenville a more caring, diverse, and vibrant community.  The arts are the true backbone of any great culture. Lyric Theatre is a great and accessible way to get people to think and feel!  
  • The Wiz and The Hot Mikado are both shows that reimagine traditional stories, but from a predominantly African American perspective.  The Wiz is an adaptation of Frank Baum's The Wizard of Oz, and The Hot Mikado is an adaptation of Gilbert & Sullivan's English operetta, The Mikado.

Fight for our Rights!

Yes, the cost for the rights to perform these two shows are quite high!

  • GLOW has already had to spend over $10,000 from it's operating budget to obtain the rights to these two shows.  
  • Your generous donation with entitle you to several levels of perks, ranging from a signed poster, complimentary tickets to the shows, to a private patron party with the cast!
  • Every little bit helps!  GLOW has always prided itself on being a truly grass-roots company - started with a mere $700 production just five years ago!

What this means for GLOW

What you give goes directly to what you see on stage.

  • Licensing agencies make all organizations pay ALL fees upfront, before production begins.  
  • This has the negative effect of reducing operating capital at the time a performing arts organization most needs it:  production time.
  • This year, GLOW is attempting to engage a very specific audience: those who don't go to the theatre.  There are many who simply cannot afford a night out at the theatre, or even if they did (and most importantly), might not see stories to which they can relate. 
  • GLOW is hoping to provide hundreds of free and subsidized tickets through several organizations that engage underserved and marginalized populations in the Upstate. 
  • None of this can happen for free, so please help GLOW fund their rights, and ensure the rights of all residents of SC to be able to go to the theatre this summer!

Our Risks & Challenges

It don't come easy!

  • With rapid growth (GLOW has grown some 600% in the last five years), comes growing pain. 
  • Relying on ticket sales and grants to survive is difficult.  We need the support of folks just like you to allow GLOW to produce professional and socially conscious lyric theatre.  
  • It is always our intention to retain the grass-roots feel, but to expand as needed in order to create the highest quality and most engaging art possible.  
  • Our hope is to continue to engage with Upstate community and seek out those people and business that believe in GLOW’s mission. 
  • GLOW has never run a deficit.  Help us keep it that way!

Other Ways You Can Help

GLOW has a long list of fantastic patrons that help with time, and in-kind donations and services.

  • Check out the "Support Us" tab on our website to find other ways to help GLOW grow:  http://www.glowlyric.com/support-us/
  • Heck, Tell Your Friends!!  :)  The more people that know about GLOW's top shelf productions and mission, the more better!

story:
Our story

Loka Art Studio is a dance school founded by Scholastica W. Pribadi, a young indonesian dancer and choreographer that works to preserve and teach Indonesian Art Dance Traditions. Scholastica with Loka Art Studio aims to teach young kids from rural and low-income areas to love and learn traditional dances. She counts with the artist support of many professional dancers that perform in festivals and championships in Indonesia.

To learn more about Scholastica W. Pribadi work, you can look at the facebook page https://www.facebook.com/Lokaartstudio or also watch this touching video of her recent visit to Klayili Village kids in West Papua Island:

What we need

Loka Art Studio has received an invitation to perform at prestigious Sibu International Dance Festival in Malaysia and needs your help to pay for plane tickets for 16 dancers, accommodation and costumes.

This festival represents a big opportunity to promote Indonesian culture and Loka Art Studio work, since it is an international gathering for world class artist to show their great talent and performance in a form of exchange of inspirational idea, movement exploration, seminar, and performances.

What you get

Loka Art Studio is cooperating with Batik Kebon Indah, a local NGO  of Batik Art from Java Island, Indonesia. Batik Kebon Indah is producing the precious scarfs and fabrics we are offering as perks for this crowdfunding. and part of the fundings collected will go to help reconstruct after the heartquake. To learn more about Batik Kebon Indah you can watch this video


The batik is an ancient artisan technique of wax-resistdyeing with natural dyes colours. Indonesian batik made in the island of Java has a long history of acculturation, and is the most developed in terms of pattern, technique, and the quality of workmanship. On October 2009,UNESCO designated Indonesian batik as a Masterpiece of Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity. Learn more about batik technique in this english subtitled video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4H2uuDfRmek

Other ways you could help

Would you please help us spread the word about our campaign? You can share our cause with others through the share tools (Facebook, Twitter, etc.) provided. The more people that know about us the better our chance to go to Sibu International Dance Festival in Malaysia. Thank you so much for your support!

Perks

Dance Video Tutorial

Dance Video Tutorial (Balinese or Javanese dance at your choice)

Lesson of Indonesian Dances

Online Private Lesson of Indonesian Dances by Scholastica w Pribadi


Handmade Wooden necklace

Indonesian Handmade Wooden necklace

Indonesian Lurik Scarf

Indonesian Lurik Traditional Scarf (200x110cm) made by local NGO Batik Kebon Indah

Indonesia Handmade Batik Scarf

Indonesian Handmade Batik Scarf (250mx53cm) in 2 colors (1 month process made by local NGO Batik Kebon Indah)

Printed and Hand Made Batik fabric

Indonesian Printed and Hand Made Batik Fabric (250mx53cm) in 2-3 colors (2 month process made by local NGO Batik Kebon Indah)

Indonesian Hand Made Batik

Indonesian Fully Hand Made Batik Fabric (250mx53cm) in 2-3 colors (3 month process made by local NGO Batik Kebon Indah)

Personalized Video + Indonesian Hand Made Batik

- Personalized video with Dance and Thank You by Loka Art Dancers.

- Indonesian Fully Hand Made Batik Fabric (250mx53cm) in 2-3 colors (3 month process made by local NGO Batik Kebon Indah)


Thank you for helping make Loka Art Studio's dreams come true!!

story:
Short Summary

I'm Daniel Llewelyn-Williams. I come from a long line of dockers and policemen in the industrial port town of Newport... and I'm an actor.. and a writer. I have a passion to make theatre that's accessible to a non theatre audience but not necessarily by writing solely for any one group or celebrating popular culture just to get "down with the kids". I have a passion for local history and for acknowledging the less glamorous human stories of tenacity and compassion which become lost when we cease to immortalise them in story and song.
I need support to realise my ambitions for my stage play, A Regular Little Houdini, to put it in front of an audience in Hollywood and across California to charm them with the story of a working class Edwardian boy who defies his destiny and, despite his desperate surroundings, maintains his positivity and the lustre of his burning desire to break the mould and become a stage magician, despite the industrial grind which consumes every one around him. 
When we booked this showcase tour of USA and UK, we had funding in place which since, has sadly fallen through. We are seeking crowd funding to ensure the American tour is a success. Our mission is to put this play in front of people who could help realise our dream of turning this successful stage show into a successful feature film, immortalising the human themes in the piece and the lesser known history of a former industrial town which, for two generations has bred despondency and a lack of ambition in it's youth.


What We Need & What You Get.

In lieu of our lost funding, we aim to raise at least £2000 to augment the marketing and advertising budget (a crucial factor in pulling crowds for theatre) whilst touring America and Edinburgh Fringe, affording us the opportunity to promote this show to an audience of influential people. We are taking the show to the Hollywood Fringe Festival, the San Diego Fringe Festival and the Headwaters Theatre in Oregon, and then we take it to the Pleasance at the Edinburgh Fringe. Fliers, posters, online ads, sponsored editorials, interviews, reviews, advertising in local and national publications, radio slots. The more support we have, the more we can commit to marketing and the more we will get back in terms of exposure to audience and to professional parties.

There are a range of perks, stretching from, "your name in the book", the published script, as a supporter of the cause; signed programs; a weekend  away for 2 in a luxury 2 bed flat and a guided tour of the Newport Transporter bridge and the landmarks within the show by the writer; "named character"; your name immortalised in the script as a secondary character. Please see the "perks section" for more options.
If we don't reach our goal, what money which has been kindly pledged will be used to great effect in the sliding scale of the marketing beast. This is a hungry monster and will consume everything you put into it... but... the more we put in, the more positive the effect on the audience figures. Anything we put into this fund will be better than nothing. We are hoping for £2000 but a figure less than that will be gratefully received and considerately utilised.

The Impact

To make this story an international success would have social repercussions on the disenfranchised generation within Newport, the subject of the play, by making their history, the story of the very land on which they stand, relevant in a wider world; the consequences of which, we hope, would inspire young people, like my son and daughter, who have grown up in what they might perceive as a "no hope dive", to believe that positive futures can be made in a post-industrial environment, where jobs are like gold-dust; that pride in, and knowledge of, one's very history is what makes us who we are; that we are the result of millions of generations of success stories, and that natural selection has deemed us "all" to be relevant. 
I create theatre about human issues, about the human condition, about what it is to struggle and still to thrive in this short life and yet to care. 
I've won several awards and am an associate of Theatr Clwyd. I am currently developing a new script about the Chartist uprising of 1839 called "The Chartists and the Lament of George Shell". Please check out my theatre company website www.flyingbridgetheatre.co.uk

Risks & Challenges

The risk is that we take this show to Hollywood, to San Diego, to Edinburgh and beyond and for all the effort and expense of touring a show internationally, we fall at the last hurdle and fail to commit a satisfactory marketing budget. The worst that could happen is that nobody comes to see the show after going to all the effort of touring it over 7000 miles.

Our challenge is to overcome this, by firstly raising a marketing budget from nothing. Secondly to be economical and practical with our marketing opportunities. We will dress in costume, hawk our wares to any radio station, shopping centre, museum, or any other gathering place. We are theatre creatives, we are creative in out thinking for this.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please join our social media pages, share them, and our show website with your friends and colleagues.

www.facebook.com/regularlittlehoudini
twitter handle; broadsworddan@hotmail.com
www.aregularlittlehoudini.co.uk
Please read up about the show and the tour on the website. Let your friends know about this amazing new show and tell them its a must see.

Please use the indiegogo share tools.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Turban'd - The Musical

Turban'd is a one of a kind, original musical that centres around the character 'Kewal Singh'. Kewal is a sikh boy with big dreams of making it big in Bollywood. The musical talks about his journey in tinsel town, the changes, the rejections, the struggles, little victories, dance, drama, love... all this and much more!

The idea behind the project is to address the stereotypes that society has formed. Where talent, passion, experience, knowledge and hard work should decide your future, sometimes things like color, religion and aesthetics play a bigger role. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Since I aim to first produce the musical in Delhi, and then tour around the world, we have put the expected funds to be $20,000.
  • A lot goes into making a musical, starting from paying the artists to booking a venue where everyone would like to come watch us perform, technical support, music, sets, costumes, etc. Like I said... a lot. And I don't want to hold back on any aspect.

The Impact

  • Turban'd - The Musical, is an attempt to make a difference and make society realise, superficial things can't decide what opportunities will knock on your door. 
  • Many of you have come seen the magic me and my team has created on stage. The difference is, this musical has been my dream for the last two years and after much research and my time working on the script, I feel it is time to finally turn my dreams into reality.
  • Your love and support means the world to me.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • I request once again, please get the word out and make some noise, your support means more to me. Please don't hesitate to share and spread the word about Turban'd, to friends and family. All your help & support is much appreciated. 
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
