story:
My name is Lorraine Chapman and along with Joan Talarico-Brodsky we are thrilled to introduce to you the Shaker Dance Revival Project. I am the Resident DanceMaker and Joan is the Dance Revivalist of this new strategic program at Canterbury Shaker Village. The SDRP honors Shaker dance while rethinking tradition for contemporary audiences and dancers. Both Joan and I share a passion for movement commensurable with the Shakers. Like the Shakers we believe that movement connects both dancers and non-dancers to an essential aspect of what makes us human.

My background in dance spans 42 years of training, commitment, dedication, performing, teaching and creating. The dance world is where I chose to reside many years ago. It is my home and movement is my faith. When I dance I understand my purpose and I feel that things are harmoniously in order. The power of moving tunes me into the simplicity of the present moment and the simplicity of moving tunes me into the power of the present moment. It is in these ways that I understand the Shaker way of life. 

For Joan dance has always been a part of her life. The impulse to move to music was there from the very beginning. From childhood on, dancing has been a need and one that she built into a career as a teacher, performer and finally, a movement therapist. She believes that dance is intrinsic to all world cultures because it's innate to the human condition and creates a universal language.  The Shakers also had a need to express themselves through dance which was the foundation of their community worship. 

The SDRP was birthed from Joan's desire to bring dance back to Canterbury Shaker Village. In her search for an artistic programmer, she discovered me and with the Village's Executive Director Funi Burdick's blessing we have been going non-stop since December 2015! 

For our first endeavor we coordinated and organized the SDRP's inaugural summer dance intensive which took place in the Village's iconic Meeting House on both June 22-24 and June 27-29 with our first artists residencies on June 25 & 26. We had a total of 24 enthusiastic and talented participants that were a joy to work with, and 19 of New England's most preeminent, knowledgeable and inspiring dance educators teaching their classes. The Meeting House had not experienced dancing inside of it's walls, erected in 1792, for close to 100 years. The significance of dancing inside these walls again was palpable, with a few people even experiencing "chills". The participants took contemporary technique classes in a variety of dance styles including ballet, jazz, modern, post modern, Pilates, Yoga, dance making, partnering, core strength & deep release, free writing & improvisation, hip-hop, Isadora Duncan technique, classical ballet variations, and the repertory of Skybetter & Associates and Prometheus Dance.  

"It was an honor and so much fun to teach the first dance class in the CSV Meeting House.  What a wonderful experience to see our students reflecting the spirit of the Shakers.  I would love to see this program grow so that others can experience this unparalleled location and opportunities to dance, to connect with other dancers and artists, and to experience the healing aspects of movement." - Danielle Zecker-Hannon, MA, DTR, (Integrated Pilates, Modern/Contemporary & Yoga Class)

Next on the SDRP agenda, we curated and produced our inaugural performances! On August 5th, we presented "RELEASED" which featured works by outstanding choreographers including the premiere of a new collaborative work inspired by original Shaker dances. This original piece, co-created by choreographers David Parker, a Guggenheim Fellow, and myself, a Dance Magazine “25 To Watch,” was performed by our award-winning companies The Bang Group and LCTC.

“RELEASED” also featured works by the ineffable Diane Arvanites; Boston treasure Marcus Schulkind; and Doppelgänger Dance Collective–comprised of Shura Baryshnikov and Danielle Davidson–who performed a duet titled “The Two Body Problem” by internationally known technologist, choreographer, and writer Sydney Skybetter. The program concluded with an excerpt from “Brilliant Being,” a devised work using dance and technology evolving synchronously through collaboration with a team of artists/faculty members from the Music, Theatre, and Dance Departments at Plymouth State University, including NH-based choreographer Amanda Whitworth of Tributary Dance NH; projection mapper, scenographer, and technologist Matt Kizer; playwrite Paul Mroczka and composer Jonathan Santore.

On August 6th as part of Village Rising - A day of exploration, inspiration and creativity - was ”RISING & ROTATING,” performances by emerging companies, choreographers and student groups as well as established dance artists including Sarah Duclos/Neoteric Dance Collaborative, Mariah Rasmussen, Grant Jacoby, Amanda Hinchey, Jessica Howard, Emily Jerant-Hendrickson, Wisty Andres, Shriya Srinivasan, Julien Heller, and Ballet Misha. “RISING & ROTATING” will include “Hearth” a film and dance installation by Emily Beattie in the North Shop. Hearth is an immersive installation that uses black and white film and dance to invoke the creative spirit in daily tasks.

Organized and expressive movement is deeply rooted in our rich, cultural past and is such an integral part of our humanity. We will be (and are already) creating a thriving dance environment at the Village which will reinvigorate the Shaker tradition of dance through:

1.Performance – creation and presentation of inter&multi disciplinary, professional and pre-professional works featuring both established choreographers and dance companies and emerging choreographers and student groups 

2.Dance education – summer dance intensive for pre-professional dancers and individual classes, workshops, community involvement and out-reach activities for all levels, ages and abilities

3.Therapeutic movement - Whole Person Pilates, Biosomatics and Core Health, and coming soon - PD / Parkinson’s Dance

4.Audience building and appreciation – experiential workshops, talks, conversations, video presentations, live demonstrations and lectures about the art of dance, movement and physical expression as well as both pre&post performance introductions and Q&A’s 

Joan and I believe that dance can once again secure a renewed contemporary community at Canterbury Shaker Village. We are also hoping that the SDRP will increase visitors, memberships and funding opportunities for the Village. There is a significance that Canterbury Shaker Village holds for visitors beyond dance. The Village offers all of us a rare glimpse into a completely intact living commonality. The Shakers embodied a way of life that valued service to something higher than themselves. Simplicity and peace bred ingenuity, entrepreneurial excellence, equality and enormous kindness. The Shakers exhibited a rare breed of decency and respect for all and stewarded the land with care. The SDRP is striving to invigorate a robust dance environment in New Hampshire and to expose and inspire the general public to a utopian lifestyle from which our contemporary life has much to learn.

This crowd sourcing campaign is a request for your support.

The funds gifted to this specific Indiegogo campaign (encompassing our 2016 SDRP events) will go towards:

  • dance faculty salaries
  • administrative and operational support
  • choreographers fees
  • performers salaries 
  • lighting, sound, and technical crew
  • the Boston Dance Alliance portable dance floor rental
  • costume design and construction 
  • studio rental for rehearsals 
  • the Marley floor rental for the Meeting House
  • ballet barre construction
  • gas reimbursement and travel expenses 
  • overnight housing and
  • rental for chairs for our audience on August 5th & 6th 
If you are interested in a more detailed break-down of this budget, funding a particular category, or matching a particular gift please do not hesitate to contact either Joan (thestudio.joan@gmail.com) or myself (info@lorrainechapman.org).
The magnitude of your support will be immeasurable! It will ensure the continuation of the Shaker Dance Revival Project! Reaching our entire goal of $10,000 will enable us to continue with this truly unique, exceptional and ground-breaking dance-arts and healing through movement program. The impact of your support will be felt, honored and appreciated for years to come! Please help us reach or exceed our goal!
MORE INFORMATION!
Shaker Dance Revival Project:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/949419301840476/
Canterbury Shaker Village:  http://www.shakers.org
LCTC:  http://lorrainechapman.org

My name is Lorraine Chapman and along with Joan Talarico-Brodsky we are thrilled to introduce to you the Shaker Dance Revival Project. I am the Resident DanceMaker and Joan is the Dance Revivalist of this new strategic program at Canterbury Shaker Village. The SDRP honors Shaker dance while rethinking tradition for contemporary audiences and dancers. Both Joan and I share a passion for movement commensurable with the Shakers. Like the Shakers we believe that movement connects both dancers and non-dancers to an essential aspect of what makes us human.
My background in dance spans 42 years of training, commitment, dedication, performing, teaching and creating. The dance world is where I chose to reside many years ago. It is my home and movement is my faith. When I dance I understand my purpose and I feel that things are harmoniously in order. The power of moving tunes me into the simplicity of the present moment and the simplicity of moving tunes me into the power of the present moment. It is in these ways that I understand the Shaker way of life.

story:
About Bravo

The ethos at Bravo Theatre Company is “opportunity for all” - in practice, this means that we are willing to take risks on inexperienced performers and with new writing as well as engaging more experienced actors and tackling established productions. We always look at the potential in someone when they audition for us. We aim to raise the standards of local theatre and strive to present quality productions in a welcoming, supportive and friendly environment.

About All That Glitters

This drama focuses on the personal rather than the political, set as it is against the backdrop and turmoil of the First World War and the Russian Revolution. We see the close, passionate but at times turbulent relationship between Tsar Nicholas II and his wife Alexandra; here was a man thrust into the spotlight much earlier than he had anticipated, ill prepared for such a role.

We witness the very different personalities of the four daughters, the longed for heir to the throne and his life threatening medical condition. Despite their privileged position, the children were raised modestly and learned to appreciate how ordinary Russians lived. This play details their lives (as seen by outsiders) in a 'gilded cage'. “All That Glitters” is a significant piece of 20th century history retold for a modern audience.

Please note that the production is planned to be performed in early 2017, subject to final confirmation on performance venues and dates. We hope to provide these details before this campaign ends in early September. Full information will be placed on the Bravo website, Facebook pages and Twitter feed.

What We Need & What You Get

The overall target of £750 will help to fund:

  • Hiring the right venue to host this world premiere production (around £650)
  • Costumes (approximately £250)
  • Appropriate items to give an authentic feel to the play (£100)

Bravo will cover any shortfall through ticket and merchandise revenue.

There will be an official DVD made of the production; a copy of this will be given to all contributors unable to attend but are willing to donate £20 or more.

For those donors who are able to attend a performance, up to 4 free tickets and a copy of the programme will be offered as shown below:

  • £20 – 1 free ticket and 1 programme
  • £35 – 2 free tickets and 2 programmes
  • £60 – 4 free tickets and 4 programmes (plus a mention on our website, if agreed; we will not publish any details without a donor's permission)

The Impact

All of Bravo Theatre Company's productions are prepared on a “profit share” basis-the net proceeds after all costs have been deducted from the ticket sale are divided with the company taking a percentage and the rest is shared between the actors and creative technicians. Any money raised in this campaign will mean that those costs are reduced and will lead to the shares being larger.

We are attempting to support local actors and technicians by providing them with opportunities to work; as a consequence of the profit share arrangements, anyone involved can also claim this as a professional credit for their CV or online profiles.

The first 4 productions we have delivered to date have made some sort of profit and this has helped us keep going and growing!

There is considerable educational value in this drama and should it prove successful, we may look at presenting it in some schools in the future.

Risks & Challenges

As this play is a historical piece and is based on real events, it is vitally important that it is as authentic as possible, so the costumes and props used must be convincing; any financial contributions you are able to make will go a long way to help us deliver a quality production.

Auditions are being held and a strong cast of performers is being brought together; actors playing real life people is quite a challenge, so it is vital to have the right mix of personnel involved. To this end, a directorial triumvirate has been formed which will work very closely with the cast to ensure a high quality and convincing artistic product.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can monetarily contribute to this project; however, there are other ways you can help.

Full details of the production will be found on the official Bravo website:

http://www.bravotc.uk/nextproduction.html

You can join the public Facebook group for Bravo:

https://www.facebook.com/groups/bravotc/

You can also follow the company or the play on Twitter:

  • @BravoTCUK
  • @ATGRomanovs

story:
So Who Are We?

We are  Lost Girls Theatre. A 501(c)(3) Non-Profit founded in 2012 by director Katie Siegel and playwright Andie Arthur, our mission is to create theatre infused with a sense of wonder. 

Through highly visual acts of storytelling we seek to combine the mundane with the magical to shed new light on modern concerns through the lens of classical themes and pop culture. We strive to bring the excitement of unique and original theatrical performances to audiences both young and young at heart. Also general geekery and fun, because meaningful and fun should always go hand in hand!

"Juliet Among the Changelings" is a very special project to our company as it is our first full length feature production. The script, design, and performance elements of this show are the result of four years of continuous creator work and community building for our company, and we couldn't be more excited to share it with you.

By joining our Indiegogo campaign you're becoming part of our family of playwrights, directors, designers, actors, and all around awesome people. Your donations will go to helping us improve the scope and quality of our show by increasing our access to the resources we'll need to bring truly unique and beautifully realized stage visions to life.

Give A Little, Get A Lot

With this campaign we're working to raise an additional $7,000.00 to increase the artistic experience of our current "Juliet Among the Changelings" production, which opens on August 12th, 2016. We have already received grants from the Miami Dade County Department of Cultural Affairs and the Coral Gables Foundation, and through their generosity we're making sure our cast and crew receive the compensation they more than deserve. Your contributions will go directly to helping us execute beautiful set, lighting, and sound design. All culminating in a theatrical experience unlike anything you've experienced before. Not to give too much away, but...okay, just a hint... PUPPETS!

Lost Girls is a theatre of personality and fun, and as such we've created a collection of unique perks named for the famous changelings of classical and pop culture. Whether you consider yourself more of an elegant Titania, a loyal Dobby, or an ever optimistic Abby, check out our perks section to see what you can expect in exchange for your contribution. Every contribution you make is tax deductible, and every donation means the world to us. There is no donation too small!

So what happens if we don't meet our $7,000.00 goal? Good question. As this is a flexible funding campaign and we are a 501(c)(3) Non-Profit organization, all of your donations will come to Lost Girls Theatre. Every penny will go either to improving the artistic quality of "Juliet Among the Changelings" or aiding the Lost Girls team in our mission to develop future projects that seek to expand both the content and visual language necessary for theatre to reach new, diverse audiences for years to come.

Looking to the Future

Theatre is, at its heart, about creating a community. This is Lost Girls' first full production, but we've already been hard at work creating a space where those who think of themselves as artists and non-artists alike can share unique ideas, content, and design. For the past two years we've been hosting the "Getting Lost" play reading series at South Miami's Deering Estate to give playwrights from diverse backgrounds with new, creative approaches a platform to show and get feedback on their work. 

Our company is made up of a diverse mix of people and personalities, and we know that every member of the Lost Girls community brings valuable insights and ideas. As we grow, our goal is to reach out beyond the scope of just theatrical production into community education and development. Exposing theatre to audiences that may currently find themselves under represented or under served, and building the theatre patrons of tomorrow.

But it all starts here. With your help our vision for "Juliet Among the Changelings" can get the support it needs to be produced to it's fullest potential. Come join our Lost Girls family and help us create the future of American theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help out, but a little tight on funds? That's alright! We want you as part of the team in whatever way works for you.

Help us get the word out by sharing our Indiegogo campaign with your family, friends, even your arch nemesis, Gerald. Just use our share tools at the top of the page.

Keep yourself in the loop! Join our mailing list or buy performance tickets at the Lost Girls Theatre website. Follow us on Instagram or Twitter, or like us on Facebook. Remember that the more posts you like, tweets you share, and pictures you comment on, the more opportunity your community has to learn about "Juliet Among the Changelings." 

Let us share a little of our magic with you. Join the campaign and find out what Lost Girls Theatre is all about.

story:
Background:

Writer/Director David Lally wanted a way into Herman Melville's world as he wrote this show in 2009 for the Metropolitan Playhouse's Annual Author Festival, that year focusing on the works of Herman Melville. Called "Melvillapalooza", David didn't want to just focus on the big works like Moby Dick and Billy Budd, but wanted to include a sampling from all of Melville's works. And that's how Mr. Melville's Playhouse was born.

What We Need & What You Get

The Metropolitan Playhouse subsidized the original festival. Reviews were great. Backstage said it was "immediately accessible",  "good clean fun played by an enthusiastic troupe."

The Midtown International Theatre Festival is a great platform to bring this show back in 2016. However, M.I.T.F. doesn't provide any funding.

We would like to raise $5,000. Where will that money go?

  • Actors. We hear so much about how a life in the theatre is one in which you are not compensated or compensated very little. We believe that all our actors, whether union or non-union, should make a fair wage.
  • Costumes. Mr. Melville's Playhouse, though taking place in the contemporary world, is costumed with period costumes. These do not come cheap and it's a reason why many theater companies no longer do period pieces.
  • Costume Designer. We have a great one in mind. She costumed the original production, which was subsidized. We'd love to hire her back but who wants to work for free?
  • Set Pieces: Though the festival provides some basic set pieces, we want to dress the set up a bit. The original production benefitted much from having a nautical-themed set. We can't recreate that completely but every dollar raised will help dress up the stage.
  • Rehearsal space. The festival does not provide space to rehearse so we have to rent studio time throughout Manhattan. Yes, there are discounted spaces, but even with discounts rehearsal space regularly runs upwards of $20 per hour.

Risks & Challenges

It's a challenge to produce good theater these days. With exorbitant costs facing theater people, it's a wonder anything gets done. But with your help, we can put on a great show. Are there risks? Absolutely! Are we up to the challenge? Of course! Every dollar helps.

Every contribution is important! If we can get a few hundred people to even just donate $10 we will be way on our way to achieving our goal!

Can't contribute money? Not a problem!

Hey, we all know money is tight. But if you can't donate financially, you can donate your time or if you have a space, donate your space! We'll still give you props in the program!

Hey, just reposting us on social media is a big help! Tell all your friends!
story_txt:
Background: Writer/Director David Lally wanted a way into Herman Melville's world as he wrote this show in 2009 for the Metropolitan Playhouse's Annual Author Festival, that year focusing on the works of Herman Melville. Called "Melvillapalooza", David didn't want to just focus on the big works like Moby Dick and Billy Budd, but wanted to include a sampling from all of Melville's works. And that's how Mr. Melville's Playhouse was born.
What We Need & What You Get
 The Metropolitan Playhouse subsidized the original festival. Reviews were great. Backstage said it was "immediately accessible",  "good clean fun played by an enthusiastic troupe."
The Midtown International Theatre Festival is a great platform to bring this show back in 2016. However, M.I.T.F. doesn't provide any funding.
We would like to raise $5,000. Where will that money go?

Actors. We hear so much about how a life in the theatre is one in which you are not compensated or compensated very little. We believe that all our actors, whether union or non-union, should make a fair wage.
Costumes. Mr. Melville's Playhouse, though taking place in the contemporary world, is costumed with period costumes. These do not come cheap and it's a reason why many theater companies no longer do period pieces.
Costume Designer. We have a great one in mind. She costumed the original production, which was subsidized. We'd love to hire her back but who wants to work for free?
Set Pieces: Though the festival provides some basic set pieces, we want to dress the set up a bit. The original production benefitted much from having a nautical-themed set. We can't recreate that completely but every dollar raised will help dress up the stage.
Rehearsal space. The festival does not provide space to rehearse so we have to rent studio time throughout Manhattan. Yes, there are discounted spaces, but even with discounts rehearsal space regularly runs upwards of $20 per hour.


    Risks & Challenges It's a challenge to produce good theater these days. With exorbitant costs facing theater people, it's a wonder anything gets done. But with your help, we can put on a great show. Are there risks? Absolutely! Are we up to the challenge? Of course! Every dollar helps.
Every contribution is important! If we can get a few hundred people to even just donate $10 we will be way on our way to achieving our goal!
Can't contribute money? Not a problem!
 Hey, we all know money is tight. But if you can't donate financially, you can donate your time or if you have a space, donate your space! We'll still give you props in the program!
Hey, just reposting us on social media is a big help! Tell all your friends!

story:
The Skinny

Our mission at Mitch and Murray Productions has been to bring modern, compelling plays from the global stage to Vancouver.  We've been tagged "HBO for the stage" by a few of our audience members and local critics have raved about our brand of theatre.  Over our five year history, we've received 12 Jessie Richardson award nominations and attracted an engaged sizeable audience base that is diverse in age and ethnicity.

Making the cozy Studio 16 our home, our aim is to give theatre sex appeal, starting with the artwork, glass of wine and friendly front of house volunteers when you hit the lobby.  Audiences who attend our shows are coming with anticipation of an event!

(Past shows, left to right - "RACE", "SPEED-THE-PLOW", "RAPTURE, BLISTER, BURN")

 

This November, we had planned to bring a wonderful new piece of theatre to town.  "Detroit" by Lisa D'Amour is a Pulitzer Prize-nominated play in which two couples who live in adjacent houses awkwardly try to get to know each other. This hilarious and unnerving play operates with a delicious sarcastic humour that reflects an unpleasant but graphic picture of the new struggling class. Characters negotiate addiction, denial and failed social connections as the realities of shifting neighborhoods and the new economy weigh in their collective identities.  Sounds like a perfect play for Vancouver, right?

Well, for some reason, the public funding bodies didn't think so.  Shockingly, after all of our success, we received no grant funds this year from our annual applications, and so don't have the pivotal cornerstone funding needed to stage this ambitious production.  We're taking action to challenge the ways your tax dollars are spent on arts funding, but that story is for another time.

We recently announced cancellation of "Detroit" due to the funding issue and were overwhelmed by the avalanche of response from our audience members, colleagues and supporters.  So many people wrote to us and encouraged us not to cancel the show, pledging assistance and support.  Those who know this play pleaded with us to find a way to give it life despite the lack of public funds.

So here we are, attempting to revive production of this play with the stellar cast and crew all committing to the show, which can hopefully go forward.  These artists are some of the finest talents onscreen and stage in Canada.

(Clockwise from top left - Jennifer Copping, David Mackay, Luisa Jojick, Director Lois Anderson, John Taylor and Aaron Craven.)


Our funding goal is the bare minimum we'll need in order for us to pull off this production, and while it gives us barebones finances, we will do as we always do - pull off a great looking production on a shoestring budget.  Hell, we've been doing this with sweat, labour and innovation for five years, why stop now?

This is a lofty goal.  We will need support and the spreading of this fundraiser not only from our artistic colleagues but the broader community.  We need members of the business community and those with the desire to support a strong artistic entity in Vancouver to step forward and support us. We'll aim to educate public funding bodies more in future, but for now, our existence lies with patronage from those who care.

We can't do it without you.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The $15,000 goal is about triple what we usually raise in donations every year.  This money will go towards the major expenses of the show - theatre rental, royalty payments and production design.

Perks for donating include listings in our playbill and social media, complimentary tickets to opening night performance and reception, ad space in our playbills and much more! Business operators and those wanting to raise awareness of a specific cause can receive promotion across all of our materials, where it will be viewed by thousands of people.

Should we raise the needed funding we'll commence with production of "Detroit", opening this November 4th at Studio 16 in Vancouver.  Audiences are in for a treat - the play is so wonderfully funny, dark and topical.

If we don't raise the full amount, we'll be replacing "Detroit" with a smaller less expensive show during the same dates.  No matter what, we'll do our thing in 2016.

But we really want to bring "Detroit" to this city.  That is the ultimate goal.

 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign around on all platforms.  If you've seen our shows, talk us up to your friends and colleagues.  We'll need some critical mass in order for this fundraiser to achieve its goal.

If everyone who has seen our shows or had any association with the company speaks up a little bit on our behalf, we can do this.

Detroit is set against the backdrop of homes. You can help us to build one this year.

Very best and thank you,
The gang at Mitch and Murray Productions

story:
Hi! My name is Peter Schueller and I have started a theater company called esō theatricals in Budapest, Hungary. We have already put up two shows (http://budapesttimes.hu/2016/05/06/broadway-com...) and are in the process of formally becoming a non-profit organization for the next season!

As an English-language musical theater company, we plan to keep connecting members of the local and international communities and expose them to high quality, culturally relevant productions. These have been and will continue to be made accessible by always including Hungarian super-titles. As shown with its premiere productions, esō theatricals has engaged and brought together a melting pot of different peoples and cultures. With the proper funding, we will deliver professional caliber productions that will expose audiences to exceptional performers and present renown musicals from the past and present.

The next production and purpose of this funding request is “Sweeney Todd”. That show will be followed by two more productions, bringing the company's season to a total of three musicals for the year. As we grow in recognition, we hope ticket sales and established support will keep us going!

Our casts are diverse, always including at least 5 different nationalities, and welcome to individuals of all gender, race, ethnicity, sexual orientation and identity. We believe this is crucial in helping to create a cultural dialogue and mutual understanding through art and performance. This combination of artists and musical material has so far created an inclusive atmosphere that has been a satisfying and complete theater going experience, delighting new viewers and providing nostalgia for veterans.

Summary of overall objectives:

1.  Successfully provide audiences with desirable and enjoyable entertainment.

2.  Expose the community to iconic musical theater as well as providing exceptional training and services.

3.  Educate the community in various aspects of English-language musical theater methodology, perspective, and history by creating an environment of active cultural relevance and discourse. This will eventually include school and low-income outreach.

4.  Create understanding and compassion towards cultural differences and cultivate mutual good will.


esō theatricals’ conceptual framework is unique among the current musical theater industry in Budapest. Currently, there is no formal venue dedicated to English-language musical theater, especially one that also addresses fundamental styles of performance on a professional level.


"esō theatricals believes all art is created with the intention of exposing visceral emotions. The strength of humanity exists in the vulnerability of its dreams, as expressed through tangible methods. The love or hate of a certain idea or theme communicated simply through intention, can create certain contrasts, positive/negative connotations, understanding, awareness, etc., thus allowing the viewer to sense harmonies/disharmonies and instigate an inner dialogue of thought and meaning. Through a high standard of artistic integrity, esō theatricals intelligently discerns and portrays musical theater content of historical and contemporary relevance and is able to produce highly enjoyable productions to a discerning public and broader community alike. esō theatricals' outreach model also connects the community with professional performers in a more intimate setting, thereby drawing a larger percentage of the community on a regular basis".


Budget requirements for Sweeney Todd: (currency exchange as of May 13, 2016)

Fees associated with non-profit organization registration in Hungary: $611

Theater rental: $2,805

Show performance rights: approximately $1,510-$2,000

Personnel and cast, including musicians: $5,645

Show scores and advertising: $215

Set and Costume Budget: $719


Total: $11,505-$11,995
Projected Ticket Sales based on previous sales: $2,588
Amount needed: $8,917 minimum
Any funds received over this amount will go towards administration costs for the whole year and roll over into the next production[s]


Thank you very much in advance for your support! With your help, we can make this happen and create something truly unique and special!

-Peter Schueller


Peter Schueller was born in California and trained in classical vocal performance at the University of Southern California while at the same time branching out into Musical Theater, Theater and Film. Before relocating to Budapest, Peter was seen in numerous professional productions throughout Southern California. Some of his favorite roles have included Tony in West Side Story, Frederic in the Pirates of Penzance and Bobby Child in Crazy for You (awarded Best Actor in a Musical by stagescenela.com). Since being in Budapest, he has acted in, directed, music directed, and choreographed numerous showcases and performances. Some tv and film credits include featured roles in Ridley Scott’s The Martian, Ron Howard’s Inferno, X Company, and NBC’s upcoming Emerald City.

 Classically, Mr. Schueller has been heard as the Tenor soloist in Mozart’s Requiem, Poet/Narrator in Schumann’s Dichterliebe, Tamino in The Magic Flute, Alidoro in Orontea, and as an understudy in SF Opera’s Dead Man Walking, among many other roles. He is a member of the American Guild of Musical Artists and the Mu Phi Epsilon Musical Fraternity.

Additional comments:

esō, means “within”, while in Hungarian means “rain”.  To cleanse, nurture and grow the potential within.

story:
Hello all. Our company E3OUTLAWS PRODUCTIONS Co., INC. Its a company founded in June 2006 and this year we are turning 10, Yes we have been a production company for the last ten Years and until today we had never ask for help.

We had received lots of help during the past ten years amazing angels, and sister companies, as well as nonprofit organization that had said yes we believe in what you doing and we want to help. We are eternally grateful to everyone that had help our company bring Excellent performance into the New York Stages.

 Today we are asking you to help us raised $10,000. to celebrate our 10 years and to produce our Summer 2016 productions as well as our 4th Theatre Festival. Yes we are already on our fourth year of our eARTh Theatre Fest 'Lorca Al Desnudo'

Help our heart beat on the 2016. Any contribution Matter and if you give and share you are really being part of our angels,  because that is what you are when you give to us, our saving angels.

We need $10,000 help us. For your contributions you are going to be mention in our programs and our Website as part of our Angels and Associates producers.

$25 Name on our Programs as White Angels

$50 Name on our Programs as Silver Angels and Sponsor.

$100 Name on our Programs as Golden Angels, Associates Producers, And free entrance to our Productions.

$500 and Up Name on our Programs as Platinum Angels Producers, And free entrance to our Productions, as well as your name on our Web Page.

Your contribution will help our Theatre company to continue our work, it will give opportunities to us, our staff, our Actors, our Technicians, and Theatre Venues continue bringing Excellent performance and great artist from New York and other parts of the world to share theirs crafts with the world bringing the Young community to learn about theatre and be involve in the arts.

We have an excellent track records with our outstanding performance, always being scrutinized by the press giving our performance greats review and being nominated and Awarded multiples times for our many shows by Latin ACE (Association Of Critics in Entertainment) AWARDS. HOLA (Hispanic Organization Of Latin Actors) AWARDS. ATI (Association of Independent Theater) Awards.

We want to thank you for your Donnation if by any means you are passing for a hardship at this time, Thank you and please just help us by getting the word out, help us make noise about our campaign. Use the share tools from Indiegogo.


Thank you.

With Love for humanity, for the Arts and for the Planet.
E3OUTLAWS PRODUCTIONS Co., Inc.

story:
Hello! We are Beacon Theatre Productions, a 501(c)3 non-profit theatre company in Philadelphia which produces plays that "educate, inspire, and challenge." Our focus as a company is on live theatre that sheds new light on events and figures from history and literature. 

Our latest production is the Philadelphia Premier of "Young Frederick Douglass," a play by Walt Vail, inspired and adapted from The Life and Times of Frederick Douglass, by Frederick Douglass. The Life and Times of Frederick Douglass is published by Random House, Inc. Our venue: Olivet Covenant Presbyterian Church Theatre, 608 N. 22nd Street, Philadelphia, PA 19130 (Fairmount Neighborhood) The production runs for three weekends, April 8 - April 24, 2016.



At BTP, our goal is to provide theatre to ALL who are interested. With a production like Young Frederick Douglass, we especially aim to bring youth to the theatre who might otherwise not attend due to financial struggles or just because they are not aware that theatre that promotes the empowerment of those who are marginalized is available in their own city! 

This year we are offering "Mentor Matinees:" free tickets to mentors and mentees. So far we have had an incredible response from organizations such as Big Brothers Big Sisters and the Philadelphia Chapter of 100 Black Men, and in order to accommodate this response and also produce a professional-level show, 

WE NEED YOUR HELP AND SUPPORT!

What We Need 

How much money do we need from this IndieGoGo campaign? 

$3,500.00 

Compared to other campaigns, $3,500.00 is a "blip" on the radar of fundraising, but for us at BTP, $3,500.00 will go an incredibly long way!

  • Stipends: We believe that designers, actors, and directors should be fairly compensated for their hard work!
  • Set / Lighting / Costuming / Props: While our actors are working to tell an incredible story, the life of Frederick Douglass in his younger years is even more powerful with professional-level costuming, set design, lighting, and props.
  • Community Outreach: WE'RE GOING TO SCHOOLS! We will tour scenes from the production to Philadelphia schools to spark the discussion amongst Philadelphia youth about how Frederick Douglass began his life a slave, and fought his way to freedom through the power of education. To organize these events, several hours must be devoted by our staff, and we want to make sure they are taken care of for their dedication.

Risks & Challenges

Mounting a production for three weekends can be a terrifying feat for a new and emerging company, especially one whose goal is to provide compensation for all actors, directors, designers, managers, and staff involved! There are over 10 key players helping to make this show a reality, and through funding from organizations such as the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, the Dolfinger-McMahon Foundation, and individual donors we CAN make this goal a reality! We are excited and won't rest until we have the funds! Last year we produced "Bonhoeffer's Cost" with over 400 attendees, and we aim for even more with "Young Frederick Douglass." 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate funds, you can still help us out! If you live in the Philly area, please contact us (beacontheatreproductions.org) for volunteer opportunities such as ushering, house management, and more. Word of mouth is also our best way to spread the word of our needs -- please share our campaign with your own social networks via Facebook, Twitter, and e-mail!

Beacon Theatre Productions receives state arts funding support through a grant from the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, a state agency funded by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and the National Endowment for the Arts, a federal agency. Additional funding provided by the Dolfinger-McMahon Foundation, Union Benevolent Association, and individual donors like you!

Come see the show! "Young Frederick Douglass" runs April 8 - April 24 2016 at Olivet Covenant Presbyterian Church Theatre, 608 N.  22nd Street, Philadelphia PA 19130. Tickets go on sale March 10th at www.beacontheatreproductions.org.

Further BTP Contact Information:

Beacon Theatre Productions, PO Box 4026, Philadelphia, PA 19118. 

beacontheatre1@gmail.com 

(267) 415-6882

The Life and Times of Frederick Douglass is published by Random House, Inc. Our venue: Olivet Covenant Presbyterian Church Theatre, 608 N. 22nd Street, Philadelphia, PA 19130 (Fairmount Neighborhood) The production runs for three weekends, April 8 - April 24, 2016.



At BTP, our goal is to provide theatre to ALL who are interested. With a production like Young Frederick Douglass, we especially aim to bring youth to the theatre who might otherwise not attend due to financial struggles or just because they are not aware that theatre that promotes the empowerment of those who are marginalized is available in their own city! 
This year we are offering "Mentor Matinees:" free tickets to mentors and mentees. So far we have had an incredible response from organizations such as Big Brothers Big Sisters and the Philadelphia Chapter of 100 Black Men, and in order to accommodate this response and also produce a professional-level show, 
WE NEED YOUR HELP AND SUPPORT!   What We Need  How much money do we need from this IndieGoGo campaign? 
$3,500.00 
Compared to other campaigns, $3,500.00 is a "blip" on the radar of fundraising, but for us at BTP, $3,500.00 will go an incredibly long way!


Stipends: We believe that designers, actors, and directors should be fairly compensated for their hard work!
Set / Lighting / Costuming / Props: While our actors are working to tell an incredible story, the life of Frederick Douglass in his younger years is even more powerful with professional-level costuming, set design, lighting, and props.
Community Outreach: WE'RE GOING TO SCHOOLS! We will tour scenes from the production to Philadelphia schools to spark the discussion amongst Philadelphia youth about how Frederick Douglass began his life a slave, and fought his way to freedom through the power of education. To organize these events, several hours must be devoted by our staff, and we want to make sure they are taken care of for their dedication.



    Risks & Challenges Mounting a production for three weekends can be a terrifying feat for a new and emerging company, especially one whose goal is to provide compensation for all actors, directors, designers, managers, and staff involved! There are over 10 key players helping to make this show a reality, and through funding from organizations such as the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, the Dolfinger-McMahon Foundation, and individual donors we CAN make this goal a reality! We are excited and won't rest until we have the funds! Last year we produced "Bonhoeffer's Cost" with over 400 attendees, and we aim for even more with "Young Frederick Douglass." 
    Other Ways You Can Help If you're unable to donate funds, you can still help us out! If you live in the Philly area, please contact us (beacontheatreproductions.org) for volunteer opportunities such as ushering, house management, and more. Word of mouth is also our best way to spread the word of our needs -- please share our campaign with your own social networks via Facebook, Twitter, and e-mail!
Beacon
Theatre Productions receives state arts funding support through a grant from
the Pennsylvania
Council on the Arts, a state agency funded by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
and the National Endowment for the Arts, a federal agency. Additional
funding provided by the Dolfinger-McMahon Foundation, Union Benevolent Association, and individual donors like you!
Come see the show! "Young Frederick Douglass" runs April 8 - April 24 2016 at Olivet Covenant Presbyterian Church Theatre, 608 N.  22nd Street, Philadelphia PA 19130. Tickets go on sale March 10th at www.beacontheatreproductions.org.
Further BTP Contact Information:
Beacon Theatre Productions, PO Box 4026, Philadelphia, PA 19118. 
beacontheatre1@gmail.com 
(267) 415-6882

story:
Short Summary

We are Seoul Shakespeare Company, an all-volunteer theatre company, and Seoul’s only English-language Shakespeare company. Since 2011 we have been bringing together members of the Seoul theatrical and artistic community to perform an annual major Shakespeare production for audiences in Korea--both expat and Korean.  Last year's production, Titus Andronicus, was a huge stepping stone for our company, bringing a new degree of sophistication to our productions, but because of Korea's MERS panic, which hit exactly during the run of our show, our ticket sales were not enough to start financing this year's production of Much Ado About Nothing, so we are continuing our tradition of an annual crowdfunding campaign, asking our supporters to again be a part of our next production and show their love for the theatre community in Seoul.

This year's production, Much Ado About Nothing, goes in a brand new direction for our company.  In our tradition of alternating between tragedy and comedy, we are swinging the pendulum in the opposite direction from the dark, technically complex Titus of last year to bring audiences a lively, warm, fast-paced, playful experience, with a design and style reminiscent of Elizabethan stage practice. 


What We Need & What You Get

Putting on a piece of theatre is always expensive!  In this campaign, we are asking for a small portion of the total cost of the show.  The total budget for this show is approximately $16,000, about three-quarters of which is just for the theatre rental.  Other costs include rehearsal space rental, printing, fabric for costumes, materials for our minimal set, and a small number of props.  What we don't raise through this campaign we hope to earn through hosting small events and through ticket sales, If you can help us fund this show, we will be very grateful, and to show our appreciations we will credit you in our programs, on our website and Facebook page, and on our video of the production.  To our higher-level donors, we will also send perks such as signed posters and programs, a DVD, and personalized video performances of Shakespeare's sonnets.  Check out our perks list for all the perks we are offering.  No matter how little you can give, you will have our deep appreciation. 

Many of us involved in this show have friends and family abroad, and this campaign is also a way that our loved ones can support us and be a part of our artistic endeavors. Whether we know you personally or not, you will have our love and gratitude.


(Please note that on Indiegogo making a contribution does not automatically sign you up to receive a perk.  If you would like to receive a perk, you must specifically click on the perk you would like to receive.)


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't give directly to our production, you can help us by sharing our campaign through social media, and, if you're in Korea, coming to our show!  Ticket reservations for the show are already available: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/much-ado...  

If you have a Korean bank account, you can also contribute via bank transfer.  Your contribution won't show up in our Indiegogo total, but we can still send you the perks listed above.  Send us an email to let us know that you've contributed, and we can add you to our list of donors.  Here is a link to our bank information: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/make-a-c...



Crew:
Director: Michael Downey
Stage Manager: Lindsay Bellinger
Artistic Director/Producer/Costume Designer: Lauren Ash-Morgan
Assistant Stage Managers: Laura Jasi, Maria Fernanda Silva
Lighting Designer: Iain Culp

Cast: 
Leonato: Lorne Oliver
1st Messenger / Sexton / Tomb Attendant: Mary Yoon
Beatrice: Lauren Ash-Morgan
Hero: Heather Moore
Don Pedro: Sam Osborne
Benedick: Jamie Horan
Don John: Chris Zaczek
Claudio: Charles Jeong
Antonio: William Roszell
Conrade / Tomb Attendant: Angie Ahn
Borachio/Friar Francis: Jason Cutler
Balthasar: Jake Kwon
Margaret: Kim Hyman
Ursula: Molly Stewart
Dogberry: Jeffrey Wagner
Verges: Simon Clarke
Seacoal: Sarah McRoberts
Watchman 1 / Lord: Alameen Saidu
2nd Messenger / Watch / Tomb Attendant: Joseph Van Dorn
3rd Messenger / Watch / Tomb Attendant: Mariah Perrin

story:
COURAGE

Courage, NACL Theatre’s latest outdoor performance spectacle, is an ensemble-generated play with a company of 25 performers, conceived and directed by NACL co-founder and Artistic Director, Tannis Kowalchuk, with music by Rima Fand, text by Melissa Bell and Mark Dunau, dramaturgy by Mimi McGurl, costumes by Karen Flood, and a special cameo appearance by film actress Debra Winger.

The performance is based on Bertolt Brecht’s Mother Courage and Her Children, along with sources including The Runagate Courage by Von Grimmelshausen and Peace by Aristophanes. Courage advocates for compassion and resiliency in a time of crisis, it exercises spectators’ emotional intelligence in its examination of tyranny, injustice, and the true costs of war. Courage will have its New York City premiere with three free shows on Governors Island September 22-24, 2017, and we need your support to get us there.

What We Need

NACL needs to raise  $15,000 to bring Courage to New York City. Funds will help NACL pay more than 30 collaborators and provide housing and sustenance for everybody on the team. We must transport all our costumes, props, and sets in many vehicles to the island and since we are doubling our seating capacity in New York City, we must build a new tent system for the final scenes of the performance. 

What You Get

Sweet music, T-shirts, posters, tickets, dinner, love...

Impact

Courage is a timely performance experience. Set in a fictional refugee camp called Camp Renew, the audience is fully immersed in the show’s environment.

What Happens in Courage? After receiving a visitor’s pass for their camp tour, the audience is introduced to a character played by Debra Winger who invokes the spirit of Bertolt Brecht in a prologue to the performance. Before long, the camp visitors (the audience) embark on a tour guided by a merchant woman named Courage and her adopted daughter Kyoko.

Along the way, the audience encounters General Publik and his army of stilt walkers, a smuggler and her newly arrived group of refugees, the preacher, camp musicians, and a professor who presents the visitors of Camp Renew with a tent-production of Peace, by Aristophanes. Throughout, Courage looks for her son Billy who she knows has joined up with the military.

Who's In Courage?  NACL has assembled a remarkable cast of performers who sing, stilt-walk, act, write, and design. The company is made up of performers from the NACL community in upstate New York, New York City, and as far away as Japan and Canada. We are: Writers Melissa Bell and Mark Dunau; Composer Rima Fand; Dramaturg Mimi McGurl; Costume Designer Karen Flood; Actors Jessica Lopez-Barkl, Jessica Beveridge, Michael Chojnicki, Bradley Diuguid, Brett Hughes, Oliver King, Tannis Kowalchuk, Simon Kowalchuk-Swartz, Daniel Lendzian, Nick Lopez, Keith McHenry, John Roth, and Yurika Sase, Debra Winger; Chorus Members Melissa Bell, Tracy Broyles, Rebekah Creshkoff, Rocky Davis, RaeAnn Handshy, Annie Hat, and Nancy Peterman; Stilt Corps Gregg Erickson, Corinna Grunn, Adrianne Picciano, Jon Jon Thomas, Tyler Watts; Musicians Sarah Alden, Zoe Christiansen, and Doug Rogers; Production Management Brad Krumholz and Sue Currier; Stage Management Aubrey Ellis, with Brendan Dromazos; and Technical Direction by Zoot

Why support Courage?

Courage addresses difficult ideas about justice imbalanced; it evokes situations when war is the first reflex, where people seek refuge from disaster. Through the collaborative efforts of the NACL community, Kowalchuk and the team have built a performance that explores riveting human experiences and situations with beautiful music, heart-wrenching scenes, and plenty of humor in all the right places.

The theatrical experience provided by Courage is an opportunity to see and experience our world today with a new lens, and to help us process not only the news headlines and current events, but  to help decipher our own deeper thoughts and feelings as individuals and communities in times of unrest. Courage can inspire creative and unexpected responses in us all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with friends, at work, with social media circles, and loved ones. Thanks so much!

story:
VISIT: http://bravenewworldrep.org/current-season/

Raves from the 2016 World Premiere: 

“The Plantation is a savvy, relevant and deeply satisfying adaptation of a Chekhov masterpiece. It's as funny as it is devastating and I can’t wait to see it again.” – Pulitzer Prize winning playwright David Lindsay-Abaire.

"Brave New World's Artistic Director Claire Beckman has adapted and directed a poignant, powerful, riveting and relevant production that resonates profoundly in these current times when our country struggles to find our voice and path forward with regard to race relations and respect for all people. The acting ensemble, production values & direction...all first rate!" – Actor Blair Underwood.

"Fantastic production and exceptional performances from the top down. Audience members sobbing and cheering around me." – BNW fan

BNW is grateful to the Governors Island Trust for the opportunity to return for a longer 10 performance run at the glorious Commanding Officer's House on Governors Island! We believe this production is important for more people to see and deserves greater exposure.

THE PLANTATION, set in Virginia 1870, seven years after Emancipation, five years after the Civil War ended, and eight years before Jim Crow, re-imagines Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard in the American South, when African American men were given the vote, 1500 were elected to public office including two U.S. Senators, and the state of Virginia was just barely re-admitted to the Union.  

As America witnesses the current administration's efforts to unapologetically erase President Barack Obama's legacy and achievements, this timely adaptation asks us to consider WHY the fascinating period in American history known as Reconstruction is largely overlooked in the history books, and continues to be neglected in public school curricula. Did Reconstruction fail? Or is it more likely that the PROMISE of African American leaders and citizens was too great a threat for many Americans? ARE we living in a New Jim Crow era? WHAT can we learn from history to avoid repeating it?

In 1861, Anton Chekhov, grandson of a former serf, was 1-year-old, when the Russian Tsar, Alexander II, abolished serfdom, two years before Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation. Like Lincoln, "Alexander the Liberator" was also assassinated. In a January 1861 letter to Fredrick Engels, Karl Marx wrote: "In my opinion, the biggest things that are happening in the world today, are on the one hand, the movements of the slaves in America started by the death of John Brown, and on the other the movements of the serfs in Russia."  

This project began in 2015 as a staged, indoor/outdoor reading on Governors Island, to coincide with the 150th anniversary of the end of the Civil War, and the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Movement. Senseless tragedies in Ferguson, Staten Island, Baltimore, Cleveland, Charleston, Baton Rouge and St. Paul, fueled this labor of love. And since our most recent presidential election, it has assumed an even greater mercenary mission. Chekhov's universal humanity, humor, and understanding of class and status, as re-imagined in 1870 Virginia, provides historic perspective and gives voice to the voiceless. 

The Plantation is about a dysfunctional "family" that rips apart at the seams, like the very fabric of our country. W.E.B Dubois famously warned that "The problem of the Twentieth Century is the problem of the color-line." Indeed, American confusion between class and race has turned the color-line into a convenient and unjust economic weapon since Jim Crow 'separate but equal' laws went into effect seven years after this play takes place. Seven years after Barack Obama became the first Black president, "whitelash" had already motivated the Black Lives Matter movement, and since the election of DJT, given rise to new shut downs against Americans of color and Immigrants. We cannot afford to be silent. From our 2005 production of To Kill a Mockingbird to Lynn Nottage's Fabulation, and Elmer Rice's Street Scene re-imagined in the Harlem Renaissance, among other plays, Race in America has been a central theme and focus in BNW's body of work. The Plantation is our effort to return to the historic genesis of this neglected conversation. 

Thanks to the Governors Island Trust, our immersive production, now inside the stunning pre-Civil War Commanding Officer's House in the historic Nolan Park section of the island, returns for 10 intimate performances on August 31, September 1, 2, 3, 9, 10, 15, 17, 23, and 24.

The Plantation's total budget of $17,300 will pay for:

Production Expenses: $5,050

28 Actors, Creatives, and Crew: $12,250

Our program is supported in part by public funds from the NYC Dept of Cultural Affairs, in partnership with the city council, local sponsors including fine artist Titus Kaphar and individual supporters like you! Without at least $5,000 in additional individual contributions and sponsors from this campaign, we will not meet our goal. We humbly ask for your help and will provide tickets and other perks! Thanks so much!!!

Many thanks to colleague Bob McGrath, Ridge Theater artistic director and three-time obie-winner, and the many actors, designers and stage managers who have contributed their time and talents to the development of The Plantation:

Craig A. Grant⚜️, Tim Craig, Lauren Young, Nick Plakias, Hale Thompson, Leonie Ettinger⚜️, Roy Eaton, AnnieRose Kafer⚜️, Tyler Egan, Alice Kors, Alice Barrett-Mitchell⚜️, John Edmond Morgan⚜️, Caroline Ryburn⚜️, Brittany Giles-Jones⚜️, Neville Aurelius, Al-nisa Petty⚜️, Daniel Blanda, Shawn-Herb Felton, Jonathan Kirkland, Martina Nevermann⚜️, Harrison Adams, Lucy Gwathmey, Carol Klenfner⚜️, Benjamin Furiga and Sarah Elizabeth Dickerson, Gretchen Ervin⚜️, Lauren Harkins⚜️, Jacob Minevich, Michael Moss⚜️, Nathalie Thomas⚜️, Marchant Davis, Tereza Hakobyan & Love Lolli, Mike Longo⚜️, Russell Norris, Norman Small, Tasneem Nathari, Byron Freeman, Lisa Renee Jordan, Faith de Montrichard⚜️, Taylor Weinberg, Chelsea Gregory, Emily Dalton, Arthur French, Damond McFarland, Dannie Toussaint, Hui Cox, Issa Best, Kayla Thomas, Perri Yaniv, William Brenner⚜️, Emely Zepeda⚜️, Patrick Lachance, Stacey-Rae Allen⚜️, Emily Czudak, Steve Gridley⚜️ and Ann Flanigan.

⚜️Member/Former member of Brave New World Repertory Theatre

Grant⚜️, Tim Craig, Lauren Young, Nick Plakias, Hale Thompson, Leonie Ettinger⚜️, Roy Eaton, AnnieRose Kafer⚜️, Tyler Egan, Alice Kors, Alice Barrett-Mitchell⚜️, John Edmond Morgan⚜️, Caroline Ryburn⚜️, Brittany Giles-Jones⚜️, Neville Aurelius, Al-nisa Petty⚜️, Daniel Blanda, Shawn-Herb Felton, Jonathan Kirkland, Martina Nevermann⚜️, Harrison Adams, Lucy Gwathmey, Carol Klenfner⚜️, Benjamin Furiga and Sarah Elizabeth Dickerson, Gretchen Ervin⚜️, Lauren Harkins⚜️, Jacob Minevich, Michael Moss⚜️, Nathalie Thomas⚜️, Marchant Davis, Tereza Hakobyan & Love Lolli, Mike Longo⚜️, Russell Norris, Norman Small, Tasneem Nathari, Byron Freeman, Lisa Renee Jordan, Faith de Montrichard⚜️, Taylor Weinberg, Chelsea Gregory, Emily Dalton, Arthur French, Damond McFarland, Dannie Toussaint, Hui Cox, Issa Best, Kayla Thomas, Perri Yaniv, William Brenner⚜️, Emely Zepeda⚜️, Patrick Lachance, Stacey-Rae Allen⚜️, Emily Czudak, Steve Gridley⚜️ and Ann Flanigan.⚜️Member/Former member of Brave New World Repertory Theatre

story:
Let’s see our people and stories celebrating Deaf culture, history and ASL in a visible platform.

Deaf Spotlight will produce SKIN, a play written by an emerging Deaf playwright, Crystal L.M. Roberts. This production focuses on a subculture of the Deaf community - Deaf queer womxn and their complicated lives as Deaf, lesbian, friend, lover, and supporter. The play supports the cultural and theatrical development of the Deaf community and individual Deaf artists. 

Your contribution will help finance our third theatrical production by creating a space and time for Deaf actresses and a Deaf director to bring a Deaf playwright's creation onto the stage. 

YOUR SUPPORT

We're asking for your help to produce SKIN. We need at least $15,200 to make this dream a reality:

  • Honorariums for the cast and creative / technical team: actresses, playwright, director, stage manager, set designer, dramaturg, photographer, and stage light designer
  • Materials to build the stage
  • Venue for rehearsals and performances

Come see our show, May 4 - 7 & May 12 - 13, 2017 at the 12th Ave Arts Mainstage, Seattle, WA.  All performances will be open captioned in English. Follow us on social media and website, too. 

 

CAST:

Rhonda Cochran | GLO: Rhonda Cochran is excited to be a part of her first play with Deaf Spotlight. An avid theater lover/goer, Rhonda also has enjoyed behind the scene work as a ASL Coach and Interpreter for local theaters.  Outside of the theater,  Rhonda enjoys spending time with her family and is the mother of Theresa and grandma to 2 beautiful girls.

Kalen Feeney | QUINN: Kalen is a Washington native and excited to be returning to Seattle! She toured with the National Theatre of the Deaf and has trained with the American Conservatory Theatre, Deaf West Theatre, and Oregon Shakespeare Festival. She has appeared on Cold Case and Switched at Birth. In addition, Kalen is a screenwriter and has produced several short films.

Amelia Hensley | SAMMIE: Amelia Hensley has enjoyed theatre her whole life, and her expressiveness landed her the lead role in in her first professional production Children of a Lesser God with the Arkansas Repertory Theatre. Since then, Hensley has performed with the Theatre Arts Department at Gallaudet University, Capital Fringe, Faction of Fools, Studio Theatre, and the Kennedy Center. Her recent works include the critically acclaimed I was most alive with you, directed by Craig Lucas,  and starring in the role of Thea in Deaf West Theater’s Spring Awakening on Broadway in 2015-16. She received her BA from Gallaudet University in theatre arts and educational drama.

Michelle Mary Schaefer | ASH: Michelle Mary Schaefer , not new to the stage, was the first Deaf Female Actor who challenged herself by portraying as Billy as a guy in Tribes by Nina Raines three times last year.  Schaefer has also recently portrayed as Sarah Norman in Children of a Lesser God in Tampa, Florida.  

TEAM: 

Crystal L.M. Roberts | Playwright: Crystal L.M. Roberts is a PNW Deaf lesbian mother of two CODAs. She is a pen for hire, political activist writer, ghost writer, poet, playwright and occasional reader at the Salon of Shame. Skin was commissioned by Deaf Spotlight to showcase how various Deaf, gender nonconforming, queer womxn go about their everyday lives. It is a tribute to the many strong, beautiful, wise friends and lovers in her life that have befriended, mentored, counseled, and gave her pints of ice cream when she needed it. Crystal now lives in the other Washington with her fiancé where she will enter the MPA program at Gallaudet University.

Alexandria Wailes | Director: Alexandria Wailes has over 15 years of acting/directing/ choreographing and a lifetime of dancing. She was a part of the creative team and an associate choreographer for Deaf West's Spring Awakening in LA and on Broadway. 

Patty Liang | Producer: Patty Liang is the Executive Director of Deaf Spotlight. She oversees artistic and cultural programming to support the Deaf artists and their work and to encourage the Deaf community to embrace and celebrate the arts. Patty received a BFA in Ceramics from the UW, and a MA in Nonprofit Management for the Arts from NYU. She believes everyone have the innate ability to create and they can express their stories and thoughts through the arts.  

Deaf Spotlight | Nonprofit : Deaf Spotlight inspires, encourages, and showcases creative works of, by, and for Deaf people in the Pacific Northwest through events that celebrate Deaf culture and American Sign Language.

story:
Short Summary

First and foremost, we would like to thank you for visiting and considering donating to our cause. We greatly appreciate it.
We are WreckLess Dance Crew out of Jacksonville, Florida. WreckLess is the adult promotional and competitive team for the company i-Move U-Move dance workshop series. The crew is composed of local dancers and instructors with various training in many genres of dance. Our main style is hip hop. However we can also perform some contemporary modern, modern fusion ( hip hop and contemporary) and ballet. Our mission is to help spread the education of hip hop dance and to uplift, unite and support each other through movement while building relationships and growing into better people every day. 

Currently we have been selected to be apart of two competitions where we will represent the USA. The first is the K-pop cover dance festival. We just recently received our bid to the 2nd round of the competition on April 18th. The first round was based off of views and likes of the cover dance video we submitted to the cover dance website. Now the 2nd round will take place April 28th at 6pm at the Source (6940 Beach Blvd Buena Park, CA 90622). This round will be based off our live performance and the judges scores and crowd reaction. As long as we place top 3 we can be selected as finalists in which we will be flown to South Korea to compete in the final round ?@6 30th-June 5th, all expenses paid. Then we will compete for the grand prize and to become the k-pop cover dance champions of the world. We are in need of 7 roundtrip tickets for each member's travel to there and back. We also have a showcase on the 30th so we are flying out Thursday, to compete on Friday and flying back home to prepare for the showcase. If we can do this it will help spread the awareness of Jacksonville Dance Community and talent and it would also strengthen the case of Jacksonville having professional dancers which will inspire a lot of the students here around town. We have also been selected represent America in Croatia called Dance Star. For this competition we will combine with other dance teams from Chicago, Phoenix, and Detroit to represent the nation against the world. Dance Star competition begins May 25th. The plan is to leave the US on May 23rd and return May 29th. In order for us to participate we must raise $2000-$4000 to help cover expenses such as food, stay, flight, team USA paraphernalia and other means of transportation for the entire trip. 

These competitions and our successes in them would greatly boost the hype and awareness of the Jacksonville dance community. It would help us with networking as well so we can meet some new dancers and choreographers to bring to Jacksonville to further spread the education aspect of dance. This would benefit the community as a whole because everyone would have someone new to take class and learn from. One of our goals has been to help put Jacksonville​ on the map for the dance scene. The more attention we bring to the city the better it will be for our dance community. We would like to say thank you in advance for helping us reach these major milestones in our dance career as a crew.

What We Need & What You Get

We need as much support as we can get.  We would like to ask for your support, donations and that you spread the word about our campaign and us as a dance crew in Jacksonville. We have some perks that you may enjoy.

The Impact

This would greatly affect WreckLess as a crew, as far as our growth and the exposure that we will receive. It would be huge for us mentally as well. These are some experiences that we never imagined could happen to us especially with us being from Jacksonville. It has been so hard for us to get exposure and to book gigs so this is a dream come true for us as a crew. Because of how it will impact us directly it will help with building​ the dance community because we are some of the instructors here in town. 

Risks & Challenges

The risks and challenges that we have to overcome with this campaign are not making it to the finals of the K-pop cover dance competition, also with our own showcase coming up on the 30th it is a lot to focus on both performances. But the crew is up to the task and we are working very hard to deliver 2 A+ performances, one in LA and the others back home for our showcase. It's exactly the life we want to live and were told we couldn't staying in Jacksonville.

Other Ways You Can Help

The more you share the more we grow. So we ask that everyone share the campaign and let someone know that there​ are dancers in Jacksonville working to be the best they can be and bring a demand for professional dancers right here.

story:
Because of rewrites and the fact that I really want to capitalize on this opportunity, I need a little extra money that I didn't plan on for things like:

  • New characters added = more actors needed!
  • Rehearsal photos
  • Production photos
  • Additional props
  • Press kits/business cards/project proposal materials
  • Transportation and storage

It just comes out to a little bit more over budget than I had intended and I really need your help to make it happen.

I'm SO EXCITED about this show - I've never been so happy with a script going into the rehearsal process, and the cast and team are all first rate. If I get this right we're gonna knock this one outta the park - I need the extra cash to help me do that.

CONVICTED
Theatre at the 14th Street Y.
344 E. 14th St.

Friday, August 4th 1230PM
Friday, August 11th 730PM
Monday, August 14th 400PM

Book your tickets here:
https://14streety.secure.force.com/ticket#details_a0S36000003FI2JEAW

story:
The Story

TRUCE is a dramatic love story of self-acceptance, forgiveness but never forgetting. It is a story about a brother who loses his brother to gay teen suicide and bullying. It is a story about HIV stigma in the LGBT community. It is a story about domestic violence from both the abuser point of view and the victim's point of view. It is about family and about who are your real friends in this crazy world. 

Jesse finds out that he has been diagnosed with HIV from his doctor, and needs to tell his boyfriend, Casey. Casey discovers that his younger brother has committed suicide due to bullying and not enough love from the people in his life. Casey plans on proposing to Jesse until he finds out about Jesse's diagnosis and then goes into a blackout domestic violence attack on Jesse. Stormy is Casey's younger sister who is the glue that holds everything together and in the end is the one person who has an intervention with Casey. After leaving Jesse's apartment, Jesse meets Aaron who apparently knew Jesse ten years prior in London under a different name and was also a victim of his domestic violent attacks. Before Casey shows up in the alley, Jesse and Aaron leave the premises to clean up Jesse and start a new life. Meanwhile, Stormy and Casey have an intervention that changes both of their lives forever.

The Cast

Mia Tesfay will play STORMY; Jeremy Behrens will play the role of AARON; Christopher Ellis will play the role of JESSE.

We are still casting for the role of CASEY.

The Vision

Director/Producer/Playwright, B.Michael Peterson, wants to take you down through to the other side of central park in upper west side to an upscale loft apartment and then to a dark alley in Hell's Kitchen for this production of TRUCE. We will be incorporating a unique makeup design - designed by Angel Reichl.

Multi-media will be incorporated into the performances by Seattle and Los Angeles based photographer, Michael McAfoose (Urban Focus Studio) with photography and video that correlates with the themes in the show, including an official video trailer and video montages that will be seen in the show.

The Company & Production Staff

So far we have put together our production team and couldn't be more proud of this team.

Artistic Director // B.Michael Peterson

B.Michael Peterson is a producer playwright, theater director, and a former stage manager of 15 years. His directing highlights include “Kiss of the Spider Woman” by Manuel Puig (Trail by Fire TheatreWorks), “BREAK” by J.Stephen Brantley (Against the Wall Productions), “His Mother Calls Him Petey” by John C. Davenport (2010 Page to Stage Short Play Festival/Seattle Playwrights Collective) and “The Greyhound” by Scot Auguston (Spin the Bottle at Annex Theatre Company). Peterson studied directing with Portland-based director, Devon Allen, at the Portland Center Stage’s Greenhouse School of Theater. Peterson is the author and creator of “Popuessing: The Place of the Dragon”, “Can’t Tear Me Down: The Story of the 1969 Stonewall Riots” and “Kritical Suicide”. He values a great deal on live theater with new play development and is always eager to work with dramaturges, playwrights and directors with a similar artistic statement than his. Highlights from his stage management career include “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” with Adam Goldthwaite (Lord Leebrick Theater Company/Eugene, OR), “The Trial” directed by Steve Coker (La Bodega Productions, “HAIR” directed by Joe Zingo (Actors Cabaret of Eugene) and “Women in Peril” directed by Jason Sharp (Annex Theatre Company).

Resident Dramaturge // L.Nicol Cabe

L. Nicol Cabe focuses on new, locally-written theatre and believes in the amazing talent collected in Seattle. She has participated in Director’s Lab West 2014, and has worked with such wonderful Seattle theatre companies as Annex Theatre, Live Girls! Theatre, Taproot Theatre Company, and Ear to the Ground. She has also worked on shows with Cornish College of the Arts, Theater Schmeater, and Work It Productions’ Shakespeare on the Troll. Her one-woman show, “best-of-craigslist: Live!” went to the Portland Mini-Fringe Festival in 2011, and if you buy her a margarita, she might talk about her very first solo performance, “Sockpuppet MacBeth.”

Production Stage Manager & Lighting Associate // Petra Zanki

Petra studied light design with Michael Mannion and Henk Danner, and pursued her theatre studies at the performing arts department at the Sorbonne Nouvelle in Paris. She worked with renown Croatian and Slovenian theatre directors and groups such as Montažstroj, Shadow Casters, Oliver Frljić, Via Negativa, Tea Tupajić, Banana Gerila etc. co/creating, presenting and producing theatre and dance works across Europe, in the US, and Australia. In the US, she collaborated with PS122 and On The Boards. She has also edited magazines and written articles on theatre and performance.

Resident Make-up Artist // Angel


Against the Wall Productions is an ensemble-based theater company in Seattle, Washington that aims to produce cutting edge dramatic plays written by gay male identified playwrights that educate, preserve and cultivate society on the themes and issues surrounding the gay male community at large. Additionally, ATW Productions produces a summer comedy series of LGBTQ standup comedians as a contrasting balance to the mission of our company.

The Fundraising Journey

Producing theater posses many challenges but the biggest is building a solid budget and finding funds is meek for arts groups in the world. What we are raising money for is essentially the cost for rehearsal space, performance space, materials and salaries for the artists, managers, technicians and talent involved.

    Above all, don't forget to share this great project with your friends on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Myspace, Pinterest and your blogs. The themes associated with this play need to be addressed in our communities. Help us start the conversation by making a donation today. Be sure to check out the perks and packages listed below.

    We will be updating this campaign regularly with exclusive interviews with the cast and production team, as well as members of the community that have experienced domestic violence, HIV stigma and gay teen suicide.

    Much thanks, gratitude and appreciation...

    B.Michael Peterson // Artistic Director // Against the Wall Productions
