 and written articles on theatre and performance.
Resident Make-up Artist // Angel



 

Against the Wall Productions is an ensemble-based theater company in Seattle, Washington that aims to produce cutting edge dramatic plays written by gay male identified playwrights that educate, preserve and cultivate society on the themes and issues surrounding the gay male community at large. Additionally, ATW Productions produces a summer comedy series of LGBTQ standup comedians as a contrasting balance to the mission of our company. 
    The Fundraising Journey
 Producing theater posses many challenges but the biggest is building a solid budget and finding funds is meek for arts groups in the world. What we are raising money for is essentially the cost for rehearsal space, performance space, materials and salaries for the artists, managers, technicians and talent involved.   Above all, don't forget to share this great project with your friends on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Myspace, Pinterest and your blogs. The themes associated with this play need to be addressed in our communities. Help us start the conversation by making a donation today. Be sure to check out the perks and packages listed below.We will be updating this campaign regularly with exclusive interviews with the cast and production team, as well as members of the community that have experienced domestic violence, HIV stigma and gay teen suicide. Much thanks, gratitude and appreciation...B.Michael Peterson // Artistic Director // Against the Wall Productions

story:
WELCOME to the Indiegogo fundraising campaign for the development of...


The Wicker Husband, a new folk musical

book and story by Rhys Jennings
music and lyrics by Darren Clark
based on an original short story by Ursula Wills-Jones

FINAL WEEK UPDATE: "The Sparrow's Tale" as sung by the Tailor's Wife...

The Wicker Husband will be an unconventional musical combining puppetry, folk music and dance to weave the tale of an Ugly Girl and her understanding of the cruel world she lives in. It is the story the Outsider, of self-acceptance in a society that tells us what it is to be "Ugly".

With permission from Ursula Wills-Jones to adapt her original short story, composer Darren Clark and bookwriter Rhys Jennings have been developing the idea since 2014 with the help of director/dramaturg Charlotte Westenra - and this year we will be conducting a series of three dramaturgical workshops towards a private industry presentation to share the work we have developed.

It is set to be an exciting year for us, and we'd love for you to help us on our journey of exploring this exciting new work.




We are applying for Arts Council funding to help us stage a series of three workshops in 2016. For a successful bid, we need to raise 10% of our funding from outside sources, which is why we are asking for YOUR help.

Your support will allow us to explore the theatrical world, create and develop new material, engage a puppetry director, collaborate with artists, and eventually stage a full rehearsed reading of the show to pitch for it's future...

The first workshop will be a week of exploration with a team of actors and musicians working on the material and structure of Act II. This follows a previous successful workshop at the Royal Welsh College of Music and Drama, which focussed on Act I. Funding will provide: venue hire, artist fees and printing costs.

The second stage will consist of a series of meetings and collaborations between puppetry experts and basket-makers, a period of design and the creation of a prototype puppet (full scale 'bunraku' man made of wicker) and three days exploration with a team of three puppeteers. Funding will provide: expert consultation fees, workroom hire, material cost, construction time, rehearsal space and performer fees.

The third, and ultimate, goal is to conduct a week's rehearsal of the full production with a team of actors and musicians, culminating in a script-in-hand industry presentation. Funding will provide: venue hire, performer fees, printing costs, an audio recording, a production booklet about The Wicker Husband and provision for the industry presentation...



Your help will make an incredible difference to how quickly we are able to make it to the third stage of development. In return for your help we will offer a number of perks as incentives to donate:

  • Those who donate any amount, however small, will be added to the Wicker Husband Mailing List keeping you informed of the project's development. This will give a unique insight into creating a material for a new musical and you'll receive updates, pictures and recordings at each stage of the process.
  • For donations over £5 you will receive a Special Wicker Email. (Indiegogo terms dictate that we cannot mention on this page what it's for!)

    Visit: http://bit.ly/TheOtherPerks to find out more.
  • For donations over £15, you will have access to the above PLUS a hand-written card from the Wicker Husband team thanking you for your contribution.
  • For donations over £25, and once our third stage of development is reached, you will have access to all the above PLUS online access to some audio recordings of Darren Clark's music for The Wicker Husband, a folk musical made during our industry presentation. 
  • For donations over £50, and once our second stage of development is reached, you will receive all the above PLUS an invitation to see our Wicker Husband puppet in action at the end of our three day exploration. If you are unable to attend (date: TBC) we will organise a separate time for you to meet the puppet in person.
  • For donations over £75, you will receive all the above PLUS a copy of our production pack, about The Wicker Husband, the journey so far and our plans for the future. These will be limited edition and will be provided to all industry contacts at our private rehearsed reading.
  • For donations over £100, you will receive all the above PLUS a copy of the first draft script signed by the cast of our rehearsed reading.
  • If you are feeling incredibly generous and donate anything in excess of £150, you will receive all of the above PLUS an exclusive invitation to our industry reading in 2016 (date: TBC).  

Wherever possible, we will endeavour to mention all those contributors who wish to be named in future publications pertaining to The Wicker Husband, a folk musical. 





Your help, however great or small, will be invaluable to the development of The Wicker Husband. It's an ambitious project in its combination of forms, styles and practices. By its very nature, Musical Theatre requires huge amounts of dramaturgical and explorative work, and with the inclusion of puppetry, folk music, dance and storytelling, this project demands even more time spent in these early days.

We want this to be a remarkable and innovative theatrical experience, and your help will not only support our project, but set a useful precedent for future collaborators who wish to embark on similar ambitious projects. For this reason, we have kept all production notes, emails, drafts and so forth, and we hope that in future we can make this information freely available to the public, in particular those practitioners who wish to see how we took a small idea and transformed it into a bold and brave piece of theatre. 




As well as appealing for donations, we are also keen to hear from anyone who can offer any other "in-kind support" which will help towards our goal. The monetary worth of some of this support can also be used toward our 10%, which the Arts Council require. This includes, but is not limited to:
  • Printing costs: help with printing all or some of our written material - drafts, scripts, musical notation, invitations, booklets etc.
  • Rehearsal venues and workshop space: full provision or reduced rate offers.
  • Audio/Video recording: our third level of development will include a recording of the rehearsed reading, which will require equipment and technical assistance.
  • Mentorship and guidance: if you have experience in puppetry, theatre-producing, research and development, grant-application or similar areas of expertise, please get  in touch and see how you can guide us toward our goal.
  • Design: until the show reaches production stage and we secure a designer, any artists or designers are welcome to get in touch at this stage to help by creating conceptual artwork of puppets, characters and settings.
  • Materials: donations of puppet materials, willow, withy or similar.
  • Storage: once our prototype puppet has been made, we will need to find somewhere safe to keep him temporarily when he is not in use. (London)
  • Press & Publicity: writers and journalists are welcome to talk to the team about the project and help us spread the word.
  • Digital engagement: website design, development and social media guidance.

If you are able to help with any of the above or can think of other things you can offer us, please send us an email to wickerhusband@gmail.com.

And if you can't help with any of the above, but would like to help in a small way, please engage with us online by following us on Twitter and Facebook or subscribing to our Youtube channel.

Thank you for helping!
Rhys, Charlie & Darren.







Thankyou to all those who have helped on our journey so far and to those whose work features in our campaign video: 

Ursula Wills-Jones, Darren Clark, Rhys Jennings, Charlotte Westenra, Christine Bramwell, Matthew Schmolle, Purni Morell, Carolyn Forsyth, Joanne Harris, Rachel Cox, Elexi Walker, Liz Lawson, Yasmin Lewis and all at The Unicorn Theatre, Slavka Jovanovic, Beth Warnock, Chris Wootton, and all at The Little Angel Theatre, RWCMD, Ann McNulty, Laura Pitt-Pulford, Richard Heap, Michael Taylor Matus, Jack Monaghan, Sufia Manya, Perry Lambert, Josh Sinclair Evans, Laura Wickham, Anne-Marie Piazza, Josh Sneesby, Eilon Morris, Andy Munro, Chris Aukett, Mei Mac, Geri Allen, Maisie Turpie, Will Cousins, Joshua LeClair, Ashleigh Cheadle, Rachel Salenius, Leejay Townsend, Stiofàn O’Doherty, Loren O'Dair, Matthew Cole, Abigail Parmenter, IRIS Theatre, The Actors Church, The Wells Way Pop Up, The Society of London Theatre, Viv Care, Dave Bond, Jennifer Ruth-Adams, Adena Cahill, Rosie Archer, Hannah Roper, Eleanor Pawsey, Ross Hoey, Tom Corbishley, Dafydd Gape, Dafydd Weeks, Jordan Turner, Jonathan Radford, Corey Jones.

And a huge thank-you to all those who have donated towards our fundraising:

LINKS:
THE ACTORS GUILD
SPOTLIGHT
THEATRE TOKENS
WATERSTONES
CAFE ROUGE
BOOTS
THEATACCOUNTS
DRAMANIC
THE ACTORS CENTRE
SAMUEL BLACK PHOTOGRAPHY
CASTING WORKSHOPS

story:
Sweat with MBDance! 

I am thrilled (slightly breathless, but mostly just thrilled ) that I get to bring two full evenings of MBDance works to L.A. at Highways Performance Space on August 14 and 15. And this includes two premieres (full Attend Me and Limbs)! Nehemoyia Young, Ashley Brockington, Marina Magalhães, and I will all be dancing, and a local poet will open up the space. Highways: MBDance

Storied bodies, mythological bodies, bodies-in-creation, and bodies as manifestos…these are the places from which I have created the works we'll share at Highways. MBDance is characterized by muscles, beads of sweat, and exertion as well as surrender and softness. Our vision of beauty is expansive, and the new pieces chart intimacy and legacy through this lens. 

For Attend Me, I was inspired by the writings and philosophy of Audre Lorde--particularly her love poems. With the dancers, I have brought forth a kinetic vision of radical self-acceptance and self-love, romantic love, and defiant love between Black women. Torian Ugworji created beautiful animations for this trio. We've been honored to create and share in-progress versions of "Attend Me" through two CUNY Dance Initiative Residencies, and we performed an excerpt from the piece at our beloved BAAD! in New York. The performances we are raising funds for at Highways in Los Angeles will be the first time we've performed the full piece with full lighting, sound, costuming, and animations! May Audre Lorde approve and affirm of how we have been alchemists with her spirit and ours. 

Limbs is a new piece I created especially for the phenomenal Marina Magalhães. Marina is a lightning bolt of a performer, quickening and slowing the pulse of audience members as she chooses, with her deft uses of nuance and passion. With an elegant set created by Julio Sims, I created a solo inspired by the swooping and braided branches of ancient trees I researched in Richmond, VA. This piece invites us to consider "What is the legacy of our natural world? Where and how have we secreted away space within us to appreciate the sacred beauty of nature?" and "What does it mean to be old?" 

I will also dance a structured improvisation from my grace is high and low series. Folks in L.A. will experience versions 5 and 6, after performances at WOW Cafe Theatre, BAAD!, and the American Dance Festival. As I deepen my own study of our bodies' inherent value and compelling nature, this work becomes more and more rich. 

MBDance frequently performs on shared bills and at festivals. We have only had full evenings of our own work at Dogtown Dance in Richmond, VA--and now at Highways Performance Space in Los Angeles! Over the past two years, I have devoted more time to my art, researched and studied voraciously, and been blessed to have artistic mentorship from giants like Jawole Zollar, Founding Artistic Director of Urban Bush Women. My work has expanded, deepened, and matured.  My community organizing has also grown, and that affects my art--how I think about it, who it is for, and what we all have to gain. I am blessed to be held by a circle of powerful thinkers, makers, and dreamers. For all of these reasons, MBDance's work is stronger than ever. Now is the right time to step in to these full evenings of MBDance work. 

                            


Our Exchange with You

First, THANK YOU for your support of me and of MBDance in all the ways that you do. We are raising $7900 for this tour. I am putting in over $1000, and with the rest crowdsourced, we will:

  • bring a production assistant with us to L.A. to work with the set and the animations
  • pay all of the personnel (dancers, poet, producer, lighting designer)
  • buy four round-trip flights
  • provide per diem for the dancers--artists work hard; down with the "starving artist" trope!
  • supplement the small stipends that went to set designers and composers
  • have the evenings recorded by a professional videographer
In exchange for your financial support, we can offer: 
  • a video viewing and discussion circle of the GRACE IS HIGH AND LOW evenings at Highways 
  • including your name in the program at Highways
  • including your name in our closing blessing at rehearsals (energy is powerful and real!)
  • private Partner Stretch & Tension Release sessions with me
  • prints of beautiful photographs from Attend Me, with powerful quotes from Audre Lorde on them

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about the Sweat with MBDance fundraising campaign; share the video and invite folks in!
  • Please let me know how I can help YOU! Our community of do-ers, artists, educators, makers, thinkers, and community organizers is powerful. How can I lift up your work in this world? Let's be in a divine flow together! 

Highways: MBDance                                                                                       www.mbdance.org

story:
Short Summary

Justin M. Schlabach is a theatre director from Spokane, Washington. He is the former Artistic Director of Lilac City Performing Arts, a theatre company committed to producing work about social and personal issues in the Inland Northwest. In New York City, he's directed the staged reading of Once Upon with Writopia Labs and acted the role of Chris Pasco in Ophelia with Gotham Dance Theater. Justin developed a devising method with which he directed Hog Heaven and On the Subway for Old Orchard Theatre. His method begins with actors bringing source material that inspire them regarding the premise. In the case with Solitaire, actors used the premise of depression. The focus was not only the darkness of depression, but also the light; finding the balance. Justin then conducted improvisation exercises to draw out theatrical ways to present the source material around the metaphor of the classic card game Solitaire. He then wrote the script in twenty days based on the material learned by the cast in source material and improvisation. The result is the story told in Solitaire about Jordan and Christy who both live with depression and how it affects their lives as well as those who love them. This play will have its first appearance at Joria Productions in New York City the second weekend of September.


Solitaire is a significant play because it delves into a taboo subject. Depression is a serious condition that not only plagues the world, but also has strong roots in New York City.  Moreover, the effects of depression are detrimental to both the individual and those who love them. According the Andrew Solomon, author of the Pulitzer Prize Finalist book Noonday Demon, 15% of individuals who are depressed will attempt suicide. It is the hope of this ensemble to help audience members want to talk about this subject, give hope that one can live a thriving life with depression, and perhaps inspire the 15% that taking one's life does not have to be the answer. Moreover, 20% of ticket sales will be given to The Trevor Project as a donation to help their work in reaching LGBT youth who struggle with depression and considering suicide. (Justin M. Schlabach and Solitaire: An Original Play are not affiliated with The Trevor Project)

This Indiegogo campaign is the means to present this work. With the funds raised we can pay for the performance space,  props, costumes, set, and rehearsal space. Your contribution will make this play happen and perhaps have an impact on individuals who live with depression.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise at least $3,600 to present Solitaire. Our budget breakdown is as follows:

  • $850 for the Performance Space Rental
  • $1,500 for Rehearsal Space Rental
  • $500 for the Set, Props, and Costumes
  • $100 for Printing Flyers and Materials
  • $650 for Indiegogo Donor Rewards and Shipping
As a thank you to contributions, we will not only include you in a shout out on our Facebook page and in the program, but also send donor rewards based on contribution amounts which include a Solitaire T-shirt, playing cards featuring the Solitaire image, a signed poster, DVD of the performance, and complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice. Justin M. Schlabach will also be hosting a Producers' Brunch for extraordinary contributions.

      


The Impact

Solitaire delves into the darkness of depression. According to Andrew Solomon, "About 3 percent of Americans - some 19 million - suffer from chronic depression. More than 2 million of those are children." This subject is one that is rarely talked about and needs to be addressed. In addition, this play also provides suggestion on how to live with depression. Knowing that living a vital life with depression is a personal and subjective path, Solitaire sensitively gives hope while pointing individuals in the direction to the help they themselves need. It is our hope that this play will reach individuals who need to hear about it either because they themselves deal with depression in their everyday life or they know of someone who lives with depression. With the numbers being so high and the risk too great, Depression needs to be discussed and people made aware. Moreover, with the ensemble's desire to donate to The Trevor Project, this production will not only create awareness, but also allocate funds to an organization that helps depressed LGBTQ youth on a daily basis and facilitates suicide prevention.

Justin M. Schlabach has used his devising method to create two previous plays: Hog Heaven and On the Subway. Hog Heaven emphasized the importance of family and On the Subway explored the nature of friendship. Both productions moved audience members to the point where they remembered the stories and their messages years later. Justin's goal is to do the same with Solitaire. This play can have a positive influence on the city of New York and to the extended geography that audience members will take it.

  


Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk with Solitaire is having people hear about the production. New York City has so many plays with companies that have bigger budgets to market their shows. Moreover, while Solitaire will be performing in Hell's Kitchen, it is also near all the well-known Broadway houses which can distract audience member from seeing this play. However, we will use the resources we have to let as many people know about Solitaire as possible. A press release has been sent to many publications including The New York Times, PlayBill, New York Magazine, New York Post, Time Out, Village Voice, among others. Flyers will be printed for use to spread to people the ensemble meets in our interactions to let them know about the play. We will also be using word-of-mouth, Facebook, and Instagram to spread the word. Our success will be dependent on people like you to take the time to share this play in your personal interactions and on your social media. If we can raise more than our $3,600 goal, we can use the funds for marketing materials to broaden the circumference of awareness. Between our efforts and your assistance in creating awareness, we can let as many people know about this play as possible even without a large marketing budget.

  


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot financially contribute to our Indiegogo campaign, you can still spread the word. Share this campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc. The more people know about it, the better our chance to not only reach our goal, but possibly surpass it. If we surpass our $3,600 goal, we can use the funds for marketing and reach even more individuals to see this show. Therefore, whether or not you are able to contribute, please share!
story_txt:
Short Summary Justin M. Schlabach is a theatre director from Spokane, Washington. He is the former Artistic Director of Lilac City Performing Arts, a theatre company committed to producing work about social and personal issues in the Inland Northwest. In New York City, he's directed the staged reading of Once Upon with Writopia Labs and acted the role of Chris Pasco in Ophelia with Gotham Dance Theater. Justin developed a devising method with which he directed Hog Heaven and On the Subway for Old Orchard Theatre. His method begins with actors bringing source material that inspire them regarding the premise. In the case with Solitaire, actors used the premise of depression. The focus was not only the darkness of depression, but also the light; finding the balance. Justin then conducted improvisation exercises to draw out theatrical ways to present the source material around the metaphor of the classic card game Solitaire. He then wrote the script in twenty days based on the material learned by the cast in source material and improvisation. The result is the story told in Solitaire about Jordan and Christy who both live with depression and how it affects their lives as well as those who love them. This play will have its first appearance at Joria Productions in New York City the second weekend of September.

Solitaire is a significant play because it delves into a taboo subject. Depression is a serious condition that not only plagues the world, but also has strong roots in New York City.  Moreover, the effects of depression are detrimental to both the individual and those who love them. According the Andrew Solomon, author of the Pulitzer Prize Finalist book Noonday Demon, 15% of individuals who are depressed will attempt suicide. It is the hope of this ensemble to help audience members want to talk about this subject, give hope that one can live a thriving life with depression, and perhaps inspire the 15% that taking one's life does not have to be the answer. Moreover, 20% of ticket sales will be given to The Trevor Project as a donation to help their work in reaching LGBT youth who struggle with depression and considering suicide. (Justin M. Schlabach and Solitaire: An Original Play are not affiliated with The Trevor Project)
This Indiegogo campaign is the means to present this work. With the funds raised we can pay for the performance space,  props, costumes, set, and rehearsal space. Your contribution will make this play happen and perhaps have an impact on individuals who live with depression.   What We Need & What You Get We need to raise at least $3,600 to present Solitaire. Our budget breakdown is as follows:


$850 for the Performance Space Rental
$1,500 for Rehearsal Space Rental
$500 for the Set, Props, and Costumes
$100 for Printing Flyers and Materials
$650 for Indiegogo Donor Rewards and Shipping


As a thank you to contributions, we will not only include you in a shout out on our Facebook page and in the program, but also send donor rewards based on contribution amounts which include a Solitaire T-shirt, playing cards featuring the Solitaire image, a signed poster, DVD of the performance, and complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice. Justin M. Schlabach will also be hosting a Producers' Brunch for extraordinary contributions.

      

    The Impact Solitaire delves into the darkness of depression. According to Andrew Solomon, "About 3 percent of Americans - some 19 million - suffer from chronic depression. More than 2 million of those are children." This subject is one that is rarely talked about and needs to be addressed. In addition, this play also provides suggestion on how to live with depression. Knowing that living a vital life with depression is a personal and subjective path, Solitaire sensitively gives hope while pointing individuals in the direction to the help they themselves need. It is our hope that this play will reach individuals who need to hear about it either because they themselves deal with depression in their everyday life or they know of someone who lives with depression. With the numbers being so high and the risk too great, Depression needs to be discussed and people made aware. Moreover, with the ensemble's desire to donate to The Trevor Project, this production will not only create awareness, but also allocate funds to an organization that helps depressed LGBTQ youth on a daily basis and facilitates suicide prevention.
Justin M. Schlabach has used his devising method to create two previous plays: Hog Heaven and On the Subway. Hog Heaven emphasized the importance of family and On the Subway explored the nature of friendship. Both productions moved audience members to the point where they remembered the stories and their messages years later. Justin's goal is to do the same with Solitaire. This play can have a positive influence on the city of New York and to the extended geography that audience members will take it.

  

    Risks & Challenges The biggest risk with Solitaire is having people hear about the production. New York City has so many plays with companies that have bigger budgets to market their shows. Moreover, while Solitaire will be performing in Hell's Kitchen, it is also near all the well-known Broadway houses which can distract audience member from seeing this play. However, we will use the resources we have to let as many people know about Solitaire as possible. A press release has been sent to many publications including The New York Times, PlayBill, New York Magazine, New York Post, Time Out, Village Voice, among others. Flyers will be printed for use to spread to people the ensemble meets in our interactions to let them know about the play. We will also be using word-of-mouth, Facebook, and Instagram to spread the word. Our success will be dependent on people like you to take the time to share this play in your personal interactions and on your social media. If we can raise more than our $3,600 goal, we can use the funds for marketing materials to broaden the circumference of awareness. Between our efforts and your assistance in creating awareness, we can let as many people know about this play as possible even without a large marketing budget.

  

    Other Ways You Can Help Even if you cannot financially contribute to our Indiegogo campaign, you can still spread the word. Share this campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc. The more people know about it, the better our chance to not only reach our goal, but possibly surpass it. If we surpass our $3,600 goal, we can use the funds for marketing and reach even more individuals to see this show. Therefore, whether or not you are able to contribute, please share!

story:
We are raising funds for a Poughkeepsie Fringe Theatre Festival. Your help is needed for a Performance space rental, Hiring experienced lighting/sound technicians, insurance and advertising. We want as many people from the community as possible to participate and enjoy Poughkeepsie's very first Fringe Theatre Festival!

Thank you for your time :-)

What is a Fringe Theatre Festival?  Well courtesy of fringefestivals.us we have answers!

"Its focus is the performing arts: Theatre, dance, puppetry, spoken word make up the fringe core, but festivals often include film, visual elements and Music.

They're easy to participate in and usually feature an array of original material.  

In the United States, no one organization or individual owns, controls or regulates the name "Fringe."  There are no national rules for how each individual festival operates; the festival's content, finances and structure vary from city to city.  Generally, however, all the festivals are committed to an open forum of expression!"

***PLEASE SHARE***this Project with Everyone!!

The festival is scheduled for May 2016.

Our first venue is the CUNNEEN-HACKETT ARTS CENTER THEATER located at 12 Vassar St. Poughkeepsie, NY 12601

We have our very first artists Jocelyn Johnson-Kearney and Alex Taylor set to present and perform a world premiere of their original work during the festival.  

Jocelyn Johnson-Kearney is performing the series of works A LOT TO SAY.


Jocelyn Johnson-Kearney presents a wide range of original written work from
an equally wide range of experiences.  Short stories, poetry,
monologue and other forms powerfully express a perspective informed by
her and her family's deep involvement in the civil rights and black
power movements, family life, and her work in human services.

Ms. Johnson-Kearney earned a degree in playwrighting from Howard University,
and has performed and produced some of her work in the Poughkeepsie
area.  She has written articles and a regular food column free lance for The Poughkeepsie Journal, and designed and conducted a ReadersTheatre program for Poughkeepsie area youth and children.   She has been a community organizer, dedicated particularly to improving the Poughkeepsie City School District.
An accomplished cook and jewelrymaker as well as a writer, Ms. Johnson-Kearney
lives and works in Poughkeepsie.

An excerpt from MISSISSIPPI by Jocelyn Johnson-Kearney captures Fringe Theater at its best!

MISSISSIPPI   Excerpt

Tourists heard only wind

and  that

Confederate flag flapping

over the governor’s mansion.

We, too moved silently 

led by a Southern Belle

through the glorious

stone structured monument, 

priceless furniture,

curtain threads of gold.

What wonders

created this

and all we know today.

Grandma had seen

the work

white stone lies lifted by

black hands of people

bleeding, screaming unrelieved

over time

to claim the sky

South, North, East, West

Grandma, Ma and 

I see from this 

single eye.


Alex Taylor is presenting a series of tremendous one acts- FAINFORA-

NIGHT FALLS OVER RAPID STREET

SHIMARA: The BODY BEHIND

SHOW ME YOUR SAFARI


Any artist interested in participating in the festival please email poughkeepsiefringetheatre@gmail.com

story:
BE MITICO! L'esposizione universale dell'improvvisazione teatrale a Milano

Eccoci finalmente! Il 2015 è il grande anno! Dall'1 al 7 luglio si terrà un grande evento: il Milano International Theatresports™ Institute Conference - MITICO, una settimana di improvvisazione internazionale con workshop, forum, spettacoli e tanti altri eventi che si terranno a Milano proprio durante l'EXPO.

www.mitico2015.it

L'importanza culturale della manifestazione sarà globale in quanto coinvolgerà artisti e professionisti dell'arte dell'improvvisazione da tutto il mondo accogliendoli nel nostro Paese, facendoli incontrare tra loro e con gli improvvisatori italiani, facendo vivere loro l'esperienza del Festival e della Città che li ospita realizzando al contempo spettacoli internazionali aperti al grande pubblico di EXPO 2015.

Un'occasione davvero unica che vede Milano terza tappa di un Festival già riconosciuto a livello mondiale, organizzato dall'International Theatresports™ Institute presieduto da Keith Johnstone precedentemente ospitata a Calgary (Canada) nel 2011 e a Würzburg (Germania) nel 2013.


Vogliamo che Milano e l'Italia intera vengano valorizzate al meglio organizzando in tutta la Città eventi che godranno anche in lingua inglese, rendendoli fruibili anche, per esempio, da parte di chi si trova nella Città meneghina per l'Esposizione Internazionale.

L'idea di realizzare un'esposizione internazionale delle eccellenze dell'improvvisazione teatrale mondiale è un valore aggiunto che intendiamo offrire alla Città di Milano e all'Italia.

Vogliamo valorizzare la Città nel modo meno prevedibile: abbiamo concentrato i corsi, gli spettacoli e i panel della settimana nella zona della Martesana, nella zona operaia di Milano, con spettacoli nello storico teatro di Zelig e al Teatro Officina, spazio nato da un dopolavoro. Altre attività si svolgeranno a Cascina Martesana, un bel progetto di valorizzazione e recupero del quartiere.

Vogliamo poi realizzare la serata evento del Festival presso Villa Clerici, con uno spettacolo internazionale di improvvisazione negli spazi del giardino all'italiana.

In questo modo vogliamo offrire un evento di grande valorizzazione delle bellezze e del patrimonio culturale italiano, lasciando un ricordo indelebile per i numerosi artisti stranieri che interverranno, oltre ad includere lo spazio stesso in un evento importante per il teatro di improvvisazione mondiale.

La manifestazione ha raccolto l'interesse da parte del Comune di Milano che patrocina l'iniziativa. Gli eventi di MITICO sono inseriti in EXPO IN CITTA'.

Chi siamo

L'organizzazione del Festival prevede il coinvolgimento di molte realtà associative che hanno competenze complementari nell'ambito degli eventi, dell'arte e dello spettacolo dal vivo, con una particolare inclinazione per il teatro d'improvvisazione.

Associazione MUSE


Le socie di Muse costituiscono una squadra di professioniste in ambiti multidisciplinari, con titoli di studio legati all'architettura, alle scienze giuridiche e umanistiche, al giornalismo, al design.

La mission delle Muse è valorizzare i beni culturali, siano essi storici, artistici o ambientali.

www.associazionemuse.it

Teatribù

Teatribù è l’associazione culturale nata a Milano nel 1999 con lo scopo di promuovere l’improvvisazione teatrale, l’arte dello stare in scena senza testo.

Oltre a essere una compagnia teatrale che propone spettacoli completamente improvvisati, Teatribù è una scuola di teatro dotata di caratteristiche uniche nel panorama delle scuole di recitazione milanesi: la sua peculiarità, infatti, è quella di convergere prevalentemente sull’improvvisazione.

www.teatribu.it

Il progetto gode del prezioso sostegno delle realtà improvvisative italiane de I Bugiardini (Roma), Improvincia (Brianza) e DettoFatto (Torino).

Perché abbiamo bisogno di voi?

Perchè sappiamo che sono i partecipanti, gli amanti dell'improvvisazione e gli improvvisatori a nutrire questa arte che noi amiamo e che i migliori sponsor per questa attività di eccellenza sia chi ne percepisce il valore.

Cosa abbiamo pensato per ringraziarti per il tuo aiuto?

Abbiamo pensato a delle ricompense speciali: magliette autografate, dedica speciale di un’improvvisazione, esclusivi workshop, pass per il festival, anche uno spettacolo direttamente a casa tua. Se sei particolarmente fanatico puoi anche diventare sponsor principale!

Con i fondi che ci aiuterai a raccogliere contiamo di portare a termine le spese dell’intero festival, come ad esempio coprire le spese di affitto del teatro, l’alloggio e il vitto per gli artisti, le spese di organizzazione e il lavoro finora fatto dai nostri videomaker, grafici e comunicatori per dare corpo ed anima all'evento... organizzare un festival mette tante risorse ed energie in campo!

Dai un'occhiata alla colonna qui a destra per scoprire che cosa abbiamo preparato per ringraziarti del tuo contributo.

Non puoi contribuire economicamente? Il tuo impegno può comunque fare la differenza: parla del progetto, diffondilo condividendo questa pagina progetto Indiegogo sui social e parlane a quante più persone possibile; aiutaci a far conoscere la nostra proposta.

Ti invitiamo a seguirci su facebook e sul nostro sito per sapere come andrà avanti questa avventura: pubblicheremo infatti continui aggiornamenti, news ed approfondimenti sul festival ed i suoi protagonisti.

Se ami Milano e ami l'improvvisazione, diventa MITICO!

Ci piacerebbe uscire dallo schermo e abbracciarti, ma ci limitiamo per ora a dirti GRAZIE!

Ti aspettiamo a Milano dal 1 al 7 Luglio 2015!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

BE MITICO! The international exposition of improv theatre in Milan

Here we are, finally! 2015 is the year! From July 1st to July 7th a big event will take place: the Milano International Theatresports™ Institute Conference - MITICO, a week of international improvisation with workshops, panels, shows and a lot of amazing events happening during EXPO 2015.

www.mitico2015.it/milano/en/

The event has a global cultural meaning, involving artists and professionals coming from all the world, welcoming them in our country, making them meet with each other and with the italian improvisers, giving them the opportunity to experience the festival and know the hosting town, performing shows for EXPO visitors.

A unique chanche, Milano is the third stage of a worldwide acknowledged festival, organized by the International Theatresports™ Institute chaired by Keith Johnstone, previously produced in Calgary (CAN) in 2011 and in Würzburg (GER) in 2013.

We want to valorise Milan and Italy, putting on events in the whole town, accessible to all the english speaking people that will be in town for the EXPO.

The event has garnered interest from the City of Milan which sponsors the initiative. MITICO events are included in EXPO IN THE CITY, that coordinates and promotes all cultural and recreational events taking place in Greater Milan during Expo 2015.

Who are we

Associazione Muse is a cultural organization dedited since 2005 to the creation and promotion of artistic and cultural projects. MITICO is conceived and developed together with the Improv school Teatribù of Milan.

Why are we looking for your help?

Your contribution will not go unrewarded: we prepared a list of special perks for our supporters, Italian as well as international: autographed t-shirts as well as exclusive workshops, full access special passes, even a dedicated show at your homeplace. If you are a real fanatic you can become our main sponsor!

The collected funds will be vital to help us cover the main expenses such as: location rent, meals and accommodation for the artists and help for the expenses we are sustaining while organizing, like the production of graphics and video... The organization of a Festival is a wonderful experience involving many resources and energies!

Take a look at the perks listed here on the right to find out more about your rewards!

What if you can’t donate? No problem, your help can still mean a lot to us! Help us get the word out, we're always looking for more supporters; share this campaign on your social channels and talk about it to as many people as possible. Help us make some noise around our project!

Follow us on facebook and on our website to always get the latest news about our adventure: we will keep our channels up to date and publish highlights and trivia about the event and its protagonists.

If you love Milan and you love improv, BE MITICO!

It would be amazing to be able to hug you; right now we'd love to say a huge THANK YOU!

And see you in Milan between 1th and 7th July 2015!

diventa MITICO!
Ci piacerebbe uscire dallo schermo e abbracciarti, ma ci limitiamo per ora a dirti GRAZIE!
Ti aspettiamo a Milano
dal 1 al 7 Luglio 2015!------------------------------------------------------------------------------


BE
MITICO! The
international exposition of improv theatre in Milan


Here
we are, finally! 2015 is the year! From July 1st
to July 7th
a big event will take place: the Milano
International Theatresports™ Institute Conference - MITICO,
a
week of international improvisation with workshops, panels, shows and
a lot of amazing events
happening during EXPO 2015.www.mitico2015.it/milano/en/

The
event has a global cultural meaning, involving artists and
professionals coming from all the world, welcoming them in our
country, making them meet with each other and with the italian
improvisers, giving them the opportunity to experience the festival
and know the hosting town, performing  shows for EXPO
visitors. 


A
unique chanche, Milano is the third stage of a worldwide acknowledged
festival, organized by the International Theatresports™ Institute chaired by Keith Johnstone, previously produced in Calgary (CAN) in 2011 and in
Würzburg (GER) in 2013.

We
want to valorise Milan and Italy, putting on events in the whole
town, accessible to all the english speaking people that will be in
town for the EXPO.

The
event has garnered interest from the City of Milan which sponsors the
initiative. MITICO events are included in EXPO IN THE CITY, that
coordinates and
promotes all cultural and recreational events taking place in Greater
Milan during Expo 2015.


Who
are we

Associazione
Muse is a cultural organization dedited since 2005 to the creation and promotion of artistic and cultural
projects. MITICO is conceived and developed together with the Improv
school Teatribù of Milan.

Why are we looking for your help?
Your contribution will not go
unrewarded: we prepared a list of special perks for our supporters,
Italian as well as international: autographed t-shirts as well as
exclusive workshops, full access special passes, even a dedicated
show at your homeplace. If you are a real fanatic you can become our
main sponsor!The collected funds will be vital to help us
cover the main expenses such as: location rent, meals and
accommodation for the artists and help for the expenses we are
sustaining while organizing, like the production of graphics and
video... The organization of a Festival is a wonderful experience
involving many resources and energies!Take
a look at the perks listed here on the right to find out more about
your rewards!What
if you can’t donate? No problem, your help can still mean a lot to
us! Help us get the word
out, we're always looking for more supporters; share this campaign on
your social channels and talk about it to as many people as possible.
Help us make some noise around our project!Follow
us on 
facebook and on our website  to always get the latest news about our adventure: we
will keep our channels up to date and publish highlights and trivia
about the event and its protagonists.If
you love Milan and you love improv, BE MITICO!It would be
amazing to be able to hug you; right now we'd
love to say a huge THANK
YOU!
And see you in Milan between
1th and 7th July 2015!

story:
Love Me Tinder is an musical sketch comedy revue that pops the ultimate Valentine’s Day question - swipe left or swipe right? Love Me Tinder features original songs like:
  • Hey Siri
  • I Have a Boyfriend
  • He Belongs to Me
  • Spice it Up
  • On Valentine's Day
  • Save Your Load
  • Bodies are Gross

Love Me Tinder is written by the ensemble cast, composer/musicians Brian Kremer and Ammon Taylor, with help from director Adrienne Dawes, choreographer Lisa Hueske, and secret weapon Ward Crockett (Chicago -based writer/filmmaker). 

Our ensemble cast includes Cene Hale, Minerva Villa, Jillian Summar, Jared Robertson, David Nguyen, and Chris Hatcher. Each and every one can "actually sing." 

We crushed our first fringe festival performance (FronteraFest Short Fringe 2015 - Best of Week). We crushed performances at INdustry Night, TNM Tonight, our first comedy festival (Out of Bounds) and hosting/performing in our own musical comedy cabaret (HOOT!). 

Now we need your help to crush one final crushthing: a full length show in February 2016.


YOUR DONATIONS HELP!

Our budget is small. Your donations help pay for the items we can't borrow, barter or "borrow" (also known as stealing): expenses like our venue rental (SVT's Studio Theater), marketing, and small stipends for our performers, musicians, choreographer, ASL interpreters (YES!!!), and crew. 


STRETCH YOUR LOVE!

Any little bit you can give helps - any BIG gift helps us do EVEN MORE. Extra funding from this campaign can help us increase artist stipends (yo, they TINY!), support our next big project, or even take Love Me Tinder on the road to a comedy festival near you!  


ABOUT HECKLE HER

Heckle Her is an independent comedy company in Austin, TX led by award-winning playwright/producer Adrienne Dawes. We make the work we'd like to see more of in Austin - musical comedy projects that feature diverse perspectives with women and people of color as lead collaborators.   www.heckleher.com @heckleher

#DONTHATEDONATE

story:
The world premiere of a radical new dance theater work set inside the mind of WHISTLEBLOWER Bradley/Chelsea Manning as (s)he awaits court-martialing & sentencing after leaking state secrets.



who/what/where/when

Bessie and Obie Award Winning choreographer Mark Dendy's latest work Whistleblower takes place in the mind of Chelsea Manning at the moment of her sentencing in a controversial trial in which she was found guilty of espionage for leaking proof of US war crimes in Iraq and Afghanistan and divulging State Department Secrets.

Whistleblower is an impressionistic piece that is a free associative Fantasia. It does not attempt to tell a linear story or a factual history. It draws from the personal history of the performers, the biographical material of its protagonist and court room transcripts. It utilizes found dialogue, internet chatter, Brecht, Kafka,  and diverse dance styles. Text and gestural vocabularies combine with projections, set and costumes by Stephen Donovan, original music by Heather Christian and lyrics by Mark Dendy - all coming together in a multimedia production that makes no attempt to make sense of something that already makes no sense at all.  Whistleblower is designed to operate as dream logic, appealing to the subconscious more than to the rational mind. There is no wrong interpretation of this work. It is multi-layered, juxtaposing several different scenes at the same time for a split focus effect. 

PERFORMED BY

Chris Bell, Mark Dendy, Stephen Donovan, Rebecca Lubart, Mei Yamanaka             and introducing Liv Bruce as Chelsea/Bradley Manning.                   

 Plus video cameo appearances by special guest performers.

DIXON PLACE

September 11, 12, 18, 19, 25 and 26 at 7:30pm


WHISTLEBLOWER investigates and juxtaposes two types of secrets: Secrets of State that are to be protected at all costs and Biological Secrets of being transsexual. Manning's trans identity sets her apart from the boundaries of the heteronormative binary gender society we live in and puts her in a unique position to be the Whistleblower. 

The piece asks the questions: What defines a traitor; a patriot? What and who defines gender? The dialogue between the internal and external states of being transgendered in the world is explored. State Secrets and gender secrets intersect and collaborate to create a true American hero.


Chelsea Manning is serving 35 years in Leavenworth prison for releasing and exposing war crimes and diplomatic embarrassments spanning over 10 years.


If you believe that art and artists should be a part of the political and national dialogue, especially when it comes to war crimes and unjust imprisonment. Please Give Us Your Support!!!



Mark Dendy Projects is fiscally sponsored by The Field so all your contributions are tax-deductible where stated.


How funds will be used

After our commission fee, private donations and grants -

We need YOU to raise the remaining $14,000 to complete our budget.

We are need $14,000 more for the following uses:

  • The majority of money raised will go towards performers' rehearsal and performance fees. We are rehearsing for five weeks, have a week of tech/dress and 6 performances. Each performer is paid a performance fee.
  • We also have to insure our artists, so above and beyond the artists' fees, we have to raise monies to cover Insurance and Workers Comp.
  • We are splitting our rehearsal between Dixon Place and Fourth Arts Block and need money to pay for rehearsal space at Fourth Arts Block.
  • Funds raised will also underwrite our composer Heather Christian's creative fee, travel, rehearsal and recording fees.
  • Design fees, set, props and costume materials and purchases.
  • Video post production, equipment purchase and rental.



the history

Whistleblower has been in development since 2012 and is part 2 of a trilogy tilted Dystopian Distractions!  Part 1 premiered at DANCEWORKS, Santa Barbara in April 2014.

"I created this series of work because I was concerned that little work is being made in the modern dance community about war. I was appalled to learn that the “sick” reality show, Here Comes Honey Boo Boo, got higher ratings than did the final presidential debate in 2012! It appeared to me that Americans would rather be distracted from reality than be engaged in it. Taking aim at the dangerous foibles and hypocrisies of our time, I make politics palatable for an audience, sweetening the pot with humor as needed." -- Mark Dendy


the risks & challenges

The biggest inherent risk is getting butts in seats every night.  There is stiff competition among alternative performance spaces for a finite amount of theatre goers. 

In addition, there are sure to be unforeseen expenses - especially when it comes to last minute costume and set changes. Furthermore, there is always the potential for the need for extra rehearsal which would incur fees for space and artist overtime.

The biggest challenge is making a work that appeals to the populace while maintaining experimental integrity.


other ways to help

Other ways you can help is to spread the word and come see us perform.

  • use the social media to share this project - Tweet, Instagram, Facebook, e-mail  text, make phone calls, write letters, tell friends in person.
  • come see the show at Dixon Place 161a Chrystie Street, New York, NY 10002  - September 11, 12, 18, 19, 25 and 26 at 7:30pm.


Mark Dendy Projects is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Mark Dendy Projects are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
This play is dedicated to everyone in the Bronx
                              who punched me or kissed me,
                    and to everyone whom I punched or kissed.
                                      - John Patrick Shanley

So this is how it works...

Danny and the Deep Blue Sea was first written and presented by John Patrick Shanley in 1983. It hit the New York stage later in 1984, and has been making waves ever since.  This spring, under the direction of Seth Reich, with actors Peter Romano (Danny) and Angela Sperazza (Roberta), the three are coming together to bring this story to the Schapiro Theatre at Columbia University in Morningside Heights. 

So, why perform this play?  Angela, Peter, and Seth have been classmates at Columbia University's MFA Acting Program for the last three years. They have worked together through a multitude of scenes, genres, styles, and character journeys. This work has allowed them to understand each other and each of their strengths in a very specific way. Upon doing research for their recent actor showcase, Peter and Angela found Danny and the Deep Blue Sea...both of them knew that they had found something incredibly special. They enlisted Seth as director, knowing that he could help them find their truth and create a world that these two characters could live.

Seth, being an established director, saw this was an opportunity to bring a piece of theatre to a community that would resonate with its audience. 

CREATIVE TEAM:

Seth Reich, Director
Niky Wolcz, Choreographer
Corrie Beth Shotwell, Production Stage Manage 

Joe Novak, Lighting Designer

Michael Hajek, Set Dresser 

Folami Williams,  Producing Associate

                                                  Blackbox Productions, Videography


The Show...

Two people so rarely find each other at the right moment in time. But when they do, there's no telling what can happen. Danny and the Deep Blue Sea explores two people who desperately want a second chance at a better life.  Danny and Roberta are willing to fight, literally and figuratively, to find the love and companionship they so desperately need. In an aggressive yet sensitive dance, this play explores the beautiful complexities of love and relationships between two troubled loners who accidently find one another.  Shanley pushes the limits and finds a balance between sex and violence in this incredibly provocative play.

Why Danny and the Deep Blue Sea? 

What We Need... 

Support! We are raising $1700.00 to support all aspects of the production of the show. Your assistance will help to fund:

Performance rights to present the play 

Personnel- Actors/Director/Designers/Producers/Managers (although we love our craft, we believe that no one should have to work for free)

Scenic/Prop design elements 

Production of video footage used in the performance

Marketing outreach

                       THE CAST:

Angela Sperazza (Roberta)

                                                    

 Peter Romano (Danny)


THE DIRECTOR:

                                           

                                                                  Seth Reich (Director)

What is an Apache Dance?

It is called the Dance of Death. The Tough Dance. The Dance of the underworld. It, is the wild violent Apache Dance.

 Pronounced ah-PAHSH not uh-PATCH-ee, like the English pronunciation of the Native American Tribe, the name is taken from the Les Apache a notorious and brazen Parisian gang. Its members were skilled thieves and murderers. Strangling, knifing, brass knuckle fights, and shootings were common activities among gang members and were often carried out in broad day light. 

The Apache Dance is rage set to music.  It is a dance that evokes the image of a heated struggle between two lovers. 

  

A few words from Danny and Roberta!

Don't Worry....There are other ways you can help!

There are many ways to show your support.  Please let other people know about the production! Just by spreading the word on Facebook, Twitter, and word of mouth, you will be showing your support in a great way.

Come and watch the show...obviously!  There are only five performances, we hope that you can be with us for at least one of them!

Make sure to check out our Facebook page and look for pictures on Instagram and Twitter!

Danny and the Deep Blue Sea: An Apache Dance is presented by special arrangement with Dramatists Play Service, Inc., New York.

story:
Who (and what) is KTO Productions?

My name is Doug Knoop, I'm a Seattle native with deep roots in the local theater scene. Since my return to Seattle after college I've performed and directed all over the Puget Sound area.  I formed KTO Productions to allow myself and other artists to stretch beyond their "comfort zones" and to create and perform projects they are passionate about.

In the fall of 2011, our inaugural production of Conor McPherson’s “The Weir” was a crowd pleaser and a critical success. In 2012 we presented "'night mother" by Marsha Norman. Talkin' Broadway called it "as gripping a 90 minutes as can be seen on any Seattle stage..." while Jerry Kraft of SeattleActor.com said the show was “absolutely genuine and it left me genuinely moved.” In 2013 we presented Gardner McKay's romantic drama "Sea Marks" and in 2014 we were part of [Boxed], a co-op production with LungFish Productions, STAGEright Theatre, Confrontational Theatre, Clutch Theatre, Bradetta Doyle-Vines, Dan Davidson and Emily Harvey.

Why "Molly Sweeney"?

Brian Friel's 1994 drama tells the story of Molly, blind since early infancy, who describes her world before and after an operation to restore some of her sight. It's been on high on our "to-do" list for a long time.

Where is the money going?

Our first goal is to cover the rental of the rehearsal and performance spaces ($1,500-$2,000), Beyond that we are hoping to cover performance rights, technical needs (set, lighting) and basic publicity costs ($750-$1000).

And of course, we would love to pay our actors and stage manager a decent stipend. 

What you get

The perks:

$10 - Our heartfelt thanks, plus shout-outs on our Facebook page and Twitter feed.

$25 - All of the above, plus a mention on our Web site and in our program as "Indigogo donor."

$50 - All of the above, plus two tickets to the show and a copy of the program signed by the cast.

$75 - All of the above, plus two tickets to our next production in 2016 (title TBA).

$100 - All of the above plus a show poster signed by the cast and director.

$250 - All of the above, plus an additional pair of tickets to our 2016 production, and dinner for two with the producer (and schedule permitting, the director and cast) of the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love it if you can contribute, but we know that times are tough. Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word! Share this link on Facebook, Google+, Twitter or Tumblr. Tell your friends, send a text, make a call, write a letter.
  • We are still seeking a sound designer. Also if you have a special skill or talent you would like to volunteer, let us know.
  • Contact us at ktoproductions@earthlink.net

Thank you!

Many thanks for helping us bring this project to life. We appreciate your support and generosity.
story_txt:
Who (and what) is KTO Productions?
My name is Doug Knoop, I'm a Seattle native with deep roots in the local
theater scene. Since my return to Seattle after college I've performed and
directed all over the Puget Sound area.  I formed KTO Productions to allow
myself and other artists to stretch beyond their "comfort zones" and
to create and perform projects they are passionate about.
In the fall of 2011, our inaugural production of Conor McPherson’s “The
Weir” was a crowd pleaser and a critical success. In 2012 we presented "'night
mother" by Marsha Norman. Talkin' Broadway called it "as
gripping a 90 minutes as can be seen on any Seattle stage..." while Jerry
Kraft of SeattleActor.com said the show was “absolutely genuine and it
left me genuinely moved.” In 2013 we presented Gardner McKay's romantic drama "Sea
Marks" and in 2014 we were part of [Boxed], a co-op production
with LungFish Productions, STAGEright Theatre,
Confrontational Theatre, Clutch Theatre, Bradetta Doyle-Vines, Dan Davidson
and Emily Harvey. 
Why "Molly Sweeney"?

Brian
Friel's 1994 drama tells the story of Molly, blind since early infancy, who
describes her world before and after an operation to restore some of her sight. It's been on high on our "to-do" list for a long time.Where is the money going?
Our
first goal is to cover the rental of the rehearsal and performance spaces
($1,500-$2,000), Beyond that we are hoping to cover performance rights,
technical needs (set, lighting) and basic publicity costs ($750-$1000).
And of
course, we would love to pay our actors and stage manager a decent
stipend. 
What you get
The perks:
$10 - Our heartfelt thanks, plus shout-outs on our Facebook page and Twitter
feed.
$25 - All of the above, plus a mention on our Web site and in our program as
"Indigogo donor."
$50 - All of the above, plus two tickets to the show and a copy of the
program signed by the cast.
$75 - All of the above, plus two tickets to our next production in 2016
(title TBA).
$100 - All of the above plus a show poster signed by the cast and director.
$250 - All of the above, plus an additional pair of tickets to our 2016
production, and dinner for two with the producer (and schedule permitting, the
director and cast) of the show.Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love it if you can contribute, but we know that times are tough. Here are some other ways you can help:

Spread the word! Share this link on Facebook, Google+, Twitter or 
Tumblr. Tell your friends, send a text, make a call, write a letter.
We are still seeking a sound designer. Also if you have a special skill or talent you would like to volunteer, let us know.
Contact us at ktoproductions@earthlink.net

Thank you!
Many thanks for helping us bring this project to life. We appreciate your support and generosity.

story:
British theatre director Amy Bonsall and Malawian writer Stanley Kenani are collaborating to translate Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet into Chichewa, and tour it around Malawi. Please help us to support this unique project.


  • You will be helping to fund the first ever production of a poetic translation of Romeo and Juliet into Chichewa.
  • You will be supporting the best of Malawi's actors and graduate actors.
  • You will be giving hundreds of Malawians (many of whom do not speak English) the opportunity to see Romeo and Juliet in  their own language.
  • Thousands of students will have online access to a poetic translation of one of Shakespeare's great plays in their own language. 

What we need

We are asking for £2500 which breaks down as follows:

  • 9 actors = £150 pp = £1350 for 3 weeks rehearsal plus 3 performances plus £30pp for meals and travel = £270
  • 1 writer payment = £150
  • 1 assistant director payment £150
  • transport for tour and fuel = £280
  • set/costumes = £300

About the project

Shakespeare has been popular in Malawi for over 100 years and his plays are widely studied, Romeo and Juliet being the current curriculum text. However, with English as a second language, many students find Shakespeare hard to understand and enjoy. Bilimankhwe Arts has engaged Caine Prize nominated Malawian writer, Stanley Onjezani Kenani to produce a poetic translation of Romeo and Juliet to be performed at Chancellor College in Malawi in April 2016. 

The production will have a Malawian cast, drawing from the very best of Malawi's professional actors and students from Chancellor College's Performing Arts Department. It will be directed by international theatre director Amy Bonsall with a Malawian assistant director. 

Students in Malawi currently only have access to English versions of Romeo and Juliet and this is an amazing opportunity to give them a translation in Chichewa, the most widely spoken language in Malawi. The educational impact of this is huge and teachers, students, academics, theatre practitioners and artists throughout Malawi overwhelmingly support this project. The British Council in Malawi has pledged to support the project by making the text available online. This really is an opportunity for you to support the making of theatre history.

The impact of your donation

The translation

This project is the first time Shakespeare has been translated by a recognised international Malawian writer into one of the major languages of Malawi. Audiences have previously only had access to English versions of Romeo and Juliet and this is an amazing opportunity for them to be able to access Shakespeare in Chichewa. 

Having run workshops at Chancellor College with the performing Arts students, Amy was struck by the difference it made to the students to work with the text in Chichewa rather than English. They were able to use the wordplay, imagery and subtlety of the words in their performances, something they said had been much more difficult in English. 

We will publish the Chichewa and the English text alongside each other on the page. The text and translation will be clear and easy for the reader to follow the play in both languages, and move between the two. By making the production available online and publishing the play text, we will be able to reach many school students who are studying Romeo and Juliet. We have conducted research with teachers and students who have made it clear that this translation would be invaluable for them.

The production

This is an opportunity for you to be part of something unique:  Bilimankhwe is the only theatre company in the UK co-producing theatre with companies in Malawi. With years of experience of producing high quality international collaborations with both Malawi and South Africa you can rest assured that not only will your contribution make a huge difference, the resulting work will be of outstanding artistic quality.

About us


About Bilimankhwe

Bilimankhwe is a theatre company based in the UK with a sister company, Nanzikambe Arts, who are based in Blantyre, Malawi. Bilimankhwe was established in 2006 by Kate Stafford,  a theatre director who has worked extensively in Malawi, and set up Nanzikambe during her time there. Since then Bilimankhwe has produced international productions, working with organisations such as UK Arts International, The Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, Chickenshed Theatre, The Africa Centre and The Commonwealth Foundation. Bilimankhwe has been supported by Arts Council England, The British Council and many other Trusts and Foundations. 

There are so many amazing performance artists in Malawi producing fantastic work. Nanzikambe Arts has been active in producing professional theatre since 2003. This project is a continuation of the international partnership between Bilimankhwe and  Nanzikambe, developing and expanding the range of productions available to people in Malawi. 

Bilimankhwe has produced a version of Romeo and Juliet before, that incorporated Chichewa and aspects of Malawian culture. The production and the tour were so successful that it became clear there was a large appetite for a properly poetic translation of the play. 

About Amy

Amy Bonsall is the associate artistic director of Bilimankhwe and a highly experienced international theatre director. Her productions have been seen in Australia, Italy, Thailand and Malawi as well as the UK. During her career she has worked with some of theatre's greatest names, including Dame Janet Suzman at the Baxter Theatre South Africa and the Royal Shakespeare Company; Ray Cooney and Moises Kaufman in London's West End. She is also half way through a PhD at Leeds University: this production will form part of her research. 

She worked on a production of Romeo and Juliet for Bilimankhwe in 2011, which was performed for the Shakespeare's Birthplace Trust in Stratford, and toured Malawi. She has been to Chancellor College in Zomba for a Research & Development trip, workshopping the text with Drama students there, and is hugely looking forward to developing the work further.

About Stanley

Stanley Onjezani Kenani is a Malawian writer of poetry and short stories. He has performed at the Arts Alive Festival in Johannesburg, South Africa, Poetry Africa in Durban, South Africa, Harare International Festival of the Arts in Harare, Zimbabwe, and at the Struga Poetry Evenings in Macedonia. From 2004 to 2007, Stanley served as president of the Malawi Writers Union. He also serves as acting treasurer for the Pan African Writers' Association. 

He has won and been nominated for several prestigious writing prizes, including a Caine Prize nomination for his story Love on Trial. This was adapted by Bilimankhwe into a play in 2012, performed at Ovalhouse, London. Stanley is passionate about poetry, and excited about the prospect of creating a truly Malawian translation of Shakespeare's poetic love story.


Last but not least!

If you are not able to help financially, we totally understand. But please remember we still need your help! You can tell your friends, tweet and retweet about the campaign, use the Indegogo share tools, and support us on Facebook. And, if you are in Malawi, you can come and see the show!
