story:
THANK YOU EVERYONE FOR SUPPORTING "BREAKING LEGS"!

Our campaign is over, but if you would still like to contribute, please send check or money order to:

Ditch Pitchures

2200 23rd St. #B

Santa Monica, CA 90405

OR

via paypal: castingmusicalfilm@gmail.com

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Welcome Back all your R Murray High School Fans!!! We're racing down the finish line with our third and final campaign for "Breaking Legs." This one will be exclusively used for the post-production of our "little movie that could." This is really where all the magic happens. As soon as we get some dough in the bank we'll be able to show you clips from the movie! How exciting is that! So whether it's $1 or $100 you can donate, every little bit helps! Now on with the show...

     


"Footloose" Meets "Mean Girls"

After the death of her mother, high school freshman Bloom moves in with her hapless uncle (Mark Marchillo) and feeble grandma (Lee Meriwether). With little support and encouragement at her disposal, she struggles to find her footing while adjusting to small town life. A dancer by nature, Bloom (Liv Southard) is determined to find an outlet for her despair, but there's nowhere to dance in this backwoods town - except the school dance team! Just as she's trying to fit in, the boyfriend of the team’s captain falls for her, catapulting Bloom into the spotlight against her soon-to-be arch nemesis. Bloom will have to fight to win her place, not only on the team, but with her new family, even if she has to "break a leg."

Listen to us talk about our influences and our love for the '80s, especially dance films! http://crowdfundingcast.tk/crowdfunding-cast-ep...


 

Why I Made Breaking Legs? Get The Real Story!

Ok, so Breaking Legs has been a long time coming. A LONG time... When I was 6 years old, I enrolled in dance classes at my own insistence because I knew I wanted to be in the movies. My father was a big film buff, and I was inspired by the stylings of Gene Kelly, Fred Astaire and Donald O’Connor; by great movies like Gone With The Wind and Kings Row, Rebecca and Peyton Place. In 2nd grade I got my first leading role in the epic Twain Harte Elementary play, “Soup for the King”, and I was off and running. Within four years I was dancing on scholarship in Los Angeles and Marin County, and eventually trained at the San Francisco Ballet school year round.

Throughout all this time, my poor mom had to shuttle me from place to place, saying goodbye for months at a time and inevitably move to San Francisco with me. The sacrifices she made motivated me to push even further, and, after several professional stage productions, I went on to study at the USC film school. All that time I was following my passion for acting and dancing, and then, directing, but I never really fit in during school. Being a boy in a girl’s world, was not acceptable at the time. Hence, I wanted to make a modern day story about a girl's struggle to fit in.

This is what inspired me to make Breaking Legs, a coming of age story of triumph & perseverance with the social message of you can do anything if you put your mind to it! It's a great mix of struggle and comedy, because no matter how bad it gets, you can always still laugh. No one can take that away from you!

I was bound and determined to make my first feature film this year. After about a decade of waiting around, thinking that some magical investor fairy was someday going to show up, I finally just decided it was now or never. And we did it! Well, almost. So long story short, I knew I had to make this movie no matter what. The script shaped up fast, and things started falling into place. But there still wasn’t money… But knowing that delaying production would probably end in defeat, I created the money out of thin air. In other words, I bled my 401K, and put together two other sources to make enough money to get us all the way through production. 

And thank God, it worked; well, almost. We still have 3 more scenes to shoot with celebrity talent! So now, we’re entering post production, and this is where we need your help! We'll need sound design, color correction, sound mix, music rights, composer fees, digital fees, more film expenses… well, it adds up like you wouldn’t believe. 

This a big dream of mine, and I can’t tell you how happy I am even now; it’s all coming true! I hope you can help us get to the finish line. Any amount of generosity is another step forward in me achieving my lifelong dream. We'll reward you for your generosity with schwag from the film, tickets to the screening, DVD's, Posters, and even a chance to be in the movie & become one of the film's producers (how cool is that!). I hope you're able to check out the trailer for a glimpse of greatness; this little movie that could, really can be. Thank you for being a part of Breaking Legs, you'll be glad that you did!

~MARK MARCHILLO (WRITER/DIRECTOR)

 

 

Lee Ann Meriwether (GRAMMA) is an American actress, former model, and the winner of the 1955 Miss America pageant. She is perhaps best known for her role as Betty Jones, Buddy Ebsen's secretary and daughter-in-law in the long-running 1970s crime drama Barnaby Jones. The role earned her two Golden Globe Awardnominations in 1975 and 1976, and an Emmy Award nomination in 1977. She is also known for her role as John Schuck's long-haired wife, Lily Munster, in the 1980ssitcom The Munsters Today, as well as for her portrayal of Catwoman in the 1966 film version of Batman. Meriwether had a recurring role as Ruth Martin on the daytime soap opera All My Children until the end of the series in September 2011.

 

Chris Kattan (ROBBIE) is an American actor/comedian, best known for his work on Saturday Night Live and his role as Bob on the first four seasons of The Middle. He is also known for playing Doug Butabi in A Night at the Roxbury. 

Kattan attended high school in Seattle where he performed in a number of school plays. He decided to follow in his father's footsteps and returned to the L.A. area to join The Groundlings, while studying acting and directing at the University of California at Northridge. He continued to perform in live theater productions while in college.

It wasn't long before Chris was spotted by a producer of Saturday Night Live, and in 1996, he joined the cast.

While working on the legendary show, Kattan created many memorable characters, including: the Roxbury Guy, the half-monkey Mr. Peepers, the gibberish-spouting Suel Forrester, Azrael Abyss, the co-host of the fictional cable access show "Goth Talk”, and the enigmatic exotic dancer, Mango.

Kattan went on to land many more roles in feature films such as House On Haunted Hill, Lucky Numbers and Monkeybone.

Besides film and SNL, Kattan has also guest-starred on several network television programs, including NewsRadio and Grace Under Fire.

He remained an SNL cast member until 2003. Currently he lives in Los Angeles and is concentrating on his film career, with roles in independent features such asSanta's Slay (2005) and Christmas in Wonderland (2007).

In June 2014, Chris reprised his role as former SNL character Mango in a preview of Missy Elliott protégée Sharaya J's "Shut It Down" via a T by Alexander Wang campaign.

 

With his mustache, receding hairline and somewhat portly frame, Richard Riehle(PRINCIPAL BATER) has often been cast as corrupt characters whose bravado melts in the face of adversity, He spent over 15 years working in repertory theaters in Oregon, Alaska, Arizona and elsewhere, in addition to teaching acting in Northern California and at the University of Washington. Riehle ventured to Broadway in 1985 and beginning a career as a working character player. After debuting in "Execution of Justice", a play based on the murder of Harvey Milk, he remained in New York and often worked with the Classic Stage Company and the Public Theatre. Roles in the movies "Black Rain" and "Glory" (both 1989) and the miniseries "Cross of Fire" (NBC, 1989) convinced him to move to Los Angeles. It was his part in "Glory" that actually put Riehle on the potential casting lists in Hollywood. Riehle went on to give a memorable portrayal of the Reverend Scroggins who twists the truth on the witness stand in Jon Avnet's "Fried Green Tomatoes" (1991). In 1993, he was the older guard who survives the train crash with Richard Kimball in "The Fugitive" and also appeared as a member of the panel in "Jury Duty" and in a small role in "Casino" (both 1995). It wasn't until Mike Judge's, cult classic, "Office Space" (1999) hit VHS that people really started to recognize Richard and even so far as quoting lines from the movie. 

 

Liv Southard (BLOOM) is an actress, known for "Visions" (2013), 
"The Curse of the Un-Kissable Kid" (2013), "Tuesday" (2013) and the web series "Horror Haiku" (Seraph Films). Liv booked her first theatrical role following her very first LA audition, as a principal/lead in the independent science-fiction feature film THEM for Onward Motion Pictures in Fall 2012. She was nominated for a Young Actors Award in 2014 for Best Actress in a Short Film for her work on "The Curse of the Un-Kissable Kid", by Mark Marchillo. Her short film, "Tuesday", by Oscar Lalo, has been in 43 festivals world-wide winning multiple awards, including The American Pavilion Best Short Film, at Cannes Film Festival 2014. She also co-starred on the TV series "Twist of Fate" (The Weather Channel).

 

Aaron Landon (JAKE) is an accomplished actor most recently starring as the series regular character “Pesto”, in the new Disney Channel hit, "Crash And Bernstein". His credits also include the recurring role of Young Nick on the popular show "New Girl" on Fox TV, "The House of Lies" for Showtime, and the part of Young Irving Thalberg in “Paul Merton’s Birth of Hollywood” for the BBC. His rocker talents landed him a commercial for Kidz Bop as well as the part of Mini Brandon in a video for Panic At The Disco.  He recently had fun appearing as The Bully on an episode of “The Jimmy Kimmel Show.”

In addition to his acting credits, Aaron has the vocal chops of a seasoned artist. He was recently awarded “Best Male Vocalist” by the LA Music Awards, being the youngest ever nominated and then to win the vote. LAMA President, Al Bowman stated “This kid is unbelievable! He blew me away!”  Prior to that, Aaron placed in the top 19 out of 40,000 submissions for the TV show “Majors & Minors”.  Aaron said, “The highlight of that process was when Gene Simmons and other Kiss members snuck up behind me on stage and sang their song, 'Beth' with me. I’ll never forget that.” He has been awarded Best Pop Rock Artist at an event with RK Records, Best Male Vocalist Rising Star at Hollywood Rock The Mic, and 1st Place in his category for SCV’s Most Talented Performers’ Competition. He has caught the eye of several music producers along the way. Life has been busy for Aaron, but he hopes to find time soon, to collaborate along with his creative director, Jonathan George on recording some new original work.

   

Sarah Rochelle (GRACIE) is a classically trained dancer and actor who is currently a junior at the esteemed Orange County School of the Arts. She was quickly noticed by Hollywood agents, was signed, and landed her first role as a lead in a Disney mini-series. She has worked as a dancer on ABC Family and in national commercials. She has since worked on numerous independent films in both lead and supporting roles, including the role of young Amy Winehouse in a documentary about the singer's personal life.

 

William Leon (HERBIE) is an actor with more than seven feature films under his belt, including: "Bukowski" (2015) with James Franco, "Camouflage" (2014), and "Don Quixote: The Ingenious Gentleman of La Mancha" (2015), and has co-starred in such notable TV series as "True Blood", "Modern Family", and "New Girl".  

       

Alexa Sutherland (HARMONY), a 16 year old Southern California native and a whirlwind talent. She has been acting and modeling since the age of 3 and is breaking into features with "Breaking Legs"! She graduated high school a year and a half early and is using the time to learn more about acting and is learning new talents along the way.

 

Kayley Stallings (CINDA) came to Los Angeles from Ohio with her family, to pursue her dreams of becoming an actress and singer at the age of 7.  She was immediately in the hands of good representation and after some commercial bookings and multiple short films, she landed the enviable role of Cindy Lou Who, in "The Grinch Who Stole Christmas" at the renowned PANTAGES THEATER, in Hollywood, CA.  She was only 9-years-old!  Her mark had been made and her love of performing live in front of an audience, singing and entertaining the crowd was born!  Since then, Kayley has been seen in numerous commercials and starred in ABC FAMILY TV's "The Dog Who Saved Halloween" and "The Dog Who Saved Christmas Vacation". Her latest film “The Martial Arts Kid” is scheduled to come to theaters summer 2015.  She plays the daughter of Cynthia Rothrock and Don the Dragon Wilson. She is scheduled to start filming the feature film "The Peculiar Perils of Penelope Peacock" in June 2015.  She will play the lead role of Guave.

Kayley has been writing and performing songs, since she was 8.  She released her first CD titled Gone in June, 2014.  It is available on itunes.  She is currently working with music producer Donte Boss and music promoter Big Spin Records.  Her first vocal performance was at the world famous Whiskey A Go Go with her band.  Since then, she has performed at multiple venues in and around Los Angeles.  She performs solo or with her band.  On top of singing, she also plays the guitar.

 

Maria Pallas (MISS TARBLE) has had a pretty diverse career so far: not only is she a former NFL cheerleader, but she has performed in 28+ countries with the USO, has several national commercials to her credit, and performs improv with UCB. She’s also shot several leading and supporting roles in independent films (where she sometimes gets eaten by zombies). A member of Antaeus theatre company A2, Maria holds a Graduate degree in acting from the University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign.

 

Lizz Carter (LALA) is a Los Angeles based Native American and English actress.  Originally from Oklahoma, Lizz began her professional acting career at a young age performing in stage shows and commercials.  After obtaining a BFA in Acting from The University of Southern California, Lizz began her pursuit of television and film, which provided her opportunity to work with talents such as Billy Bob Thornton, John Heder, Anna Farris and Hank Azaria, to name a few.  

Lizz has been seen on ABC's Nashville, Showtime's "Huff", hosting the fake morning show "Hey, L.A.!" on the real show "Legit" on FX Network and most recently completed a pilot for FOX with Jason Alexander and Michael Caleo.  Additionally, Lizz just wrapped two features, "Catching Faith" and "Breaking Legs" to be released later this year and early 2016.  She is also excited for the premiere of her performance in "Pop Star Puppy", which is set to be the Christmas family movie of the year.  Lizz has been part of award-winning films at both Sundance and the Toronto Film Festivals, and has worked with such directors as Todd Philips ("The Hangover"), Richard Linklater ("Boyhood"), Scott Wynant ("Californication") and Eric Kripke ("Revolution") for Paramount, Warner Brothers, The Weinstein Company and MGM.  In her spare time Lizz enjoys golfing, cooking and making people laugh.

 

Groundlings Theater actor Timothy Brennen (MR. SCHUSTER) not only stars alongside fellow Groundling’s alumni Jillian Bell and Charlotte Newhouse in "Idiotsitter" on Comedy Central, but his myriad of other credits include recurring roles on "Mad Men" and Jimmy Kimmel Live, Guest-Stars on "Criminal Minds" and "Hawaii Five-O", and Co-Starring roles on "New Girl", "How I Met Your Mother", "Aquarius", "The Kroll Show",  and "Real Husbands Of Hollywood".

"Breaking Legs" Promos!

 
 
  Sarah Rochelle (GRACIE) and William Leon (HERBIE) did a money rain dance! 

   

  It really does TAKE YOU to make this thing called "Breaking Legs" go right!
 
 

The moment when you think you'll get a part, & end up as the producer! #NextTime

The Impact - From Rags to Riches - We All Win!

Coming of Age Stories are those which really leave you feeling fluffy inside. Often done with passion and very little money, they generally aren't the big blockbusters of the summer. However, the blockbuster is the story itself. A prime example is the film called, "Once." This little Independent movie became a success, garnering over $9Million at the box-office, even though it was made for an Ultra Low Budget, like ours. This goes to show you that if you really tell a good story others' hearts will watch and follow.

Risks & Challenges - The Audience & The Fans - You!

Raising funds is not easy. However, having filmed most of the movie already, we are steps ahead of the rest. We have created these entertaining videos (which you have all seen by this time), a great trailer, and have tagged our product placement sponsors; reaching their market as well. The more we all get involved the more this film will get seen. It's all about social awareness. At the end of the day, it's the audience that benefit from donating or spreading the word about "Breaking Legs," the little film that could. This way we can keep making family friendly films and entertaining all audiences.

Post-Production Completion Funds


Your funds will go to the following areas of completing the post-production phase of the film:

Actor Salaries for ADR

Crew Salaries - Editor, Sound Design, Musical Composition, Song Licensing

Catering - Meals during the live recording of the soundtrack

Location Fees for sound studios, editing bays, etc.

Equipment rentals for editing and recording equipment
story_txt:
THANK YOU EVERYONE FOR SUPPORTING "BREAKING LEGS"!
Our campaign is over, but if you would still like to contribute, please send check or money order to:
Ditch Pitchures
2200 23rd St. #B
Santa Monica, CA 90405
OR
via paypal: castingmusicalfilm@gmail.com
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Welcome Back all your R Murray High School Fans!!! We're racing down the finish line with our third and final campaign for "Breaking Legs." This one will be exclusively used for the post-production of our "little movie that could." This is really where all the magic happens. As soon as we get some dough in the bank we'll be able to show you clips from the movie! How exciting is that! So whether it's $1 or $100 you can donate, every little bit helps! Now on with the show...
     
"Footloose" Meets "Mean Girls"
After the death of her mother, high school freshman Bloom moves in with her hapless uncle (Mark Marchillo) and feeble grandma (Lee Meriwether). With little support and encouragement at her disposal, she struggles to find her footing while adjusting to small town life. A dancer by nature, Bloom (Liv Southard) is determined to find an outlet for her despair, but there's nowhere to dance in this backwoods town - except the school dance team! Just as she's trying to fit in, the boyfriend of the team’s captain falls for her, catapulting Bloom into the spotlight against her soon-to-be arch nemesis. Bloom will have to fight to win her place, not only on the team, but with her new family, even if she has to "break a leg."
Listen to us talk about our influences and our love for the '80s, especially dance films! http://crowdfundingcast.tk/crowdfunding-cast-ep...

 Why I Made Breaking Legs? Get The Real Story!Ok, so Breaking Legs has been a long time coming. A LONG time... When I was 6 years old, I enrolled in dance classes at my own insistence because I knew I wanted to be in the movies. My father was a big film buff, and I was inspired by the stylings of Gene Kelly, Fred Astaire and Donald O’Connor; by great movies like Gone With The Wind and Kings Row, Rebecca and Peyton Place. In 2nd grade I got my first leading role in the epic Twain Harte Elementary play, “Soup for the King”, and I was off and running. Within four years I was dancing on scholarship in Los Angeles and Marin County, and eventually trained at the San Francisco Ballet school year round.
Throughout all this time, my poor mom had to shuttle me from place to place, saying goodbye for months at a time and inevitably move to San Francisco with me. The sacrifices she made motivated me to push even further, and, after several professional stage productions, I went on to study at the USC film school. All that time I was following my passion for acting and dancing, and then, directing, but I never really fit in during school. Being a boy in a girl’s world, was not acceptable at the time. Hence, I wanted to make a modern day story about a girl's struggle to fit in.This is what inspired me to make Breaking Legs, a coming of age story of triumph & perseverance with the social message of you can do anything if you put your mind to it! It's a great mix of struggle and comedy, because no matter how bad it gets, you can always still laugh. No one can take that away from you!
I was bound and determined to make my first feature film this year. After about a decade of waiting around, thinking that some magical investor fairy was someday going to show up, I finally just decided it was now or never. And we did it! Well, almost. So long story short, I knew I had to make this movie no matter what. The script shaped up fast, and things started falling into place. But there still wasn’t money… But knowing that delaying production would probably end in defeat, I created the money out of thin air. In other words, I bled my 401K, and put together two other sources to make enough money to get us all the way through production. 
And thank God, it worked; well, almost. We still have 3 more scenes to shoot with celebrity talent! So now, we’re entering post production, and this is where we need your help! We'll need sound design, color correction, sound mix, music rights, composer fees, digital fees, more film expenses… well, it adds up like you wouldn’t believe. 
This a big dream of mine, and I can’t tell you how happy I am even now; it’s all coming true! I hope you can help us get to the finish line. Any amount of generosity is another step forward in me achieving my lifelong dream. We'll reward you for your generosity with schwag from the film, tickets to the screening, DVD's, Posters, and even a chance to be in the movie & become one of the film's producers (how cool is that!). I hope you're able to check out the trailer for a glimpse of greatness; this little movie that could, really can be. Thank you for being a part of Breaking Legs, you'll be glad that you did!
~MARK MARCHILLO (WRITER/DIRECTOR)
 

 
Lee Ann Meriwether (GRAMMA) is an American actress, former model, and the winner of the 1955 Miss America pageant. She is perhaps best known for her role as Betty Jones, Buddy Ebsen's secretary and daughter-in-law in the long-running 1970s crime drama Barnaby Jones. The role earned her two Golden Globe Awardnominations in 1975 and 1976, and an Emmy Award nomination in 1977. She is also known for her role as John Schuck's long-haired wife, Lily Munster, in the 1980ssitcom The Munsters Today, as well as for her portrayal of Catwoman in the 1966 film version of Batman. Meriwether had a recurring role as Ruth Martin on the daytime soap opera All My Children until the end of the series in September 2011.

 
Chris Kattan (ROBBIE) is an American actor/comedian, best known for his work on Saturday Night Live and his role as Bob on the first four seasons of The Middle. He is also known for playing Doug Butabi in A Night at the Roxbury. 
Kattan attended high school in Seattle where he performed in a number of school plays. He decided to follow in his father's footsteps and returned to the L.A. area to join The Groundlings, while studying acting and directing at the University of California at Northridge. He continued to perform in live theater productions while in college.
It wasn't long before Chris was spotted by a producer of Saturday Night Live, and in 1996, he joined the cast.
While working on the legendary show, Kattan created many memorable characters, including: the Roxbury Guy, the half-monkey Mr. Peepers, the gibberish-spouting Suel Forrester, Azrael Abyss, the co-host of the fictional cable access show "Goth Talk”, and the enigmatic exotic dancer, Mango.
Kattan went on to land many more roles in feature films such as House On Haunted Hill, Lucky Numbers and Monkeybone.
Besides film and SNL, Kattan has also guest-starred on several network television programs, including NewsRadio and Grace Under Fire.
He remained an SNL cast member until 2003. Currently he lives in Los Angeles and is concentrating on his film career, with roles in independent features such asSanta's Slay (2005) and Christmas in Wonderland (2007).
In June 2014, Chris reprised his role as former SNL character Mango in a preview of Missy Elliott protégée Sharaya J's "Shut It Down" via a T by Alexander Wang campaign.
 With his mustache, receding hairline and somewhat portly frame, Richard Riehle(PRINCIPAL BATER) has often been cast as corrupt characters whose bravado melts in the face of adversity, He spent over 15 years working in repertory theaters in Oregon, Alaska, Arizona and elsewhere, in addition to teaching acting in Northern California and at the University of Washington. Riehle ventured to Broadway in 1985 and beginning a career as a working character player. After debuting in "Execution of Justice", a play based on the murder of Harvey Milk, he remained in New York and often worked with the Classic Stage Company and the Public Theatre. Roles in the movies "Black Rain" and "Glory" (both 1989) and the miniseries "Cross of Fire" (NBC, 1989) convinced him to move to Los Angeles. It was his part in "Glory" that actually put Riehle on the potential casting lists in Hollywood. Riehle went on to give a memorable portrayal of the Reverend Scroggins who twists the truth on the witness stand in Jon Avnet's "Fried Green Tomatoes" (1991). In 1993, he was the older guard who survives the train crash with Richard Kimball in "The Fugitive" and also appeared as a member of the panel in "Jury Duty" and in a small role in "Casino" (both 1995). It wasn't until Mike Judge's, cult classic, "Office Space" (1999) hit VHS that people really started to recognize Richard and even so far as quoting lines from the movie.  
Liv Southard (BLOOM) is an actress, known for "Visions" (2013), "The Curse of the Un-Kissable Kid" (2013), "Tuesday" (2013) and the web series "Horror Haiku" (Seraph Films). Liv booked her first theatrical role following her very first LA audition, as a principal/lead in the independent science-fiction feature film THEM for Onward Motion Pictures in Fall 2012. She was nominated for a Young Actors Award in 2014 for Best Actress in a Short Film for her work on "The Curse of the Un-Kissable Kid", by Mark Marchillo. Her short film, "Tuesday", by Oscar Lalo, has been in 43 festivals world-wide winning multiple awards, including The American Pavilion Best Short Film, at Cannes Film Festival 2014. She also co-starred on the TV series "Twist of Fate" (The Weather Channel). 
Aaron Landon (JAKE) is an accomplished actor most recently starring as the series regular character “Pesto”, in the new Disney Channel hit, "Crash And Bernstein". His credits also include the recurring role of Young Nick on the popular show "New Girl" on Fox TV, "The House of Lies" for Showtime, and the part of Young Irving Thalberg in “Paul Merton’s Birth of Hollywood” for the BBC. His rocker talents landed him a commercial for Kidz Bop as well as the part of Mini Brandon in a video for Panic At The Disco.  He recently had fun appearing as The Bully on an episode of “The Jimmy Kimmel Show.”In addition to his acting credits, Aaron has the vocal chops of a seasoned artist. He was recently awarded “Best Male Vocalist” by the LA Music Awards, being the youngest ever nominated and then to win the vote. LAMA President, Al Bowman stated “This kid is unbelievable! He blew me away!”  Prior to that, Aaron placed in the top 19 out of 40,000 submissions for the TV show “Majors & Minors”.  Aaron said, “The highlight of that process was when Gene Simmons and other Kiss members snuck up behind me on stage and sang their song, 'Beth' with me. I’ll never forget that.” He has been awarded Best Pop Rock Artist at an event with RK Records, Best Male Vocalist Rising Star at Hollywood Rock The Mic, and 1st Place in his category for SCV’s Most Talented Performers’ Competition. He has caught the eye of several music producers along the way. Life has been busy for Aaron, but he hopes to find time soon, to collaborate along with his creative director, Jonathan George on recording some new original work.
   
Sarah Rochelle (GRACIE) is a classically trained dancer and actor who is currently a junior at the esteemed Orange County School of the Arts. She was quickly noticed by Hollywood agents, was signed, and landed her first role as a lead in a Disney mini-series. She has worked as a dancer on ABC Family and in national commercials. She has since worked on numerous independent films in both lead and supporting roles, including the role of young Amy Winehouse in a documentary about the singer's personal life. 
William Leon (HERBIE) is an actor with more than seven feature films under his belt, including: "Bukowski" (2015) with James Franco, "Camouflage" (2014), and "Don Quixote: The Ingenious Gentleman of La Mancha" (2015), and has co-starred in such notable TV series as "True Blood", "Modern Family", and "New Girl".         
Alexa Sutherland (HARMONY), a 16 year old Southern California native and a whirlwind talent. She has been acting and modeling since the age of 3 and is breaking into features with "Breaking Legs"! She graduated high school a year and a half early and is using the time to learn more about acting and is learning new talents along the way.
 
Kayley Stallings (CINDA) came to Los Angeles from Ohio with her family, to pursue her dreams of becoming an actress and singer at the age of 7.  She was immediately in the hands of good representation and after some commercial bookings and multiple short films, she landed the enviable role of Cindy Lou Who, in "The Grinch Who Stole Christmas" at the renowned PANTAGES THEATER, in Hollywood, CA.  She was only 9-years-old!  Her mark had been made and her love of performing live in front of an audience, singing and entertaining the crowd was born!  Since then, Kayley has been seen in numerous commercials and starred in ABC FAMILY TV's "The Dog Who Saved Halloween" and "The Dog Who Saved Christmas Vacation". Her latest film “The Martial Arts Kid” is scheduled to come to theaters summer 2015.  She plays the daughter of Cynthia Rothrock and Don the Dragon Wilson. She is scheduled to start filming the feature film "The Peculiar Perils of Penelope Peacock" in June 2015.  She will play the lead role of Guave.
Kayley has been writing and performing songs, since she was 8.  She released her first CD titled Gone in June, 2014.  It is available on itunes.  She is currently working with music producer Donte Boss and music promoter Big Spin Records.  Her first vocal performance was at the world famous Whiskey A Go Go with her band.  Since then, she has performed at multiple venues in and around Los Angeles.  She performs solo or with her band.  On top of singing, she also plays the guitar.
 
Maria Pallas (MISS TARBLE) has had a pretty diverse career so far: not only is she a former NFL cheerleader, but she has performed in 28+ countries with the USO, has several national commercials to her credit, and performs improv with UCB. She’s also shot several leading and supporting roles in independent films (where she sometimes gets eaten by zombies). A member of Antaeus theatre company A2, Maria holds a Graduate degree in acting from the University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign.
 
Lizz Carter (LALA) is a Los Angeles based Native American and English actress.  Originally from Oklahoma, Lizz began her professional acting career at a young age performing in stage shows and commercials.  After obtaining a BFA in Acting from The University of Southern California, Lizz began her pursuit of television and film, which provided her opportunity to work with talents such as Billy Bob Thornton, John Heder, Anna Farris and Hank Azaria, to name a few.  Lizz has been seen on ABC's Nashville, Showtime's "Huff", hosting the fake morning show "Hey, L.A.!" on the real show "Legit" on FX Network and most recently completed a pilot for FOX with Jason Alexander and Michael Caleo.  Additionally, Lizz just wrapped two features, "Catching Faith" and "Breaking Legs" to be released later this year and early 2016.  She is also excited for the premiere of her performance in "Pop Star Puppy", which is set to be the Christmas family movie of the year.  Lizz has been part of award-winning films at both Sundance and the Toronto Film Festivals, and has worked with such directors as Todd Philips ("The Hangover"), Richard Linklater ("Boyhood"), Scott Wynant ("Californication") and Eric Kripke ("Revolution") for Paramount, Warner Brothers, The Weinstein Company and MGM.  In her spare time Lizz enjoys golfing, cooking and making people laugh. 
Groundlings Theater actor Timothy Brennen (MR. SCHUSTER) not only stars alongside fellow Groundling’s alumni Jillian Bell and Charlotte Newhouse in "Idiotsitter" on Comedy Central, but his myriad of other credits include recurring roles on "Mad Men" and Jimmy Kimmel Live, Guest-Stars on "Criminal Minds" and "Hawaii Five-O", and Co-Starring roles on "New Girl", "How I Met Your Mother", "Aquarius", "The Kroll Show",  and "Real Husbands Of Hollywood".

story:
We need to raise the money to build the set in a professional theatre so that the show can go ahead. It is a big production and needs a big set. To go with the big cast.
This is a company that ranges from age 4 to adult and promotes confidence and talent for all. The production in November is going to be the product of hard work by all the cast, and it would be a shame not to have the set they desearve.

story:
We are almost there! Help us finish what we started... and make you really like it! Be part of making history and help us dazzle the world with our new Epic Musical.

Thanks to you, we have covered a long way in the journey and we have more to cover. Help us get ready for our workshop with producers to present our project and keep it going and moving towards completion. $20,000 are needed to cover the preparations for the workshop so we can bring our epic musical to life. Be with us as you have always been and help us go there as you helped us come here! We already recorded 6 demo songs in February, shot 2 music videos in April, had a 29-hour reading with top Broadway actors in May as well as 3 concerts in New York City (Queens Central Library, The Triad, 54 Below). The concept for the Make-up, the Sets and the Costumes have been designed and 14 songs are fully composed already. The workshop we are planning in October/November will give a sense of the choreography and of the direction to investors so they can bring the needed funds to complete our project and reach the stages of Broadway. 

Feel proud and share the success. Help us now!

Every dollar really does make a difference! We will give you a lovely THANK YOU on our Facebook Page to our 5596 fans, on Twitter to our 2054 followers and your name will be in our Thanks Page on our official website.

Sets, Make-up and Costumes


First TV coverage on a major Egyptian TV channel!


Music Videos



Cast: 

Christina DeCicco (Evita / Spiderman) as Nefertiti, N’Kenge (Motown / Sondheim on Sondheim) as Queen Ti, Seph Stanek (Naked Boys Singing) as The Scribe, Aaron LaVigne (Spiderman / Rent) as Maho, DJ Bucciarelli (Jesus Christ Superstar / Saturday Night Fever) as Tut Ankh Amon

Creative Team:

Director, Creator and Producer: Hisham Abdel Khalek
Music: Hesham Nazih
Book and Lyrics: Mohamed Metwally 
Producers: Olivier Delesse, Saad Bin Mohammed, N'Kenge Inc., Jason Hewitt
Choreographer: Chet Walker (Pippin, Fosse)
Music Director: Phil Reno (Something Rotten!)
Scenic Design: Riccardo Hernandez (The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess, Caroline)
Projection Design: Aaron Rhyne (A Gentleman's Guide to Love & Murder)
Costumes Design: Giovanni Gobbi (Don Giovanni, Tosca, Così fan Tutte)
Lighting Design: Robert Wierzel (Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill, Fela!)
Makeup Design: Joe Dulude II (If/Then, Wicked)
Hair & Wigs Design: Charles Lapointe  (Newsies The Musical, Violet)
Assistant Director & Choreographer: Alessandro Pellicani (Studio 54 The Musical)
Stage Manager: Andrea Wales (First Date, Anything Goes)
General Managers: Jump Start Enterainment - Roy Gabay & Daniel Kuney (Rock of ages, 39 Steps)
Production Counsel: Jonathan C. Herzog & Nathan Sheffield
Video Documentation: Elliot Storey
Accountant Consultant: Christopher A. Cacace
Graphics Design: Samir Mustapha & Mohsen Gouda

MOTOWN's N'Kenge to Perform Excerpts from AKHENATEN: THE MUSICAL This Weekend
by BWW News Desk - Feb 3, 2015

Tony Nominee Charl Brown Is Part of Tonight's Concert Version of Akhenaten the Musical
By Andrew Gans in Playbill - May 1, 2015

Other ways you can help!

Get the word out! Share this page with your network on social media... 
Thanks you for supporting us.
story_txt:
We are almost there! Help us finish what we started... and make you really like it! Be part of making history and help us dazzle the world with our new Epic Musical.Thanks to you, we have covered a long way in the journey and we have more to cover. Help us get ready for our workshop with producers to present our project and keep it going and moving towards completion. $20,000 are needed to cover the preparations for the workshop so we can bring our epic musical to life. Be with us as you have always been and help us go there as you helped us come here! We already recorded 6 demo songs in February, shot 2 music videos in April, had a 29-hour reading with top Broadway actors in May as well as 3 concerts in New York City (Queens Central Library, The Triad, 54 Below). The concept for the Make-up, the Sets and the Costumes have been designed and 14 songs are fully composed already. The workshop we are planning in October/November will give a sense of the choreography and of the direction to investors so they can bring the needed funds to complete our project and reach the stages of Broadway. Feel proud and share the success. Help us now!Every dollar really does make a difference! We will give you a lovely THANK YOU on our Facebook Page to our 5596 fans, on Twitter to our 2054 followers and your name will be in our Thanks Page on our official website.



    
Sets, Make-up and Costumes





First TV coverage on a major Egyptian TV channel!






Music Videos






Cast: 

Christina DeCicco (Evita / Spiderman) as Nefertiti, N’Kenge (Motown / Sondheim on Sondheim) as Queen Ti, Seph Stanek (Naked Boys Singing) as The Scribe, Aaron LaVigne (Spiderman / Rent) as Maho, DJ Bucciarelli (Jesus Christ Superstar / Saturday Night Fever) as Tut Ankh Amon

Creative Team:

Director, Creator and Producer: Hisham Abdel Khalek


Music: Hesham Nazih


Book and Lyrics: Mohamed Metwally 


Producers: Olivier Delesse, Saad Bin Mohammed, N'Kenge Inc., Jason Hewitt


Choreographer: Chet Walker (Pippin, Fosse)


Music Director: Phil Reno (Something Rotten!)


Scenic Design: Riccardo Hernandez (The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess, Caroline)


Projection Design: Aaron Rhyne (A Gentleman's Guide to Love & Murder)


Costumes Design: Giovanni Gobbi (Don Giovanni, Tosca, Così fan Tutte)


Lighting Design: Robert Wierzel (Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill, Fela!)


Makeup Design: Joe Dulude II (If/Then, Wicked)


Hair & Wigs Design: Charles Lapointe  (Newsies The Musical, Violet)


Assistant Director & Choreographer: Alessandro Pellicani (Studio 54 The Musical)


Stage Manager: Andrea Wales (First Date, Anything Goes)


General Managers: Jump Start Enterainment - Roy Gabay & Daniel Kuney (Rock of ages, 39 Steps)


Production Counsel: Jonathan C. Herzog & Nathan Sheffield


Video Documentation: Elliot Storey


Accountant Consultant: Christopher A. Cacace


Graphics Design: Samir Mustapha & Mohsen Gouda

story: We are a group of young artists and mental health advocates working to bring awareness to and reduce the stigma against mental health through the performing arts. However, we need your help with our start-up costs. We will need to rent out a rehearsal space, pay venue costs, royalty payments to the playwrights of the plays we will be performing, costumes, and various other materials and equipment needed for performance. By donating to us, you are directly contributing to the end of silence surrounding mental health. If you cannot contribute, please share this campaign around on social media, tell your friends and family, and help us spread the word. You can also make a donation to us with costumes, materials, props, equipment, make-up, and anything else you can think of. Thank you so much in advance for your help. We could not do this without you.

story:
We’re going to Scotland! But we need your help.

The Beyond the Page Theatre Company at West Potomac High School was chosen to perform at the world’s largest arts festival, the Edinburgh Fringe, in August, 2015. Thirty-four students are going as actors and tech, to perform the musical, The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee, in front of an international audience. Read what the students are saying about this incredible opportunity.

We can’t even describe the feeling of excitement buzzing around the drama department (yes, even more than usual)!

But here’s the thing. A two-week trip to Scotland costs money. Lots of money. For plane tickets, accommodations and meals. For 34 people.

 

We know it’s a lot of money to raise. That’s why we’ve been raising funds since we found out we were going to Fringe, with special performances, babysitting nights, a yard sale, and even a car show. And now we’re asking you.

No matter what you give, please know that your donation will go directly to funding our trip to Scotland.

And don't forget to tell your friends!

Thank you!

story:
Too Much Drama A Stage Play

We are Black Elixir Media, a Fort Myers FL entertainment company, Co-Owned by Marcus Colón and LaShanda Hutchins Colón. As an African American stage production, this play will mean so much to a community, that doesn't get to see people of color on stage that much. Too Much Drama is a play that touches on domestic violence, kids who deal with step parents, a parent who has just be released from prison and other topics relevant to the community. To make this happen we need to raise $1,500. The money will go to renting the venue, set construction, costumes, and promotions. This inspirational Stage Play is one of a kind and written by the Producer Marcus Colón and co directed by LaShanda Hutchins Colón. 
These types of productions are important to the community at large, because they not only promote the arts, but they also help to promote diversity in those arts. 
We absolutely need YOUR HELP!  Because without it we will NOT be able to bring this production to life. But your assistance is not without perks. Donating you will receive the following
$1 The good feeling for helping out. 
$5  Name Listed on our official website as a donor  
$10 Name Listed on our official website as a donor and listed in the program
$25 Name Listed on our official website as a donor and listed in the program along with 1 cast autographed poster
$50 Name Listed on our official website as a donor and listed in the program.  1 free ticket to the performance along with 1 cast autographed poster.
$100 Bronze Donor: Name Listed on our official website as a donor and listed in the program.  2 tickets to the performance. 2 Cast autographed posters
$250 Silver Donor Name Listed on our official website as a donor and listed in the program. 4 free tickets to the performance and 4 cast autographed posters.  
$500 Gold Donor Name Listed on our official website as a donor and listed in the program. Name mentioned during opening performance talk. 6 free tickets to the performance and 6 cast autographed posters.  Preferred seating at the performance. And 2 free "Too Much Drama" Autographed  T Shirts
$750 Platinum Donor Name Listed on our official website as a donor and listed in the program. 8 free tickets to the performance and 8 cast autographed posters.  Preferred seating at the performance.  And 4 free "Too Much Drama" Autographed  T Shirts
$1000 Diamond Donor Everything in the platinum donor package. 10 free tickets to the performance and 10 cast autographed posters.   Preferred seating at the performance.  And 6 free "Too Much Drama" Autographed  T Shirts

story:
Hi! 

We are MI MAMA ME MIMA Theatre Group! Welcome to our Indigogo page for our new play "En Exclusiva" that tells the story of a Mother's desperation to keep her son from being deported to their country of origin.  

The play will open on July 10th 2015 at the Dorie Theatre in Hollywood. 

My name is Agustin Melendez, I'm the writer/director. I came to the States 15 years ago. (Man, that feels like a long time ago!) 

After many struggles to survive in this great country I feel like this is home now and I feel proud to say that I am a member of the Immigrant Community in Los Angeles. 

My mother Roxanne (Which is the hottest and smartest producer in town, haha) and I (not too hot and smart because I need her help to produce this play) welcome you to know more about our theatre group and our new play that will run this summer for the whole month of July. 

We strongly believe that Theatre is a poweful communication tool that will help us spread the message of the IMPORTANCE and NECESITY OF A COMPREHENSIVE IMMIGRATION REFORM and let people know through entertainment more about the every day challenges that the Immigrants of this country face daily.

With your help and donations we can reach more audiences by creating an impact in the community of Los Angeles and hopefully to other cities in the country.

story:
Medicine Ball: Playwrights v. Poets is in danger!

The mafia is taking over!

For the past three years, Seattle Theatre Works has been fully producing this annual literary boxing match which brings a team of 7 playwrights and 7 poets together to test their mettle against one another in a fierce competition for some major spoils – either a bottle of Two Buck Chuck for the winners or a can of warm Pabst Blue Ribbon beer for the losers!

Pretty clear, huh?

Well, we don’t like this to be very clear.

That’s why we named our event after an obscure piece of exercise equipment. So we decided to make it even more challenging for the writers and more confusing for the audience by inviting local visual artists to participate! We now use their artwork as prompts for the writers. So when we present the plays and poems, we project the visual art so the audience can see how each writer responded to the piece.

And then the audience gets to vote on which piece they liked better – the play or the poem.

It’s fun. It’s collaborative. It community building.

And it doesn’t make any money at all.

So now - as you can see in the video above – the mafia is about to infiltrate the event.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Please help Seattle Theatre Works maintain its integrity. If we can make our goal, we’ll be able to keep the Mafioso at bay. If we don’t, the mob will take over with their bookies and their drug dealers and their strippers and their concrete boots. Who knows if any of the poets or playwrights will even get out alive?

Not only will your contribution keep the mafia at bay, it will help us pay for the rental space at the lovely Erickson Theatre on Capitol Hill in early February, clothe our actors in costume pieces, light them so they look pretty, print some posters so people know this event is happening, and buy some booze to serve people during the show – because there is nothing better than watching a literary boxing match except watching a literary boxing match completely drunk.

And in order to expose more people to this weird, convoluted event – and help the writers reach a broader audience - each $20 donation will buy 1 ticket that will be given to a local charity who can in turn either auction the tickets off, give them to donors, or share them with the clients they serve. The mafia doesn’t like this – and they especially don’t like that it’s cumulative – a $40 donation equaling two tickets to charity, $100 equaling five.

Charities you can choose to donate your tickets to:

  • North Seattle College Education Fund
  • University District  Food Bank
  • Humane Society For Seattle and King County

RISKS

Are there risks? Besides the possibility that a writer might accidentally poke their eye out with a pencil, the MAFIA WILL TAKE OVER! They’re already talking to writers about fixing the competition!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We know you don’t want the mafia to turn our tongue-in-cheek literary competition between teams of writers both toiling away in dying art forms that have lost almost all their cultural relevance and turn it into a Vegas style show with glitter and legs and tiger acts. But we also know many people don’t have money – especially other writers and artists – because, well, you’re writers and artists. So if you can’t donate but still want to help us foil this coup this mafia is planning, please do share this fundraising campaign with friends s long as they don’t have any mafia ties. We’re trying to keep this on the down low.

story:
A statement from Douglas Lyons, Founder and Director of the Next Wave Initiative: 
Our nation is currently mourning, while simultaneously healing itself. In times like these I always look towards a solution; a way to pave a path towards America's future. The Next Wave Initiative allows the conversations around "Broadway equality" to become action. This program will fight to erase the ugliness of our past, while investing in the future of our profession. 

Mission Statement: 
The Next Wave Initiative is a developmental branch of The Directors Company, committed to amplifying future Black voices in The American Theatre. 

Your Part: 
100% of the proceeds from our apparel directly funds our scholarships, awards, grants, outreach programs and operational costs. Your purchase today finances a Black artist's dream tomorrow.  For more information, please reach out to nextwave@directorscompany.org.

​

How will The Next Wave Initiative Achieve its Mission? 

AWARDS and SCHOLARSHIPS 

The Lorraine Hansberry Writing Scholarship
A scholarship payment of $1,959 honoring 1959, the year Lorraine Hansberry made history as the first African-American playwright to debut on Broadway with A Raisin in The Sun. This scholarship is granted to a promising Black artist pursuing a career in Literature, Creative writing, Theatre or Screenplay writing. 

The Spike Lee Directing Scholarship
A scholarship payment of $1,986 honoring 1986, the year Spike Lee made his directorial debut with She's Gotta Have It. This scholarship is granted to a promising Black artist pursuing a collegiate education in direction for stage or screen.

The Hattie McDaniel Acting Scholarship
A scholarship payment of $1,940 honoring 1940, the year Hattie McDaniel became the first Black actor to win an Oscar award for her performance in Gone with The Wind. This scholarship is granted to a Black actor/actress pursuing theatre or film acting on the collegiate level.

The Alvin Ailey Dance Scholarship
A scholarship payment of $1,958 honoring 1958, the year Ailey founded his Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. This scholarship is granted to a Black artist pursuing dance on the collegiate level.  

DEVELOPMENT WING

The First Burp Grant
This grant is awarded to a new play or musical written by a Black artist that has yet to be produced. The grant of $1,000 goes directly towards funding the first 29 Hour reading presentation of said new work. 

OUTREACH
The James Baldwin Group a partnership between Black youth ages 12-18 and Black Broadway performers using poetry, art, dance, and writing as a means of healing. 

 The Directors Company is a 501(c)3, nonprofit theater company celebrating 40 years of supporting emerging theater artists in the development and production of their work. 

How You Can Help

Donate and spread the word!
It's a way for you to directly pour promise into the next generation of BIPOC Theatre Artists

PURCHASE OUR BLM INSPIRED T-SHIRTS

 

100% of net proceeds from t-shirt sales will directly fund the Next Wave Initiative.

story:
Hello! My name is Danielle O'Neill and I am the proud founder of Act I - Act III (a fiscally sponsored non-profit).  I have taught and performed in the Los Angeles community for decades. Through the years, I've seen how youth are impacted by performance art and I have also sadly seen performers, who were my mentors years ago, find the need to work in other fields to maintain their livelihood.  Act I- Act III is designed to help both ends of that age spectrum.  We found a diamond in the rough in Pasadena to be our new home for this thriving educational and performance theater. This historical theater has been vacant for decades and needs several renovations to bring it back to life.  For example, the theater needs wood floor, where our students will take classes and seating for our guests during live performances. 

** Our campaign officially ends soon, but after that we will still be able to accept donations via Indiegogo! We chose this platform because it allows us to keep any amount we raise to put toward our goals. Even before the renovations are complete we will be able to use the space for a Summer Youth Program! Learn more about that here. **

All donations will be both helping the Act I- Act III programming as well as helping build out this once beautiful Vaudeville Theater, back to serve in the community once more!

  • Your funding helps pay for kids of all economic backgrounds to receive training in performing arts. Studies show youth that learn performing arts at a young age develop better memory and creativity skills to help them through their general education. 
  • Your funding helps hire seniors and artists that have aged out of the industry. Giving them a second career in the field they started in!
  • Your funding helps restore and build out a 1924 Historical Theater in Pasadena, bringing it back to glory.

We have had many challenges over the past 2 years with raising funds, as many grants have paused funding due to the pandemic. Also, building expenses have tripled in cost at the same time.  This is why we need your help to get this project completed.

As a huge thank you, we have many fantastic perks from $25 - $10,000. No donation is too small! Thank you in advance!

If donating is not an option for you at this moment, you can still help! Please share and get the word out, this will help us tremendously too.

** Our campaign officially ends soon, but after that we will still be able to accept donations via Indiegogo! We chose this platform because it allows us to keep any amount we raise to put toward our goals. Even before the renovations are complete we will be able to use the space for a Summer Youth Program! Learn more about that here. **
All donations will be both helping the Act I- Act III programming as well as helping build out this once beautiful Vaudeville Theater, back to serve in the community once more!

Your funding helps pay for kids of all economic backgrounds to receive training in performing arts. Studies show youth that learn performing arts at a young age develop better memory and creativity skills to help them through their general education. 


Your funding helps hire seniors and artists that have aged out of the industry. Giving them a second career in the field they started in!
Your funding helps restore and build out a 1924 Historical Theater in Pasadena, bringing it back to glory.

We have had many challenges over the past 2 years with raising funds, as many grants have paused funding due to the pandemic. Also, building expenses have tripled in cost at the same time.  This is why we need your help to get this project completed.
As a huge thank you, we have many fantastic perks from $25 - $10,000. No donation is too small! Thank you in advance!
If donating is not an option for you at this moment, you can still help! Please share and get the word out, this will help us tremendously too.

story:
Connecting.  Coaching.  Creating.

Young Choreographers Project is about connecting, coaching, and creating. Beginning in February, young aspiring dancers from the inner-city of Los Angeles will be partnered with professional dance mentors.  Students will work closely with dance professionals over an 8-week period to create original dance pieces that will be showcased in April.  We have already been able to touch the lives of over 100 students, and we would love to expand this opportunity to more communities in the Los Angeles area.  However, we need YOUR support to make this happen.

Program Dates:  February 5, 2017 - March 26, 2017

Tech Rehearsal:  April 1, 2017

Final Showcase:  April 2, 2017 

The Impact

What we have found is that the process of creating through the art of choreography provides each student with an incresed sense of confidence and self-esteem, and it gives them the ability to truly express themselves through movement.  In addition, our students learn how to be leaders and to effectively communicate their thoughts and ideas to their peers. 

Socialization Benefits:  Dance education can help students improve their social and communication skills, learn how to work as part of a team, and develop a greater sense of trust and cooperation.

Educational Benefits:  Becoming a skilled dancer requires practice, discipline and focus, skills that can be useful in other areas of a child's life. Students who have a background in dance tend to achieve significantly higher SAT scores and do better in math and science competitions.

Improved Self-Esteem:  As children adjust to the movements and postures required in dance, they begin to get a better sense of their bodies. As they become more comfortable in their own skin, their confidence and self-esteem also improve. Dance lessons can encourage children to foster a more positive attitude and explore their own self-expression. 

What Your Donation Will Provide

Young dancers will have the opportunity to create something from nothing, to work through and develop their own choreographic process.  Each student will develop a concept, create movement, stage their piece, lead peers in rehearsals, and showcase his/her work at a final performance in April.  

  • Mentoring Program (Studio/rehearsal space and supplies):  40%
  • Showcase Expenses (Venue rental, insurance, costumes, etc.):  45%
  • Advertising/Marketing:  10%
  • Indiegogo Fees:  5%

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute but would still like to help out, please let others know about our campaign by telling your friends and getting the word out on social media. For more information about becoming a mentor for Young Choreographers Project, email info@ycpla.org or visit www.ycpla.org. If you are interested in joining the everybody dance!  program, email info@everybodydance.org or visit www.gabri.org.

story:
Short Summary

In brief:

The formative years of young lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) are more difficult than those of their heterosexual and cis-gender counterparts. We want to change that. We believe theatre is a vehicle to show young people they are not alone but also to present new information to the rest of the population in an interesting and engaging manner.

 

The ‘long story’:

  • Our first foray into live, original theatre was a big success but also a learning curve. We are convinced that, after receiving advice from critics and industry professionals we can make ‘Sexual Fears of a Modern Day Virgin’ a success whilst maintaining its focus on representing young LGBTQ people. We know from feedback and interest in planned performances that the play’s message is increasingly relevant as conservative societal forces grow - this is Rant and Rave’s raison d’etre.  We are determined to develop and improve the play dramatically.
  • Our primary aim is not only to help young LGBTQ people to feel accepted and represented, but to show them it is possible to create shows around minority identities that are successful. Through social media we will maintain contact with our audiences, providing them with advice on how they can participate in and create their own theatre. Our secondary aim is to confront our audience with identities they have not considered before, explored in an intriguing and theatrically exciting way. We want our audience to be encouraged to think, discuss, and question sexuality and gender identity, and to explore the breadth of identities which exist in a positive and accepting manner.
  • We will experiment with the dramaturgical challenges of presenting naturalistic theatre which engages with the audience. Our first focus has been the sensitive and accurate representation of the LGBTQ community; the next step will challenge us to present those honest stories in an even more dramatically exciting way that audiences can relate to. This is a key second step on the road towards popular theatre which is not rooted in broad, identity politics, but rather the experiences of individuals interacting with other individuals.

What We Need & What You Get

£500 (with the other funding we have secured) will allow us to fund the upcoming tour of ‘Sexual Fears of a Modern Day Virgin’. This includes the cost of hiring venues, paying for the travel and accommodation costs of all cast and crew, and the cost of the set. If we secure more than this £500 we will be able to look into paying the subsistence cost of the cast and crew (as no one is receiving a salary).

We are currently planning these performances of ‘Sexual Fears of a Modern Day Virgin’:

  • The Maddermarket Theatre, Norwich - matinee and evening performance on the 10th May.
  • We will then take the show to London for two nights (venue TBC).
  • Finally, we will go to the Lantern @ ACT at the Brighton Fringe Festival on the 29th May, 1st, 2nd and 3rd June,
  • We will also do two free performances for local LGBTQ youth groups in Norwich and then in Brighton.

The Impact

We believe that spreading positive awareness of, and normalising, LGBTQ experiences, especially for young people, is a valuable endeavour that will not only widen the artistic base of LGBTQ theatre in the UK. We are convinced that original theatre delivered by Rant and Rave can change minds.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help us financially, please, share this page to your social media. Every share spreads our message. We also have an email template available to anyone who wants to spread this message via email! Just contact us at info@rantandravetheatre.com.

story:
ABOUT SCUM: a manifesto

Scantily Glad Theatre is proud to bring its latest show, SCUM: A MANIFESTO, a provocative new satire, on a tour of the Canadian Fringe circuit.

In 1967, Valerie Solanas wrote the radically feminist “S.C.U.M. Manifesto: Society for Cutting Up Men,” which suggested that in order for women to be truly liberated, they must overthrow the government and kill all men. SCUM: A MANIFESTO is a look inside the mind of the woman who shot Andy Warhol and an examination of the feminist movement today. Watch us cross the line of traditional theatre, over and over...

Our tour begins with the St-Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival from June 8-June 18 at Mainline Theatre, followed by the Hamilton Fringe Theatre Festival from July 20th-30th and finally the Edmonton International Fringe Tour from August 17th-27th. 

Since its premiere at the PotashCorp Saskatoon Fringe Theatre Festival in 2016, the play has undergone a developmental workshop by Canadian playwright, Vern Thiesen (Einstein’s Gift, Vimy) and was featured in the Saskatchewan Playwrights Centre’s Spring Festival of New Plays.

SCUM is created entirely by female theatre artists: Laura Andreas (Stage Manager), S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor),  Danielle Spilchen (Director) and Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor).

ABOUT SCANTILY GLAD THEATRE

We are Scantily Glad Theatre: an emerging independent theatre company from Saskatoon. Founded in 2014, our mandate is to create original, thought-provoking theatre that promotes the work of female artists. Our mission isto create new work that tackles important socio-political issues and changes the way our audience looks at the world. Created by an all-female ensemble, we are proud to be bringing this show across Canada. 

Director, Danielle Spilchen, has toured the Canadian Fringe Circuit with award-winning Fringe comedies: Aiden Flynn Lost His Brother So He Makes Another, Dr. Frightful Presents: Dead Air and Southern Dandy 75! Creator/performers, S.E. Grummett & Caitlin Zacharias have been working together for over 5 years, creating raunchy, bold new work.

 Scantily Glad Theatre’s first show, The Loveseat premiered at the PotashCorp Saskatoon Fringe Festival last summer. The Loveseat told the story of David and Anna, a young couple going through a divorce, who must reexamine their relationship after they can’t decide who keeps the couch. SCUM: A MANIFESTO is the second work by Scantily Glad Theatre. 

WHY TELL THIS STORY?

"THE KILL BILL OF FEMINISM" (Fringe Audience Review)

When we first encountered Val and her infamous manifesto, we immediately thought “Wow, what an interesting idea for a play.” Originally, we had intended to write SCUM as a razor-sharp comedy that poked fun at the expense of feminists. Yet the more we researched Val’s story and witnessed the events of the past year (the Stanford rapist, the war on reproductive rights, and the “Pussy Grabber” himself), we realized that despite half a century between them, women today are still fighting the same fight as Valerie. To steal a phrase from social media slang: we got woke, and got woke fast. However radical, Valerie’s manifesto expresses a frustration that most women can connect with at one point in their lives. The more we worked on SCUM, the more we recognized sexism and oppression in our own lives, and the more we realized we had more to say. 

Throughout the process of bringing this to the Saskatoon Fringe, we found that Val’s story was rather unknown to the general public and most people didn’t even know Andy Warhol was shot. After learning of Val’s tragic past, we recognized her story as an important one to tell in today’s current political climate: a cautionary tale of what happens when a woman is pushed to her breaking point. Not only does the play express Val’s life-long struggle to be seen, but we see Warhol’s struggle navigating the spotlight as an artist, something we as emerging artists also connected with. The art of the show comes from its mix of dark humour and pathos, while boldly strolling into absurdity. We combine the world of Andy Warhol and his Factory with the dark violence of Valerie’s manifesto and bring the audience through an investigation of the messy fight for gender equality going on in our modern world. 

While the many rights of women have progressed since Solanas’ time, we remain a long way from true equality between the sexes. Even the world of Canadian theatre is far from equal, with only approximately 30% of Canada’s artistic directors, working directors and playwrights being women. The glass ceiling is not only in the corporate-world, but deeply ingrained in our artistic communities. The longer we work on SCUM, the more deeply we fall down the rabbit hole…

Theatre is a powerful medium for exposing problems in our society. It connects an audience to the struggles of individual characters in a shared space. Rather than using theatre as a way of escaping, SCUM’s satire of the status quo challenges audience members to examine the everyday oppressions in their own lives. By using raunchy, “in-yer-face” humour, we hope to showcase work created by nasty women for nasty women that is as entertaining as it is socially provocative. 

While Valerie’s manifesto was considered shocking at the time, it provided a bold analysis of the systematic oppression of women: something frighteningly relevant today. With 2017 marking the 50 anniversary of the publication of the S.C.U.M. manifesto, and the recent international success of the Women’s March, there is no better time to tell this story, nor is it more pertinent.

MEET OUR TURDS

Laura Andreas (Stage Manager) is excited to be a part of SCUM a manifesto with these awesome women!  Laura is a graduate of the University of Saskatchewan with a BA in Drama. Select Credits: Stage manager for The Clockmaker (Neverending Highway Productions/Embrace Theatre/Live Five), and Stop Kiss (Embrace Theatre/Live Five); and apprentice stage manager for Mary Poppins (Western Canada Theatre/Persephone Theatre), The Farndale Avenue Housing Estate Townswomen's Guild Dramatic Society's Production of A Christmas Carol (Persephone Theatre), Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike (Persephone Theatre), Vigil (Persephone Theatre), The Highest Step in the World (Ghost River Theatre/Persephone Theatre) and Hedda Gabler (Persephone Theatre).

S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor) is an emerging theatre artist and filmmaker from Saskatoon and a recent grad with a BFA in Acting at the University of Saskatchewan. She has performed on the Greystone stage in Picasso at the Lapin Agile, Caucasian Chalk Circle and Coram Boy. In 2015, Grummett premiered her first solo-written play, The Loveseat, at the PotashCorp Saskatoon Fringe Festival, which she wrote as part of SPC’s 24-Hour Playwriting Competition in 2014. Sarah also directs for the screen. Her first feature, Paper Airplanes, premiered at the Yonkers International Film Festival in New York and she has made a number of short films. This summer, Grummett is gearing up to take her latest show, SCUM: a manifesto on a tour of the Canadian Fringe circuit. Recently, Grummett worked as a sound designer and assistant stage manager on Les Liaisons-Dangereuses (Theatre Naught). In the fall, Grummett will be working as a video designer for Live Five’s first show of season: Grounded.

Danielle Spilchen (Director) is a Saskatoon based theatre artist with a Bachelor of Fine arts from the University of Saskatchewan. She made her directorial debut in the 2015 Short Cuts Festival where she directed a short play titled Baggage. Danielle also has been a long time collaborator on the award winning show Aiden Flynn Lost His Brother So He Makes Another. With this show Danielle has travelled to seven Canadian cities on the Fringe circuit, one of the cities being Montreal where the show was nominated for two different awards and winning the Best English Production resulting in Aiden Flynn being part of the 2015 Wild Side Festival in the Centaur Theatre. Aiden Flynn was later accepted into the 2015/2016 Live Five Season in Saskatoon where she continued to be a part of the development and growth of the show. 

Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor) is thrilled to bring SCUM to cities across Canada this summer and to be working again with such an amazing team of women. She has spent the last two years on the Greystone stage playing Thomas (Coram Boy) and Germaine Louzon (Les Belles-Soeurs), and recently completed her fourth year of acting at the U of S. Caitlin believes everyone should have equal opportunities and rights, and that spaghetti can also be a breakfast food. She would like to thank her family and friends for their love, undying support and minimal judgement.

ABOUT THE TOUR:

The St-Ambroise Montréal Fringe Festival is in its 27th year of operation, and runs from June 8-18th, 2017. We will be performing at Venue #6: Mainline Theatre on the following days:

THU 08 June 18:00

SAT 10 June 21:15

SUN 11 June 17:15

WED 14 June 21:00

FRI 16 June 16:15

SUN 18 June 20:15

$10 for adults, $8 for students.

Tickets are available at 514-849-FEST; montrealfringe.ca

The Hamilton Fringe Festival is in its 14th year of operation. The festival runs from July 20 to July 30, 2017 in various venues in around Hamilton. Performance dates are TBA. 

The Edmonton International Fringe Festival is North America's largest and longest running fringe festival, running from August 17th-27th. Performance dates are TBA. 

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS:

Theatre ain't cheap. And as actors, it can be difficult to feed yourself anything more than a cup o' soup, let alone fund a show! But by supporting us through this campaign, you will be helping us bring this show from script to stage.

To tour this project to Montréal, Hamilton and Edmonton, our budget stands at $10,000 to cover all costs associated with travel, accommodation, props, costumes, set, salaries and advertising. Thanks to the generous support of our community, we have raised $2,000 in fundraising and we are hoping to realize the remaining $6,000 in ticket sales over the course of the tour. Your contribution towards our $2,000 Indiegogo goal will help secure the success of this production by preventing us from going out of pocket; and as we say in the theatre if we break even – SUCCESS!

Fringe Application & Venue Fees: $3,930.00

Includes fringe application fees, rental of venue in Edmonton, salary for technician in Edmonton. 

Travel expenses: $4,045.00

Includes, mileage, gas, accommodations (2 actors, 1 director and a set)

Set and Costume Materials: $750.00

Pays for a set to be built, costumes sewn or bought, and props (all the food props our tiny hearts desire). 

Advertising: $1275.00

Includes posters, flyers, programmes, print ads, buttons. 

By raising these funds prior to the Fringe, we are able to use our ticket sales to pay our team and support future creative projects.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please, share this campaign with your friends, family, loved ones, exes, allies and nemeses. If you or anyone you know are in the Montreal, Hamilton or Edmonton areas, please come out and see our show! You can support us by being a member in the audience and sharing in a laugh. 

*MATURE AUDIENCES ONLY: Violence, Nudity, Sexual Content, Course Language and other good stuff* Please: leave the kids at home!

More info available on our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/scantilygladtheatre

Follow us on the Twitter; @scantilygladsk #scummanifesto 

Thank you for your support!

Aiden Flynn was later accepted into the 2015/2016 Live Five Season in Saskatoon where she continued to be a part of the development and growth of the show. Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor) is thrilled to bring SCUM to cities across Canada this summer and to be working again with such an amazing team of women. She has spent the last two years on the Greystone stage playing Thomas (Coram Boy) and Germaine Louzon (Les Belles-Soeurs), and recently completed her fourth year of acting at the U of S. Caitlin believes everyone should have equal opportunities and rights, and that spaghetti can also be a breakfast food. She would like to thank her family and friends for their love, undying support and minimal judgement.ABOUT THE TOUR:The St-Ambroise Montréal Fringe Festival is in its 27th year of operation, and runs from June 8-18th, 2017. We will be performing at Venue #6: Mainline Theatre on the following days:THU 08 June 18:00SAT 10 June 21:15SUN 11 June 17:15WED 14 June 21:00FRI 16 June 16:15SUN 18 June 20:15$10 for adults, $8 for students.Tickets are available at 514-849-FEST; montrealfringe.caThe Hamilton Fringe Festival is in its 14th year of operation. The festival runs from July 20 to July 30, 2017 in various venues in around Hamilton. Performance dates are TBA. The Edmonton International Fringe Festival is North America's largest and longest running fringe festival, running from August 17th-27th. Performance dates are TBA. HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS:Theatre ain't cheap. And as actors, it can be difficult to feed yourself anything more than a cup o' soup, let alone fund a show! But by supporting us through this campaign, you will be helping us bring this show from script to stage.To tour this project to Montréal, Hamilton and Edmonton, our budget stands at $10,000 to cover all costs associated with travel, accommodation, props, costumes, set, salaries and advertising. Thanks to the generous support of our community, we have raised $2,000 in fundraising and we are hoping to realize the remaining $6,000 in ticket sales over the course of the tour. Your contribution towards our $2,000 Indiegogo goal will help secure the success of this production by preventing us from going out of pocket; and as we say in the theatre if we break even – SUCCESS!Fringe Application & Venue Fees: $3,930.00Includes fringe application fees, rental of venue in Edmonton, salary for technician in Edmonton. Travel expenses: $4,045.00Includes, mileage, gas, accommodations (2 actors, 1 director and a set)Set and Costume Materials: $750.00Pays for a set to be built, costumes sewn or bought, and props (all the food props our tiny hearts desire). Advertising: $1275.00Includes posters, flyers, programmes, print ads, buttons. By raising these funds prior to the Fringe, we are able to use our ticket sales to pay our team and support future creative projects.OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPPlease, share this campaign with your friends, family, loved ones, exes, allies and nemeses. If you or anyone you know are in the Montreal, Hamilton or Edmonton areas, please come out and see our show! You can support us by being a member in the audience and sharing in a laugh. *MATURE AUDIENCES ONLY: Violence, Nudity, Sexual Content, Course Language and other good stuff* Please: leave the kids at home!More info available on our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/scantilygladtheatreFollow us on the Twitter; @scantilygladsk #scummanifesto Thank you for your support!

story:
Against the Wall Productions was co-founded by Danielle Kaye and Sarah DiRenno. Both are native New York actors, who were brought together serendipitously by their love of story-telling. Against The Wall Productions is an adventurous new theatre company comprised of actors, directors, musicians, producers and playwrights. We are passionate about the collaboration and integration of both old and new works, and hope to see you at the theatre!

Savage In Limbo

Written By: John Patrick Shanley

Directed By: Wil Hart

Stage Managed By: Dana Saffran

Starring:

Danielle Kaye

Sarah DiRenno

David Spadora

Arielle Beth

Aaron Zapf

Show Dates and Times:

June 15th, 16th, 17th, 22nd, 23rd, 24th at 7pm

June 18th, and 25th at 3pm

Location:

The Secret Theatre

44-02 23rd Street , Long Island City, NY 11101

Tickets:

atwsavage.brownpapertickets.com
