story:
Clumsy Bodies Presents...

Iphigenia Crash Land Falls on the Neon Shell That Was Once Her Heart (A Rave Fable)

A play by Caridad Svich

We are Clumsy Bodies Theatre, a theatre company based in London led by two queer, disabled and gender non-conforming artists.

  Oli Smith is a writer and director; their most recent documentary Asexual has been screened at several LGBTQIA festivals, including in Lesgaicinemad in Spain, Mexico, Chile, Paraguay and Switzerland. Here, they worked collaboratively with those who self-identify as Ace to challenge assumptions around sexuality and relationships to open a lid on an often-silenced world.  

 Jess Rahman-González is an actor and  writer; tired of most available roles in theatre being so gender-specific, they wanted to carve their own space out through writing new roles and narratives. Jess is also a photographer whose photographs have been published in the Metro, gal-dem, and Banshee. They are also a published academic writer; their latest essay about gift exchange is published in University of Oxford’s Mystiques, a feminist homage to Roland Barthes.

Under the neon lights, electronic music and projected videos, Iphigenia Crash Land Falls... is a play about giving voices to those denied one. Iphigenia has been historically silenced from her own sacrificial narrative, and existing on top of this is another story about the women of Juarez, who are being murdered and disappearing even to this day. The women of Juarez are the Greek chorus, the factory workers who sew the Gucci and Prada that Iphigenia wears, but never get to wear. There's also Achilles, a queer celebrity who has a target on his back because "who I am and what I do is punishable by death."

We believe that Iphigenia Crash Land Falls... reflects what we are trying to do as a theatre company. We want to elevate and amplify voices, to work with difference, and never against it, which is an ethos we want to continue as a company after this production.

What We Need Help With:

We are looking for funding to cover the essential costs that may prevent us from getting to Fringe such as:

  • Venue (£1,085)
  • Accommodation in Edinburgh for our cast and crew (£2,090)
  • Travel to and from Edinburgh for our cast and crew (£700)
  • Performance rights (£390)

Even if we do not reach our entire goal, all the money will still go into our listed costs. If we go beyond that goal, then it will go into the other costs, such as performance licences, PRS licences and publicity, as well as financially supporting our cast and crew as much as possible - we want to thank them in some way for the time, energy and love they have poured into this project!

We have had super generous donations from Temple of Seitan, Wellness Centre and Clapham Picturehouse as unique perks for our backers, and we also have a signed copy of the play from the amazing OBIE-award winning playwright, CARIDAD SVICH (we love you, Caridad!)

As students, our finances are incredibly limited. We have invested everything we have into this project, and this theatre company. Our financial constraints put a creative constraint on what we can do in theatre. This is what we want to pursue for the rest of our lives, so the money raised will go towards making our dreams of Edinburgh Fringe possible!

Other Ways of Supporting Us:

Even if you are not able to financially support us, any help with getting the word out to those who can with the indiegogo sharing tools, and general noise about what we are trying to do, is just as appreciated by us!

Facebook: facebook.com/ravefable

Twitter: @ClumsyBodies

 

Lots of queer luv,

Jess & Oli xxxxxx

story:
Short Summary

Hello fellow sponsors!

I am a proud graduate of the Illustrious Clark Atlanta University with a Bachelors in Theatre Arts.  I am a member of the Aurora Theatre Professional Acting Apprenticeship Company Class of 2016. I was selected as  1 of 2 directors for the 2018 Alumni Series based on my submission of Grace, or the Art of Climbing. In this series, directors are expected to self produce a play production. Everything from casting and  production team to marketing and fundraising is completely our responsibility.

I have been managing depression since I was 12 years old. Writing help me cope but Theatre Arts saved my life. I wanted to choose a piece that would help tell the story about those of us who want to conquer this mental illness.    

 

To tell this story we need your help. 

    What We Need

    We are asking you to help us raise at least $5000.

    These funds will aid in the following:

    • Set design/build- materials and labor
    • Lighting 
    • Sound 
    • Props 
    • Costumes
    • Marketing- photography/print
    • Artist Appreciation- Choreographer, Actors, Stage Management, Stage Hand

    The Impact

    We often believe we have to seem flawless in the eyes of our friends and family when really we need their  support to overcome our darkest times. Without them, we doubt our own abilities to climb to the next level. We forget to understand it will not always look or feel graceful. There will be pain, we will fall, but we must learn to never let go- for falling is a part of the climb. Grace, or the Art of Climbing can teach us all how to climb out of not only depression, but grief, and daily challenges that may weigh us down. 

    Risks & Challenges

    If we fail to reach our goal, we would still get this production on its feet but it would not be at its fullest potential. I want all artists who collaborated  and trusted the success of this process to feel appreciated for the work they are contributing as well.  I will be donating personal funds to the project to ensure they do. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please share and use this Indiegogo  link to get the word out to your family, friends, and anyone who would appreciate this production.
